column1: On the Move : 90 Years of Hamburg U-Bahn ; Museum of Work ; [Exhibition On the Move, 90 Years of Hamburg U-Bahn from February 15 to September 1, 2002] ¤ This exhibition shows a side of the Hamburg U-Bahn A.G. - the history of the U-Bahn in Hamburg. For 90 years, it has shaped the face of the city. A subway that in Hamburg did not only run and drive in tunnels, but for the most part of the tracks above ground, over bridges, viaducts, dams. An electrically operated means of transport that at the beginning of the century stood out more than any other for the modernity of the metropolis. It appeared at the beginning with spectacular architecture and changed the perception of the city. The users of the U-Bahn had to get used to the tempo of the means of transport, first learn to deal with the narrowness and foreignness on the platforms and in the trains. The other side of the U-Bahn operation are the people who have maintained it daily for 90 years: U-Bahn drivers, switchmen, electricians, workshop workers in the wagon halls and on the track - they are presented in portraits and objects of their work.

Media Law in the Media Upheaval: Young Science on Industrial Property Protection, Copyright, and Media Law ¤ The present volume documents the results and discussion contributions of the first Assistant Conference Green Area, which took place on June 17 and 18, 2016 at the University of Cologne. Media law problems are discussed around the breakthrough into a European digital economy. Young researchers examine different questions and problems that arise with the digitalization of life worlds, such as linking and framing, the practical significance of the new General Data Protection Regulation, the consequences and opportunities of a right to be forgotten, copyright in the digital age, and possibilities for informational self-determination

Teamwork: Concepts and Experiences - A Group Dynamics Interim Balance ¤ Even more professional, faster, better coordinated and controlled - and even more project-oriented and goal-oriented work. There are only a few organizations and companies that can still avoid this. To achieve the mentioned goals, product boards, management circles, project teams or semi-autonomous working groups are created. Accordingly, teamwork ability is required in almost every job posting. And the trend towards teamwork seems unbroken. Nevertheless, uncertainty prevails in many places about the actual effects of teamwork and the question of the ratio of effort and benefit is repeatedly asked, because: teamwork can be experienced better than described and better described than measured. Content Karl Schattenhofer, Carl Otto Velmerig Introduction: Work in a team or work on a team? Concepts of group and team Volker Linneweber What does social psychology know about groups and teams? Margarete Gerber-Velmerig, Irmengard Hegnauer-Schattenhofer Family - Group - Organization Conny Antoni Group and team work in industry. Experiences and consequences for design Current research results Klaus Antons Team ability: The group as a learning location and as a learning method. The example of the group leader training of the Section Group Dynamics Angelika Behrenberg, Michael Fassnacht Acquisition of team competence in group dynamic further education. Result of an investigation into the sustainability of group dynamic learning Peter Sencar How innovative teams work - results of a deep study Karl Schattenhofer Self-regulation in organization-bound and in "free" teams Problems of practice Christian Schrapper, Monika Thiesmeier How cases can be well understood in groups. Team-oriented diagnosis and consulting processes at the example of social pedagogical case work in child and youth welfare Dankwart Mattke Therapeutic teams and their supervision Gisela Clausen The diagnosis of work ability Bert Voigt Team and teamwork Pro and Contra Teamwork Manfred Muster How does group work pay off? - Success criteria, success control Kurt Buchinger Group work and teamwork in organizations. Ideology and reality Karl Schattenhofer, Carl Otto Velmerig Teamwork between idealization and disillusionment - a group dynamic interim balance The authors

Universalistische Moral and cosmopolitan education : the challenge of globalization in the horizon of modern evolutionary research ; [...Conference on the topic "Universalistische Moral and cosmopolitan education" at the end of September 1999 at the University of the Federal Armed Forces in Hamburg...] ¤ Are there universal standards by which education can orient itself, and are people at all able to move appropriately cognitively and emotionally in a world society? These are just some of the questions that are discussed and dealt with in the contributions of the present volume - which originated from a scientific conference in the autumn of 1999 at the University of the Federal Armed Forces in Hamburg. The common starting point is the search for a theory that makes it possible to describe the complex anthropological and sociological phenomena in a globalized society equally well!

Under the Linden Tree and before the Emperor: New Perspectives on Court Diversity and Court Landscapes in the Holy Roman Empire ¤ The jurisdiction of the pre-modern era was characterized by a nearly unmanageable multitude of courts of various rulers and social groups. While the reception of Roman law and the introduction of learned jurists increasingly professionalized and institutionalized the administration of justice, new bodies of jurisdiction arose due to the establishment of territorial instances and the founding of new universities. The contributions of this volume discuss content-related and methodological approaches that enable the systematic analysis of pre-modern court diversity and the derivation of generalizable insights from comparative considerations.

Night fever : Design and Club Culture : 1960-today ¤ Nightclubs and discotheques are epicenters of pop culture. Since the beginning of the 20th century, avant-garde groups have gathered here, challenging social norms and exploring other levels of reality. Many clubs become total works of art, where interior architecture and furniture design, print graphics and art, light and music, fashion and performance come together in a unique way. With the book Night Fever. Design and Club Culture 1960 – today, a comprehensive overview of the architecture and design history of the nightclub is presented for the first time. Richly illustrated with images of club interiors, posters, flyers, protagonists of nightlife and their fashion.

Forced Labor in National Socialism: Companion Volume to the Exhibition ¤ For the first time, the NS forced labor is documented in its pan-European dimension as a racist societal crime. The exhibition 'Forced Labor in National Socialism' tells the entire history of NS forced labor and its consequences after 1945 for the first time. It shows that forced labor was a mass phenomenon: more than 20 million people had to perform forced labor for Nazi Germany in occupied Europe and the German Reich during World War II. The exhibition highlights how forced labor was part of the racist societal order of the NS state from the beginning: the propagated 'people's community' and the forced labor of the excluded - both belonged together. The volume documents the exhibition in its essential features and presents numerous long unknown historical photos and documents. Additional scientific essays provide a deeper insight into the research on the history of NS forced labor as well as the Weimar 'Gauforum', where the newly opened Museum Forced Labor in National Socialism is located. The sections dealt with are: Acclimation. Violence and exclusion before the war (1933-1939), Radicalization. Forced labor in occupied Europe (from 1939), Mass phenomenon. Forced labor in the German Reich (1942-1945), Liberation. Processing and consequences of forced labor, Damaged justice On May 8, 2024, the 'Museum Forced Labor in National Socialism' will open in the former Gauforum in Weimar under the auspices of the Foundation Memorials Buchenwald and Mittelbau-Dora

On the Way to the Glass University of Applied Sciences: Higher Education Policy Dimensions of Indicator-Dependent Governance; Documentation of the Annual Conference of the Bad Wiesseer Circle from May 25 to 28, 1995 ¤ Content: Trotha, K. von: Quality of Teaching - Evaluation of Universities. - Erichsen, H.-U.: Universities in Competition. - Stubbe, J. W. L.: Financing and Governance of Universities in the Netherlands. - Alderman, G.: The Debate on the Quality of British University Education: Self-Regulation, State Regulation, and the Search for Norms. - Barz, A.: Performance Indicators and Their Importance for Universities of Applied Sciences in Competition between Universities. - Mönch, R.: On the Way to the Glass University of Applied Sciences "Higher Education Policy Dimensions of Indicator-Dependent Governance" (PHF/übern.)

Unterrichtstheorien in Forschung und Lehre : [the volume goes back to a conference ... "The significance of the theory of instruction for teacher education" ... from September 22-23, 2010 in Bensberg near Cologne] ¤ Cliff notes: When instruction is discussed in public, expectations are usually expressed. What actually happens in the classroom seems to rarely meet the wishes associated with the pedagogical form
Change After the Turning Point: Society, Economy, Politics in East Germany ¤ In the year 1992, the DFG began its six-year focus program

Religious Identities in a Globalized World ¤ How do religious communities shape their identity? Under the conditions of migration and an increasingly globalized world, they are increasingly under pressure and in motion. When divergent identities meet, new constellations of encounter and networking emerge. At the same time, the need for demarcation grows. Religion can no longer be thought of as fixed locally, regionally, or even nationally. Content contours shift, new and novel connections emerge, boundaries are questioned, broken, and redefined. The theological and philosophical contributions of this volume ask about religious identities in a globalized world. Authors from all continents discuss various aspects of the topic: from dealing with 'sacred scriptures' to religious learning processes to the relationship between religion and gender. The volume is based on the International Theological Study Days of the Catholic-Theological Faculty in June 2016.

Evaluating Urban Renewal Successfully ¤ The transformation of cities and regions is today one of the great challenges in Germany. Economic structural breaks, demographic change, the competition of regions in the knowledge society and the requirements of the guiding image of sustainable development are at the same time driving forces and cornerstones of the changes. Since the beginning of the new millennium, urban renewal has been carried out with high public funding and great political presence, first in the east, then also in the west of the Federal Republic. In addition to politics and administration, a large number of residents, companies and associations are affected or involved. But are all activities really goal-oriented? Is the expenditure justified? Does public and private action also produce the desired effects? These questions form the starting point of this book. With it, existing experiences and knowledge from science and practice are presented and brought together to evaluate urban renewal processes. This is intended to support and qualify practical evaluation activities and provide suggestions for further scientific discussion.

France Yearbook 2016 : Social and Solidarity Economy in France and Europe ¤ Economic significance of the Third Sector -- Forms of social entrepreneurship -- Theories of common-good-oriented economics -- Legal, political, and organizational framework conditions This collection provides an overview of the social and solidarity economy, which is gaining importance not only in France. Comparatively, different aspects of social and solidarity-based economics and its development in France and Europe are highlighted. Different organizational forms and economic models are described, the importance of the sector in individual branches of the economy is shown and discussed, and whether and to what extent it is an alternative economic model. The content Economic significance of the Third Sector Forms of social entrepreneurship Theories of common-good-oriented economics Legal, political, and organizational framework conditions The target groups France researchers with a cultural, social, and political science background France-interested public, media, and administration as well as practitioners dealing with the topic The publisher The dfi is a social science information and research institute. As a competence center for current France and Franco-German relations, it has been accompanying and shaping Franco-German cooperation in Europe for almost 70 years. Research focuses: Social policy, economic policy, European policy, intercultural communication

Lexicographic Innovation - Innovative Lexicography: Bilingual and Multilingual Dictionaries in the Present and Future: Projects, Concepts, Visions ¤ What current challenges and problems does bilingual lexicography face today? How can traditional and currently perhaps already outdated and obsolete themes and phenomena be presented lexicographically in a new and timely manner today? What difficulties does the creation of dictionaries for languages that are unknown to a well-developed dictionary culture face today, or when the field of lexicography for these languages is rather one-sidedly developed? What must a bilingual dictionary accomplish today, and how is the relationship between print and online dictionaries to be seen in this context? Which themes and areas require more attention in the context of lexicographic research in the future? This collection of essays is intended to provide answers to such questions. It brings together contributions to bilingual dictionaries and dictionary projects as well as to selected lexicographic questions for the languages Brazilian/Portuguese, Chinese, Polish, Russian, Spanish, Turkish, and Ukrainian, which are mostly presented with German as the comparative language. It becomes apparent that today not only new requirements are placed on dictionaries (must be placed), but that the editors of dictionaries are already reacting to changing expectations and designing dictionaries differently. Due to the changed usage conditions and expectations, it seems that the conception of new types of dictionaries will be necessary in the future. The current trends also affect lexicography as a linguistic sub-discipline, so that a rethinking or further thinking is also advocated in this research area today.

Application and Financing in Public Transport : 3rd and 4th Jena Conferences on Public Transport Law ¤ Personenbeförderungsgesetz, Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007 and European State Aid Law form significant legal benchmarks for public transport. The practical application of this legal framework is associated with considerable challenges. This is all the more true as, in recent years, a comprehensive decision-making practice has developed due to divergent application. The conference proceedings show the fundamental legal questions, deal with central problems in detail, and evaluate the legal situation from scientific and practical perspectives. With contributions from Prof. Dr. Matthias Knauff; Prof. Dr. Michael Fehling; Dr. Michael Winnes; Dr. Witgar Weber; Dr. Corina Jürschik; Prof. Dr. Claas Friedrich Germelmann; Dr. Christian Baumann; Dr. Markus U. Brohm; Christiane Leonard, Tobias Kothy; Prof. Martin Kupfrian; Dr. Astrid Karl, Christoph Schaaffkamp; Dr. Lorenz Wachinger.

Person Injury Conference 2019 ¤ The concern of the Institute for Fair Damage Regulation, established in the first half of 2019, is to explore in detail what it means that the perpetrator or the liability insurer behind them must compensate the loss of the claimant as provided for by law. The first training event in Berlin (November 7-8, 2019) aims to bring all parties involved in the regulation of personal injuries up to date and question the persuasiveness of opposing arguments. Current topics to be treated include the permissible use of specialized service providers by liability insurers for the evaluation of evidence and data collection as well as the burden of proof in the liability process. An overview of the case law of the past half year will be provided for four core areas.

Psychiatric Reform as Social Reform: The Legacy of National Socialism and the Breakthrough of the Sixties ¤ Social state, marginalized groups and federal republic society. Changes and developments in the 60s and early 70s / Wilfried Rudloff ; Section IV: Reform everyday life and analysis in interregional comparison: Introduction / Berd Eikelmann -- Psychiatric reform as social reform. The example of the 'Citizens' Aid Social Psychiatry Frankfurt am Main e.V.' / Wolfgang Pittrich -- 'From the breakthrough to a different future'. Bremen psychiatry between 1945 and 1975 / Helmut Haselbeck, Gerda Engelbracht -- The chronically mentally ill 'on the sidelines of psychiatric reform'. The example of Bavaria / Hans-Ludwig Siemen Introduction / Franz-Werner Kersting ; Section I: The institution between euthanasia and reform: Institutional psychiatry under the conditions of the 'breakdown society': Introduction / Hans-Walter Schmuhl / Heinz Faulstich -- Structural crisis and reform beginning: Institutional psychiatry in the GDR and the Federal Republic up to the 60s / Sabine Hanrath -- Before Ernst Klee. The legacy of NS medical crimes as a reform impulse / Franz-Werner Kersting ; Section II: Psychiatry inquiry: Introduction / Andreas Crome / The Rodewischer theses of 1963--an attempt to reform GDR psychiatry / Jörg Schulz -- Practical reform approaches in the 60s: Therapeutic group work in the psychiatric hospital / Alexander Veltin -- The inquisition of the mentally ill is coming to an end. The history of the psychiatry inquiry and psychiatric reform in Germany / Heinz Häfner -- 'Waiting room with hope'. Psychiatry and reform in the mirror of contemporary films from Gütersloh, Bremen and Eickelborn (1963/67). Attempt at evaluation / Volker Jakob ; Section III: Psychiatric reform and democratization under the sign of '68: Introduction / Merit Niehuss -- Reform as social movement: The 'Mannheim circle' and the founding of the 'German Society for Social Psychiatry' / Manfred Bauer -- Radical psychiatric criticism in the FRG. On the Socialist Patient Collective in Heidelberg / Cornelia Brink --

Literature as a Philosophical Model of Knowledge: Literary-Philosophical Discourses in Germany and France ¤ Since antiquity, the relationship between literature and philosophy has been determined in each era in its own way. Particular importance is gained by literature for the project of Enlightenment: Here it becomes relevant as a medium of education and perfectibility of man, especially but in connection with a programmatically becoming correlation of thought and action with the French Revolution of the year 1789. At the same time, a new - strictly rationalistic - concept of science generates from the late 18th century a crisis of philosophical-metaphysical language as well as an increasing separation of the aesthetic and the epistemological discourse. Against this background, the contributions of the volume investigate the constellation of literature and philosophy in Germany and France in the long 19th century. The problem of epistemological and linguistic skepticism and the competition of a specific knowledge of poetry and a specific knowledge of philosophy as well as the resulting possibilities and limits of perception of knowledge are also addressed, as well as questions of the conceptualization of knowledge and epistemic performance, the truth and knowledge claim of poetry, and concepts of the mediality of literature in the sense of the representation or representability of metaphysical problem constellations. With contributions to Charles François Dominique de Villers, Johann Gottlieb Fichte, Friedrich Hölderlin, Heinrich von Kleist, Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, Heinrich Heine, Gérard de Nerval, Honoré de Balzac, Wilhelm Dilthey, Friedrich Nietzsche, Stéphane Mallarmé, Robert Musil, Paul Valéry, Christian Morgenstern, Frank Kafka, Martin Heidegger u. a.

Topographies of Literature: German Literature in a Transnational Context ¤ Dem Interesse an der kulturellen Bedeutung des Raumes ( topographical turn') comes to great importance for the entire humanities and cultural sciences. In a cross-section from medieval literature to the most recent present, topics such as "Representations of discursive spaces", "Spaces of literature", "Literary spaces" and "The boundaries and the foreign" are negotiated. Dem Interesse an der kulturellen Bedeutung des Raumes ( topographical turn') comes to great importance for the entire humanities and cultural sciences.

Education and Prevention: Reflections from Theory and Practice on a Much-Debated Connection ¤ This volume discusses various interdisciplinary approaches from science and practice on the connection between education (as a resource for a self-responsible life), crime, and prevention. On the one hand, education is a fundamental prerequisite for leading a self-responsible life. On the other hand, it often fails delinquent youth to utilize education as a resource. They exhibit, in addition to breaks in their formal educational biographies and missing educational qualifications, a large distance to learning and educational offers. What chance can education offer them? What connections can be sketched between education and crime from a preventive perspective? The volume seeks answers to these questions through various approaches from science and practice.

The Office: On the Rationalization of the Interior, 1880-1960 ¤ With the second industrial revolution, the service sector begins to grow significantly. At the end of the 19th century, the number of employees in banks, trade, industries, and insurance companies increases. The rationalization of these companies establishes a specialized and at the same time universal space that advances to the operational center of both private economy and public administration: In the office, machines, furniture, and people come together - form and function connect. The contributions of the volume show the office as a space of rationalization and the imaginary, which is still considered 'the real focus of the living space' (Walter Benjamin), as the center of administrative and social life.

Win, Lose, Transform: European City Regions in Motion ¤ Cities and regions are undergoing a profound transformation. But what new phenomena of spatial development are to be recognized and how can they be interpreted? What are the causes or driving forces? How do they change the space and what impact do they have on society and politics? The change of the European urban system and urban policy is at the center of this volume. If one understands 'development' as a change in relatively stable conditions and 'transformation' as a reaction to a significantly changing context, then a transformation process is currently taking place in German and European city regions. This affects the structures in politics and planning. Against the background of economic, social, and political reactions to the recent globalization push with its widely discussed apparent and invisible effects on the European urban system, contributions from different countries are compiled. The key terms are metropolization, locational competition, and profiling. The authors investigate causes, phenomena, and consequences of transformation processes in the European context. For the cities, the question arises: win, lose, or transform?

Humboldt-Forum Berlin : the project - the project ¤ The book provides a comprehensive outline of the Humboldt-Forum project for the first time. It summarizes the current state of the debate and will accompany it in the coming years. So far, the debate about the Humboldt-Forum has been conducted almost exclusively as an architecture and history debate. After the demolition of the Palace of the Republic and the competition decision in favor of Franco Stella's design, the concrete visions and plans for the Humboldt-Forum are now at the center of interest. As an innovative cultural and knowledge center, as a place of recognition and encounter for the world, the Humboldt-Forum is to intertwine publicness and experience - exemplarily for the 21st century - and at the same time confer a central public definition on the urban center of Berlin. On the occasion of the exhibition shown from July 8, 2009 at the Old Museum, in which the future main users, the Prussian Cultural Heritage Foundation with its State Museums in Berlin, the Central and State Library Berlin and the Humboldt University presented their plans publicly for the first time, Humboldt-Forum Berlin appears at Theater der Zeit. The book will document the integrative idea of the Humboldt-Forum, the project planning of its main users and the results of the architecture competition. Furthermore, it is about illuminating the intellectual challenge of the project and taking up the expectations of the public (from politics, culture, art and science). Even critical voices against the project are heard. Special chapters are devoted to international experiences in presenting world cultures as well as international reference projects for newer cultural buildings.

Paths to the New Federal Republic: Political Myths and Collective Self-Images after 1989 ¤ After 1989, the Federal Republic had to redefine its self-image and historical tradition. That Adenauer was elected the most important German, the memory of 68 was maintained, or dealing with the 'German Autumn' is evidence of the new handling of one's own history. The contributions illuminate the politically cultural and historically relevant debates, including those on patriotism and leading culture.

Fontane's Media ¤ The international congress "Fontane's Media (1819-2019)", which the Theodor-Fontane-Archiv of the University of Potsdam organized on this occasion and whose lectures form the basis of the present collection, [...].

Seine Welt wissen : Encyclopedias in the Early Modern Period ; [Catalogue for the exhibition of the University Library Leipzig and the Herzog August Library Wolfenbüttel] ¤ Publisher's text: The old culture of the printed book has been dedicated to the dissemination of knowledge from the very beginning. This is evidenced by the extensive holdings of the Herzog August Library Wolfenbüttel and the University Library Leipzig, which are presented here. The impressively illustrated volume provides the first overview of encyclopedias in the first 250 years of the printing age. These mostly richly illustrated books are understood as >>knowledge machines>>, as contemporary information media, which make phenomena of our everyday life appear in a new light, as if by instinct, by reaching for a dictionary or searching on the internet.

Stability in the Persian Gulf - Regional and Transatlantic Perspectives : 132. Bergedorfer Roundtable, 2. - 4. December 2005, Dubai, [132. Bergedorfer Protocol] ¤ The interventions in Afghanistan and Iraq have fundamentally changed the balance of power in the Middle East. At the same time, the challenges in the social, economic, and political areas have continued to grow. The conflict over Iran's nuclear program and the escalating violence in Iraq have given the question of regional stability new urgency. In solving it, the conceptions of actors from the Gulf states play a key role. The 132nd Bergedorf Roundtable in Dubai therefore mainly discussed regional approaches. Politicians and experts from the region, the US, and Europe analyzed possible ways to political stability in the Persian Gulf. The role of economic growth and political reforms, as well as the connection between democratization and stabilization, were in the center. It was about the relationship between modernization and identity, secularism and religion, traditional and Western conceptions, and between internal reform and external support. A focus of the discussion were security policy challenges. The American intervention in Iraq and the role of regional, but also external actors such as the US and the EU, India, or China were controversially discussed. Especially the policy of the Iranian government under President Ahmadinejad and the Iranian nuclear program were detailedly illuminated.

The Promises of Democracy : 25th Scientific Congress of the German Association for Political Science ¤ The „Promises“ of democracy are on everyone's lips: Democracy is a beacon of hope, for which people in authoritarian regimes take to the streets and risk their lives. At the same time, it is a reason for numerous disappointments and disillusionment with politics in existing democracies.In their contributions, the authors ask from a political science perspective how the „democracy“ as a political order form and as a political idea is ordered at the beginning of the 21st century and what conclusions can be drawn from this for future democracy policy.These current contributions are supplemented by a controversial review of German political science as a also biographically secured „democracy science“ in its founding phase.With contributions from:Frank Bandau, Hannah Bethke, Günter C. Behrmann, Dirk Berg-Schlosser, Jens Borchert, Hubertus Buchstein, Rainer Eisfeld, Henrik Enderlein, Micha Fiedlschuster, Oliver Flügel-Martinsen, Rainer Forst, Werner Friedrichs, Anna Geis, Michael Hein, Jakob Jünger, Wilhelm Knelangen, Regina Kreide, Winfried Kretschmann, Gerhard Lehmbruch, Roland Lhotta, Birte Meinschien, Martin Nonhoff, Martin Saar, Samuel Salzborn, Markus Tausendpfund, Winfried Thaa and Stefanie Walter

Mobilities and Immobilities: People - Ideas - Things - Cultures - Capital ¤ A key factor in understanding globally observed spatial transformations is the development and change of mobilities. This applies to large- and small-scale movements of people, but also of ideas, cultures, things, capital, goods, and information. And even in our hypermobile globalized world, mobility cannot be thought of without immobility. Mobility and immobility are in a close, tension-filled relationship that decisively shapes the social-spatial development and form of cities and regions. So, the most important movement machines, such as mobile phones, computers, airplanes, high-speed trains, etc., require highly complex, spatially fixed, and space-reaching technical infrastructures. New technologies enable virtual mobility at physical immobility. At the same time, virtual mobility has not replaced physical mobility; rather, physical mobility has also increased. These considerations were the occasion for the thematic orientation of the 1st Dortmund Conference on Spatial and Planning Research: Mobilities and Immobilities. This book documents a large part of the contributions to the conference, which was jointly organized by the Faculty of Spatial Planning at the Technical University of Dortmund and the Academy for Spatial Research and Regional Planning - Leibniz Forum for Spatial Sciences - in February 2012. The conference laid the foundation for a series of conferences that serve as a platform for interdisciplinary spatial and planning-related research.

European Influences on Spatial and Regional Development: An Example of Nature Conservation, Agenda 2000, and Regional Environment ¤ The implementation of the European Bird and Habitat Directives (FFH) into national law, as well as the new European agricultural policy introduced by Agenda 2000, significantly influence spatial development. The directives aim to preserve and restore particularly worthy natural habitats and their species. Large-scale designations of protected areas are required. In the spatial implementation, coordination and procedural questions are significant. With Agenda 2000, the goal is to reorient the existing direct payments for agricultural products in favor of environmental protection and structural measures. In this context, the objectives of the Structural Fund have been reduced from seven to three. Integrated regional development concepts with priority lists for the new funding policy are required. In this context, a comprehensive development of rural areas also plays a role. In view of far-reaching changes in the context of the globalization process, the question of knowledge exchange and effective use of knowledge is also increasingly being asked. An operational approach is presented using the example of business clusters, which highlights vertical and horizontal transaction patterns of knowledge. Equally important for regional development are innovative networks between innovation actors. The intraregional network relationships must also exhibit international relationships if they are to be competitive. The future of the regions depends more strongly than before on the recourse to their own forces.

Contributions to the Göttingen Environmental Historical Colloquium 2009 - 2010 ¤ This annual yearbook presents essays in environmental history based on lectures given at the Göttingen study group “Environmental History” by external authors. As previous yearbooks it is dedicated to the plurality of approaches in environmental history and serves as a valuable source for information about current research in that realm

O. M. Ungers : Cosmos of Architecture ; [published on the occasion of the exhibition "O. M. Ungers. Cosmos of Architecture", Neue Nationalgalerie, Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, October 27, 2006 to January 7, 2007] ¤ Oswald Mathias Ungers (* 1926) is both one of the most influential architects in Germany and one of the most formative architecture theorists of the 20th century. According to Ungers, a close connection to the visual arts is of fundamental importance for architecture: "Art and architecture have the same roots, are inscribed with the same codes and systems. To separate them means to destroy their value, to extinguish them." Ungers' museum buildings such as the Gallery of Contemporary Art in Hamburg or the Wallraf-Richartz Museum in Cologne, but also his own houses stand as real symbols for his radical commitment to architecture as pure art. - - The present volume illuminates different aspects of this theoretical approach based on Ungers' art collection, his collection of architecture models, his own houses, and his library for the first time and examines the inner connection of his architectural work to art themes

Interests, Values, Responsibility: German Foreign Policy between Nation-State, Europe, and the West: In Memory of Hans-Peter Schwarz ¤ Is German foreign policy since Adenauer's days interest-driven and strategically designed? Or does it follow a convenient moralism and let itself be driven by popular moods? What external policy responsibility comes to the Federal Republic in the face of the EU crisis, the tensions in the transatlantic relationship, and new security policy threats? What are the contours of a realistic and responsible power policy of the Federal Republic? In memory of Hans-Peter Schwarz, the biographer of the two chancellors Konrad Adenauer and Helmut Kohl, these questions are critically discussed in 14 pointed essays by renowned historians and political scientists.

Social Work Science Gender Research: Methodological Questions, Research Fields, and Empirical Results ¤ Social work science gender research provides insights into the ordering and regulatory power of gender and sexuality. With this publication, an explicit confrontation with the methodologies and research methods of social work science gender research takes place for the first time. In the context of different research fields of social work, the authors exemplarily show which research approaches are used and how gender relationships and sexuality can be reconstructed and analyzed as a research object. (Book cover)

Financing newly emerging private enterprises in transition economies ¤ The present book investigates the financing of new private enterprises in transition economies. At the center are small and medium-sized enterprises and their possibilities on the capital markets. Whether and to what extent the state should help these companies through loans and financing is discussed. In this, clear differences also become apparent between the individual states.

Land Use Competitions on Site - Land Use Management as Municipal and Regional Task : Documentation of Contributions to a Regional Seminar of the German Institute for Urban Studies and the Association of the Greater Region of Hanover on May 27 and 28, 1997 in Hanover ¤ Qualitatively and quantitatively efficient land use management, where not only the different land use claims are brought into balance, but also the land and soil are handled sparingly and carefully, with soil sealing being limited to the necessary extent, is a central component of sustainable urban and land development in metropolitan regions. Supported by the Association of the Greater Region of Hanover, which has been in an intensive coordination process with its members from the city of Hanover, the district of Hanover, and many individual municipalities for a long time, the German Institute for Urban Studies organized a seminar on the topic of land use management, which is documented in this publication. From the individual contributions and discussions, it became clear on the one hand how difficult regional land use management is between municipal planning sovereignty and regional overall responsibility. On the other hand, it also became apparent how central regional land use management is for sustainable urban development.

Conflict Transformation as a Path to Peace: Christian and Islamic Perspectives ¤ Islam and Christianity have frequently legitimized violence in their history, but also given strong peace ethical impulses. The approaches to this are illuminated in this volume from a Christian and Islamic perspective using new concepts of conflict transformation: How can religious resources contribute to constructively dealing with religious, but also social and political conflicts? Where are these resources to be found and how can they be applied? What role can the religious actors and actors, but also the spiritual sources and traditions of the religions as well as their spiritual and communicative practice forms play in conflict transformation? With contributions from Dirk Ansorge, Reinhold Bernhardt, Michael Haspel, Marco Hofheinz, Kerim Kudo, Christine Schliesser, Hansjörg Schmid, Konrad Schmid, Nimet Seker, Mathias Tanner, Mohamed Turki, Markus Weingardt.

Landes- und Regionalplanung in Baden-Württemberg : a mid-term balance on the occasion of the 100th meeting of the LAG Baden-Württemberg ; [joint event of the ARL and the Ministry of Economics of Baden-Württemberg on July 10, 2008 at the House of Economy Stuttgart] ¤ In the year 2008, the Landesarbeitsgemeinschaft Baden-Württemberg of the Academy for Regional Research and Regional Planning celebrates its 100th meeting. The present volume, published on the occasion of this jubilee, draws a mid-term balance on the development of regional and state planning in Baden-Württemberg and presents the work, development, and essential characteristics of the Landesarbeitsgemeinschaft Baden-Württemberg.

Surrogacy and Family: Impulses from Law, Theology, and Medicine ¤ The book examines the topic of surrogacy from a broad, interdisciplinary perspective. In Germany, surrogacy is prohibited, while in many other countries it is legal. Many people therefore fulfill their wish for a child through surrogacy abroad. The book takes this as an opportunity to grasp and analyze current findings and impulses from law, theology, sociology, child development psychology, medicine, genetics, and philosophy on this phenomenon. At the center is the question of how the well-being of the child, the interests of the surrogate mothers, and the needs of the prospective parents are reflected in the German legal order, social reality, and ecclesiastical institutions. Greeting of the President of the Friedrich-Schiller University Jena by Walter Rosenthal -- The theme of surrogacy in an interdisciplinary perspective - an introduction by Michael Wermke and Edward Schramm -- Part I - Family images as a starting point: Children want - Mothers lend. Historical considerations on the family and its feasibility by Gisela Mettele -- Farewell to the mother-centered small family? The pluralization of family forms and cultural models in the context of same-sex and/or assisted parenthood by Sylka Scholz -- Part II - The legal prohibition of surrogacy in Germany: The forbidden child - On the (criminal) legal evaluation of surrogacy in Germany by Edward Schramm --

Social Aspects of Land Recycling in Cities: Documentation of the 4th German-American Workshop "Social Aspects of Land Recycling" on June 17/18, 2004 in Leipzig ¤ Within the framework of a German-American research cooperation, procedures for dealing with vacant land in the context of land recycling (Brownfield Redevelopment) were discussed in six bilateral workshops. The book documents the 4th workshop, which dealt with the social aspects of land recycling in cities. In the revitalization of vacant land, various social aspects are usually affected. Inner-city vacant land offers a large potential for this purpose, as it is usually well-developed and centrally located. Vacant land is at the same time a focal point for social, ecological, and employment-oriented initiatives in urban renewal areas. The social acceptability of land recycling depends on how far a connection of urban planning and engineering aspects with participatory approaches to a comprehensive urban renewal of the existing stock and urban structures can be achieved. It is about effectively bundling the private economic interest in projects of vacant land revitalization and the public interest in long-term effective social effects in the relevant city districts. Land recycling is therefore no longer an isolated specialist task, but a crucial component of sustainable urban development and must meet the different requirements of spaces, users, uses, and functions.
Writing and Erasing : On a Moment of Productive Negativity ¤ Blurb: Literature begins with erasure, as the wordplay on

Genre and Race: Media Interdependencies of Aesthetics and Politics ¤ Introduction -- (Anti-)Racialized Genre Genealogies -- Politics of Representation -- Genre Adaptations and Passages -- Post- and Decolonial Racism Critique. The category of Race is currently gaining more political visibility, mainly due to the Black-Lives-Matter movement, migration and flight, not least also due to theoretical approaches such as Postcolonial Studies, Critical Race Theory, Intersectionality or Decolonizing Gender Studies. Against this background, it is necessary to critically question media-specific strategies in their diversity and historical development, which have contributed to racist thinking and racist politics and continue to do so. The category of Genre as an ambivalent and complex perception and meaning-creation structure at the interface of production, reception, and aesthetics offers itself particularly to approach media-technological traditions and means that make Race politically effective, serve various ideologies, produce affects, and at the same time also produce resistances or new perspectives and forms of articulation. The book brings together different theoretical and analytical approaches that provide insights into the history of the interdependence of Genre and Race through selected objects, as well as dealing with its international and nationally specific accentuation, where fundamental questions about the relationship between visuality and Race and the epistemological power of the gaze are always in focus. With contributions from Lisa Andergassen, Thomas Bedorf, Julia Bee, Kyung-Ho Cha, Julia Dittmann, Irina Gradinari, Irmtraud Hnilica, Karina Kirsten, Michaela Ott, Johannes Pause, Nele Rein, Ivo Ritzer, Drehli Robnik, Peter Scheinpflug and Michaela Wünsch. The editors Jun.-Dr. Irina Gradinari is Junior Professor for literary and media-scientific gender research at the Institute for New German Literature and Media Studies at the University of Hagen. Univ.-Dr. Ivo Ritzer teaches General and Comparative Media Studies at the University of Bayreuth.

Times designated : early modern epochal concepts: European history and global present ¤ Cliff notes: Is the Early Modern period a product of the Cold War? How was the concept of Modernity and Antiquity perceived during the time of Louis XIV? Are there global Early Modern periods? - Epoch formation is generally considered one of the central tasks of any disciplinary historiography. Although the term epoché in its proper sense means the threshold between times, the transition, the temporal in-between, epochs appear in current usage as largely epistemically determined, seemingly homogeneous entities in the division of a physically continuous time flow. In this, they function, whether their designations are historically, teleologically, or even only numerically shaped, primarily as practical labels, convenient reference schemes, or even as mere umbrella terms for designating a unity that is often immediately revoked by reference to the simultaneity of the non-simultaneous, yet consistently asserted, if not granted. The consolidation of the Wolfenbüttel working groups on Renaissance and Baroque research into the newly established Early Modern Research Group documents the repeated reflection on the difficult business of designating times.

Alles ist nach seiner Art ¤ There are some successful examples of approaching Wagner's monumental 'Ring' tetralogy analytically. In the present book, the result of a Bayreuth scientific symposium, the authors - all acknowledged experts - deal with the main characters of the work, after the editor has given an overview of the most important stations of the Ring interpretation since 1876. The mythological and literary sources of the characters are followed, their dramatic and musical formation is characterized. Of course, their respective significance within the tetralogy is illuminated. It is astonishing to see that the modernity of the work is not only shown in current productions, but also when contemporary socioscientific and psychological questions are posed. Access to the individual characters is of particular value for the music theater enthusiast, who should, however, be quite familiar with the work. Essential for music libraries. (3) (Klaus Hohlfeld)

In Sprachwelten über-setzen : Contributions to Economic Communication, Cultural and Language Mediation in DaF and DaZ$d42. Annual Conference of the Association of German as a Foreign and Second Language in Munich 2015 ¤ The present volume comprises the most important contributions of the 42nd Annual Conference of German as a Foreign Language, which took place under the motto DaFür München from 05.03. - 07.03.2015 at the SDI Munich / University of Applied Languages. The thematic spectrum shows a variety of current aspects of teaching and learning German as a first or second foreign language. An important focus is the theme of translation / language mediation, which – in a broad sense – is also dedicated to the title of the volume. Numerous research concepts and practice-oriented approaches that provide a broad scope for multilingualism and current heterogeneity in DaF and DaZ determine the following four thematic focal points and a practice forum from different perspectives: 1. Language mediation / interpreting and translating; 2. Multilingualism in the context of international economic and business communication; 3. Heterogeneity as a challenge and resource in DaF and DaZ; 4. Life worlds in literature and land studies.

Kings, Princes, and Empire in the 15th Century : [ ... Proceedings of the Symposium ... from July 14 - 16, 2005 at the University of Mannheim] ¤ The volume brings together the contributions of a conference, with which the late medieval researcher Karl-Friedrich Krieger was honored. It is divided into four thematic blocks: King, Court and Council under Frederick III and Maximilian I - Kingship, Roman Curia and Spiritual Princes in the 15th century - Kingship and Feudalism in the Late Middle Ages - King and Princes on the Upper Rhine. The contributions are prosopographically, constitutional and culturally as well as politically oriented and fill research desiderata in general and in individual aspects. The authors: K. Andermann, F. Fuchs, I. Havlácek, P.-J. Heinig, E. Isenmann, C. Märtl, D. Mertens, J.-M. Moeglin, J. Petersohn, D. Rando, C. Reinle, R. Scharf, J. Schwarz, E. Tremp, H. Vogelmann, T. Zotz

Municipal Financial Crisis: Consequences and Solution Approaches ¤ Municipal financial crisis has been accompanying municipalities for a long time - it is not a child of the current financial crisis. The problems lie deeper: in the growing burden of tasks, the personnel-intensive municipal services, the higher demands of citizens on their municipalities and the lagging behind revenues. Although municipalities have a certain tax autonomy (fees, contributions, municipal taxes) - their scope of action is limited by the increasingly intense municipal location competition. In addition to general reform approaches on the state level, municipalities must also make a greater effort to find their own solution approaches to improve their situation. They range from cost-cutting measures to strengthening civic participation to new models that involve citizens in municipal financial decision-making and contribute to relieving municipal budgets through <<sustainable business practices>>. The contributions brought together in this volume are primarily based on a lecture series at the University of Hanover in 2011.

Responsibility in the Risk Society : Ethical Challenge in a Changing World : [Third Interdisciplinary Symposium of the Philosophical Forum of the University of Kaiserslautern on May 11 and 12, 1993] ¤ The modern path of the Western world is in a forced way under the leadership of science and technology. This Western path has meanwhile taken on a global character and challenges us all to reflection on its origin, its effects and side effects as well as its goals.

Service Colloquium on November 10, 2005 at the Technical University of Kaiserslautern ¤ For the fourth time, a service colloquium took place on November 10, 2005 at the TU Kaiserslautern, in which doctoral and postdoctoral students from various departments presented their work for discussion. Once again, it became clear that this is a wide field in terms of content and methodology. The present working paper documents the presentations held. In the service literature, strategic questions of competition have been dealt with relatively rarely so far. Based on the consideration that strategic options for competition are generally transferable to service enterprises, Kai-Michael Dresch's contribution to the question of how modularization can provide approaches for the realization of hybrid competition strategies is pursued. It shows that modularization can be restricted on the one hand due to the interactivity of services, but on the other hand also opens up additional design possibilities. Ubiquitous Computing describes the increasing penetration of everyday life with information technology. Intelligent products and support services emerge, which will have effects on the future collection and processing of information as well as the purchase and use of services. Henrik Fälsch's contribution summarizes the transformation processes of classical services on different levels of service and propagates an increasing importance of additional services along the customer process. Patrick Gerling and Andreas Jonen's contribution is based on the cognitively oriented controlling approach, which has so far dealt mainly with functional and institutional questions. In order to be able to span an instrumental perspective, the cognitive limitations are worked out, which occur in connection with the use of controlling information. These are seen as the starting point for a cognitively oriented design of controlling instruments. In particular, the management of services often leads to high knowledge deficits of the affected managers and thus represents a typical example of the advantage of a cognitively oriented design of instruments. Universities have been given more decision-making power over budget use and institutional orientation in recent times. This can be seen as a need for instruments to support decision-making, which cannot always be covered by traditional instruments due to the special situation of universities. The Balanced University Decision Card presented by Lisa Hubig and Andreas Jonen is intended to support decision-makers in presenting decision situations by structuring the framework and the alternative actions. This is done methodically by anchoring in the widely used business instrument of the Balanced Scorecard. With the help of thinking in perspectives and the use of cause-and-effect chains to illustrate the consequences of choosing an alternative action, the situation is modeled. The potential of the instrument is presented in a case study.

The Body in Early Modern Times : Practices, Rituals, Performance ¤ Cliff Notes: Sociation in Early Modern Times proceeded largely through the arrangement and semiotic loading of human bodies. At the center of the last conference of the Wolfenbüttel Baroque Working Group were body practices across the entire spectrum from instrumental body techniques to sign-performative rituals and stagings. Thus, questions were turned to the historicity of body practices, to the field of tension between normativity and everyday action, to the interplay between the only apparent static of rituals and social dynamics, to the contrast between stabilization and legitimation of social order, as well as the possibilities of irony and subversion. The contributions of the volume emerging from the conference document an interdisciplinary view of relevant aspects of the body in the Baroque and can be assigned to four content sections: body practices in the fields of religion and magic, body practices in the fields of law and politics, body practices in narratives and visualizations, and body practices in the areas of staged performance and stage. The book 'The Body of Early Modern Times' is the last volume of the series Wolfenbüttel Works on Baroque Research.

Wolf Biermann : a Lyricist and Songwriter in Germany ¤ Poems, songs, friends and foes - Wolf Biermann has had a lot of everything." Deike Diening, Der Tagesspiegel Wolf Biermann's expulsion from the GDR after the Cologne concert in 1976 meant not only a turning point in his biography, but also in the history of the GDR. Personal and political history intersect in the life and work of the songwriter again and again. This involves central reference points in German cultural history: between East and West, German and Jewish, communism and democracy, politics and art. All of these are complex pairings that challenge historical judgment. The contributions of the book reflect Wolf Biermann's development in the political contexts of the time and also dedicate themselves to the lyricist and musician. With contributions from Roland Berbig, Holger Böning, Gerd Dietrich, Marcus Heumann, Ilko-Sascha Kowalczuk, Monika Linder, Sabine Sanio, Hendrikje Schauer, Manuel Soubeyrand, Hannes Stein, Gabriele Stötzer, Stefan Wolle, with songs and poems by Wolf Biermann, as well as numerous, partly previously unpublished photographs Appears at the large Wolf-Biermann-exhibition at the German Historical Museum, Berlin: July 7, 2023 - January 14, 2024

Visionaries and Everyday Heroes: Engineers - Building - Future ¤ From inventors, entrepreneurs, problem solvers, and visionaries. Deep and high-rise building engineers: the emergence of the professions / Bill Addis -- Shell and space. On the development of the Zeiss-Dywidag shell construction method / Cengiz Dicleli -- Mobility and transport. Fixed tracks in rail transport / Stephan Freudenstein The fascinating and diverse range of performance of 'engineers in the construction industry' is rarely perceived as such in the public. In this context, the construction industry is not only one of the key industries in economic, but also in social and societal terms: Without buildings and infrastructure, our modern life is simply unimaginable. The goal of the publication is therefore to present the profession of engineer - representative of the entire industry - as it is: fascinating, creative, comprehensive, and innovative. Engineer personalities and their innovations are presented in the background of the respective social, economic, and political influences - coming from history with a focus on current projects

Knowledge Production, Knowledge Mobilization, and Knowledge Transfer: Opportunities and Limits of the Development of Science and Practice ¤ What is the relationship between science and practice? How does research knowledge get into practice? In recent years, there have been increasing calls to examine the relationship between science and practice more closely in order to facilitate a

Maintenance and Restoration of Roads and Water Supply Systems from the Roman Republic to Late Antiquity ¤ Roads, bridges, aqueducts and canals are amongst the physical infrastructures that allowed Roman dominance over the Empire, while meeting economic, social and strategic needs. Due to their structural role in the management and control of a territory, they must be examined in view of the “longue durée”, which necessarily raises the issue of their regular maintenance and occasional restoration. By studying the interactions between different political and administrative authorities, but also the involvement of private individuals, be they users or riverside occupants, the papers gathered in this volume highlight the rehabilitation procedures of road and hydraulic facilities, but also the prevention strategies against potentially irreversible damages. To understand the overall legal framework, along with the technical constraints and socio-political modalities of these interventions, a multidisciplinary approach was adopted to foster the dialogue between history, archaeology and Roman law.

Politics as linguistically bound knowledge : political language in lifelong learning and political action ¤ The engagement with the various relationships between language and politics is as old as the realization that language is the most important medium for political thinking and acting. However, the relationships between language and politics only became a subject of scientific research in the 20th century, for example in Germany in the course of the confrontation with the language of or in National Socialism. Little has been researched so far on how, to what extent, and with what content the various relationships between language and politics find their way into the language life of the individual, what role they play, and whether and how they undergo changes. The contributions summarize the research that has been conducted so far and explore what further research can be aligned with

Strong Municipalities – Effective Administration: Advances and Pitfalls of International Public Administration and Local Government Research ¤ This collective volume addresses the central lines of development of the change of administration and local politics over the last few decades in the German as well as in the international context. On the occasion of the 80th birthday of Hellmut Wollmann, leading national and international researchers provide a comprehensive overview of central research fields and results of public administration and local government research, which also stand at the center of his work: administrative reform and policy analysis, local politics research and comparative local government as well as policy evaluation. The contributions reflect the „State of the Art“ as well as essential lines of development of the research in the fields of political and administrative science of the last few decades. Together with the biographically shaped „Spurensuchen“, valuable insights into the disciplinary history of German politics and administration research are given. Content · Public administration and administration research · Local politics and administration · Policy research and evaluation · Spurensuchen Target groups · Political scientists · Public administration researchers · Institutionally interested lawyers · Local government researchers · Advanced students of politics and administration science · Interested practitioners and decision-makers The editors Prof. Dr. Sabine Kuhlmann is the chair of the chair of politics, administration and organization at the University of Potsdam. Dr. Oliver Schwab is project leader and partner at the IfS Institute for Urban Research and Structural Policy in Berlin Public administration and administration research -- Local politics and administration -- Policy research and evaluation -- Spurensuchen

The Future of Railways : between Citizen-Centricity and Stock Exchange Listing ; Documentation of a Conference of the Evangelical Academy Baden with the AK Verkehr und Umwelt - Umkehr e.V. and the Expert Group "Citizens' Railway instead of Stock Exchange Railway"/ Heiner Monheim ... (Ed.). Contributions by Karl D. Bodack ... ¤ Dokumentation einer Tagung der Evangelischen Akademie Baden mit dem AK Verkehr und Umwelt - Umkehr e. V. und der Expertengruppe "Bürgerbahn statt Börsenbahn"

Financial Policy and Labor Markets ¤ The Financial Science Committee of the Verein für Socialpolitik discussed the financial policy approaches to alleviate labor market problems in its working conference 2001. The conference volume contains the three keynote speeches by Axel Börsch-Supan (University of Mannheim), Christian Keuschnigg (University of St. Gallen) and Bernd Raffelhüschen (University of Freiburg). -- Axel Börsch-Supan points out that population aging, in addition to the much-discussed financial gap in the statutory pension insurance, requires action in two further policy areas. Since increasing capital intensity will not be sufficient to boost productivity to the extent that the negative effects of aging on GDP can be compensated, human capital accumulation through education and training must be increased. In addition, the changed age structure will affect the composition of aggregate demand and require a significantly higher sectoral factor mobility to avoid sectoral employment crises. -- Christian Keuschnigg explains in an intertemporal equilibrium model the occurrence of credit rationing and unemployment as a result of search frictions on capital and labor markets. Financial policy measures to promote business start-ups are effective instruments to combat unemployment. -- Bernd Raffelhüschen points out that the social policy reform agenda for pension and health insurance must be expanded, as the basic security through social assistance, housing benefit, unemployment benefit and care allowance is also in need of reform. He develops a blueprint for a basic security reform that is based on two core ideas: subsidiary help to self-help and subsidization of employment instead of idleness. Related reform concepts in international comparison and existing linkages in the German social law system make Raffelhüschen optimistic that his reform proposal is not only economically attractive, but also legally implementable and politically feasible.

Designing Learning and Educational Processes : Young Forum Media and Higher Education Development (JFMH13) ¤ Im Fokus vieler Nachwuchsinitiativen steht, das Hineinwachsen in Forschung und Entwicklung der Bildungseinrichtungen zu erleichtern. Zu diesen Initiativen gehört auch das „Junge Forum Medien und Hochschulentwicklung“, das Nachwuchsforschenden sowie -praktikerinnen und -praktikern aus den vier beteiligten Fachgesellschaften (dghd, GMW, GI/FG E-Learning sowie DGfE/Sektion Medienpädagogik) eine Plattform für Diskurs und Austausch zwischen Wissenschaft und Praxis bietet. The documented conference contributions from 2013 are as diverse as formal or informal learning and educational processes with and without media can be. It is discussed, for example, what role design processes take in the context of higher education and media didactics research and how digital technologies practically support learning and educational processes. Some contributions to personnel development and promotion of young researchers in science and higher education frame the #JFMH13 volume.

Education Planning for the Nineties: Documentation of the 12th DGBV Annual Conference from October 24 to 26, 1991 in Celle ¤ The conference proceedings contain, inter alia, the following contributions: FUTURE CALCULABILITY: Planned and unplanned developments in the field of education 1970-1990 (Führ, Christoph. - Raschert, Jürgen). - LEARNING FROM EXPERIENCE (Weiß, Manfred: Prognostics in the field of education?. - Wild, Peter: Financial planning as education planning?. - Rolff, Hans-Günter: Acceptance as a planning factor?. - Klauder, Wolfgang: Employment systems as a framework for orientation?). - PERSPECTIVES OF THE NEW COUNTRIES: Education planning under difficult conditions (e.g. Döbert, Hans: Chances for a reform of the school?.- Benz, Winfried: Universities between decline and development). - THE 1990s: New goals and framework conditions for education planning (Schaumann, Fritz: Framework conditions, tasks and goals of education planning in the 1990s. - Schlegel, Jürgen: Politics and planning - Theses on a difficult relationship. - Rumpf, Horst: Learning culture and its conditions) - Appendix - UNESCO: Approaches to strategic education planning. (PHF/übern.)

Future Forum on Spatial Planning: Joint Congress 2001 by ARL and BBR ¤ Important conditions for the development of space have been profoundly changed in the transition from the industrial society to the service and knowledge society. This includes the globalization of economic processes, the progressive European integration, the expansion of information and communication technologies, as well as decentralization and public-private cooperation-oriented structural changes in the state and society. The new trends in development lead to changed requirements for spatial planning and policy. A re-adjustment of spatial planning and spatial development policy is urgently required. To this end, the Future Forum on Spatial Planning, which was held by the Academy for Spatial Research and Land Planning (ARL) and the Federal Office for Building and Urban Development (BBR) in Bonn in late 2001, should make an important contribution. The book contains the results of the Future Forum. In addition to a location determination, proposals for securing the effectiveness of spatial planning in the face of future challenges are presented.

The America of Authors : from Kafka to 09/11 ¤ Since German authors write about America, more precisely: the USA, this happens in an ambivalence of fascination and rejection. But only in the 20th, the >American< century, do the contradictory feelings unfold in a previously unknown breadth. At the same time, however, they are more conscious than before for almost everyone who travels to America - by ship, by air, or even just in their heads. That America is a projection of the European spirit, Paul Valéry has held for his European colleagues. And if Peter Bichsel's >America does not exist< seems like a federal exaggeration to many, so most people could understand Carl Zuckmayer's laconism: >America is different!< But different from what? Different from Europe? Different from what we think? Different from how it sees itself? This book deals with these questions and aspects through various examples from 20th-century German-language literature and journalism, from Karl Rossmann's Kafkaesque arrival in America to the literary processing of September 11, 2001

Current GmbH Law: Conference Proceedings ¤ The conference proceedings document the lectures held at the 7th symposium of the Institute for Notarial Law on current GmbH law. There is also a need for political action in many areas of GmbH law even after the MoMiG reform. The goal is to show the reader current problem areas and present political solutions. First, an overview is given of the development of the GmbH in Germany and Europe. This is followed by contributions on the shareholder list and the acquisition of shares in good faith, the reduction of capital, as well as the area of vinking. Further, open questions and problems in the so-called Hin- and Herzahlen are illuminated. At the end, a contribution on capital increase in crisis and insolvency of the company is presented. It is to be hoped that the results of the conference will be well received by the BGH and the legislature. With contributions by: Prof. Dr. Holger Altmeppen; Prof. Dr. Barbara Grunewald; Notary a.D. Sebastian Herrler; Dr. Jan Lieder, LL.M. (Harvard); Prof. Dr. Jochem Reichert; Dr. Jessica Schmidt, LL.M. (Nottingham)

Procurement of Transport Services in Public Transport: 2nd Jena Conference on Public Transport Law ¤ Numerous transport services in public transport must be ordered by the task carriers to ensure their existence and thus a sufficient transport offer. The conference proceedings deal with the questions associated with this and combine scientific and practical perspectives.

Civil Security : Societal Dimensions of Contemporary Security Policies ¤ Terrorism, crime or catastrophes - threats, risks and hazards of diverse origin are increasingly thought of 'on the same line'. This rationality, branded under the slogan 'Civil Security', has advanced to a core concept of security policy strategy. The book takes up questions about the preconditions, meanings and consequences of this security strategy. From different disciplinary perspectives, fundamental aspects of the constitution and change in security awareness, the transformation of the security architecture, as well as the ambivalences of the technologization of security are presented and critically discussed.

Juvenile Multiple and "High-Intensity Offenders" : Developments, Strategies, Concepts ¤ Juvenile multiple and "high-intensity offenders" are a topic that repeatedly provokes public discussions. The contributions of this volume provide scientific findings, give an insight into concepts of youth welfare and police, and blend discourses on media, public, and social policy.

Age-Friendly Work : the Demographic Shift in Workforces ¤ The demographic shift is considered one of the greatest challenges of the near future. The consequences of an aging society on work processes are increasingly coming into focus. The politically pursued increase in the employment rate of older people requires the preservation of the working and employability of this group. However, studies show that there are significant deficits on the part of the companies: Only just under a fifth offer measures of occupational health promotion. Older people, especially those who are less qualified, are rarely involved in occupational further education. Also, reservations about the hiring of older employees persist.

Vollzug für das 21. Jahrhundert : Symposium anlässlich des 300-jährigen Bestehens der Justizvollzugsanstalt Waldheim ¤ Published on the occasion of the 300th anniversary of Waldheim Prison, this book contains contributions from different authors on topics related to correctional facilities. The subjects discussed range from historical aspects and critical analysis of the efficacy of procedures and practices to whether the deprivation of freedom is still a reasonable sanction. This book will fascinate its readers because it presents the perspectives of different professions at correctional facilities and provides an overview of the debates stemming from different approaches. It becomes apparent that seemingly simple answers are not adequate solutions to this complex matter.

Intelligent Agents and the Law ¤ The deployment of robots in various areas of life brings a fundamental concern of law to the forefront: the possible clear assignment of responsibility. As a technological innovation, the digitalization of certain processes raises the question of the appropriateness of our liability concepts. If intelligent agents, whether as autonomous cars, prostheses, or irrigation systems, cause damage because they do not correctly take in data, misinterpret, or react inappropriately in autonomous mode, the question arises: Do the people behind the machine bear responsibility? The question of responsibility for intelligent agents is neither new nor limited to legal science. It was already discussed in Roman law and is now a concern of technology assessment. The present volume spans the arc from antiquity to modernity and from basic questions to application in the insurance industry, intelligent traffic, or smart homes.

The Performance of Philology in the Interpretation of Culture(s) ¤ It is certainly an exciting scientific task to define what culture is, and to think about how one can make this culture a scientific subject. Furthermore, it is a challenge to develop an approach or methodology for how one can research culture. In this undertaking, we must always have in mind that we are talking about two different concepts of culture: once of the culture that represents something inherently human, and once of a culture that is typical for a (language-)community and can be considered a characteristic feature of this community.

Administration between Design, Transparency, and Control: Contributions to the Symposium on the Occasion of Ulrich Ramsauer's 70th Birthday ¤ Der vorliegende Band versammelt Beiträge vom Symposium zum 70. Geburtstag von Ulrich Ramsauer, mit dem seine mehr als 40 Jahre währende Tätigkeit auf den Gebieten des öffentlichen Rechts, insbesondere des Umwelt- und Planungsrechts, des Verwaltungsverfahrensrechts und der Verwaltungslehre gewürdigt wurde. In den Beiträgen werden zentrale Probleme der aktuellen verwaltungsrechtlichen Diskussion behandelt: Verfahrensbeschleunigung (Peter Wysk), Öffentlichkeitsbeteiligung (Hans-Joachim Koch) und Europäisierung (Jörg Berkemann). Einleitend gibt Ivo Appel eine gestraffte Einführung in das Konzept der Verwaltungsrechtswissenschaft als Steuerungswissenschaft. Die übergeordnete thematische Verbindung stellt der Beitrag von Jochen Wagner aus philosophischer Perspektive unter dem Titel „Integration durch Freundschaft“ her; er betrachtet damit zugleich die Integration als eine der wichtigsten Staatsaufgaben unserer Zeit. The present volume combines contributions to the symposium on the occasion of Ulrich Ramsauer’s 70th birthday, acknowledging his activity in the fields of public law, especially environmental law and planning regulations, administrative procedural law and public administration, which has lasted more than 40 years. The contributions deal with key issues in the current discussion in administrative law: accelerated proceedings (Peter Wysk), public participation (Hans-Joachim Koch) and Europeanisation (Jörg Berkemann). In his introduction, Ivo Appel presents a short introduction to the concept of administrative legal science as a managing science. The contribution by Jochen Wagner offers an overarching thematic connection from a philosophical perspective, titled “Integration through friendship”. At the same time, he considers integration as one of the essential responsibilities of the state today.

Human - Animal - Machine: Linguistic Practices at and Beyond the Outer Boundary of the Human ¤ How do people speak to non-human entities, about them? How do we verbalize the relationships and differences between humans, animals, and machines? How is the boundary between the human and the non-human used to communicate social elevation and devaluation? The volume brings together linguistic and adjacent disciplines to shed light on linguistic practices at and beyond the outer boundary of the human

Literature and Illness in the Fin-de-Siècle (1890 - 1914) : Thomas Mann in the European Context ; the Davos Literature Days 2000 ¤ Zur Eröffnung / Christian Virchow -- Thomas Mann - Physicians of the Family and Medicine in Munich - Traces in Life and Work (1894-1925) / Jochen Eigler -- The Sister Figures of the Crab in the Early Work of Thomas Mann under Special Consideration of Adriatica von Mylendonk / Thomas Sprecher -- Analysis as Art. Thomas Mann and Sigmund Freud in the Context of the Turn of the Century / Renate Böschenstein -- Psychiatric Culture Criticism around 1900 and Outlines of its Reception in the Early Work of Thomas Mann / Volker Roelcke -- Illnesses of the Turn of the Century in the Early Work of Thomas Mann / Helmut Koopmann -- Illness and Genius. Approaches to Early Forms of a Mannian Thought Figure / Thomas Rütten -- The Sanatorium as a Way of Life. On Relevant Experiences of Thomas Mann / Christian Virchow -- The Sanatorium as a Purgatory / Peter Pütz -- Neurosis and Psychosis in Medicine around 1900 / Dietrich von Engelhardt -- Thomas Mann. Awarded by Illness / Inge Jens -- As a Posthumous Tribute an Interview / Helmut Koopmann

Domestic utopias : Catalog for the exhibition  ; NGBK Berlin, 15.6. - 28.7.2013 ; [on the occasion of the exhibition Domestic Utopias, New Society for Visual Arts, 14.6.2013 - 28.7.2013] ¤ „The private is political“ was a slogan of the second women's movement in the 1970s, which campaigned worldwide for women's equality in politics and society. There was already a first step in this direction during the French Revolution – but it was not successful at the time. Now the slogan becomes the motto for the exhibition Domestic Utopias of the New Society for Visual Arts (NGBK) in Berlin. „Private“ here means forms of domesticity. The exhibition starts from various housing concepts, some of which were realized and some of which had to be abandoned. Artists deal with architectural designs for these concepts, for example Moira Zoitl with the so-called Frankfurt kitchen of architect Margarete Schütte-Lihotzky. In her work Kitchen Torso — from the reduction of steps, she interprets the pioneer of the built-in kitchen, which was intended to simplify work processes and make kitchens more compact. Space shortage and the resulting isolation of the housewife were major criticisms of the Frankfurt kitchen concept. From Annette Wehrmann, UFO models can be seen in Berlin, including the Reading UFO of 1999. She wanted to create a „moment of disconnection, of withdrawal into oneself“ with these UFOs, as the artist expressed herself at the time. In the Reading UFO, for example, one can engage with partly feminist science fiction literature from the 1970s. Far from the real world, the UFOs should be non-places that leave room for the question of „what if?"

Image and Script on "Magical" Artifacts ¤ There exist numerous treatises on powerful, commonly referred to as "magical" texts, for example on shells, gems, and amulets of different cultures. However, the illustration of the aforementioned artifacts often plays only a subordinate role in the analysis.
