In this context, phenomena of cultural transfer can be traced in both the pictorial representations and the texts themselves. Furthermore, the question arises as to how the relationship between image and text is to be evaluated: Do they stand in an intrinsic relationship and jointly determine the effect of the artifact? Or do they rather offer two "readings" of a single fact? The present volume deals with these and other questions exemplarily on artifacts and handbooks, cross-religiously and cross-culturally, from Late Antiquity to the early modern period and from the entire Mediterranean region. This includes not only gems, papyrus, and Arabic paper amulets, but also manuals with instructions for "magical" actions. With various interpretation and solution approaches, the contributions attempt to approach the question of the tension between magical text and image and to consider this from a trans-cultural perspective.

The Border Region as a Site of Memory : On the Change to a Post-National Culture of Remembrance in Europe ¤ History museums and memorial sites have long conveyed primarily national historical images. In a united Europe, however, the idea of a denationalized collective remembrance is growing. This discrepancy is particularly evident in border regions, where former states with their opposing interpretations of the past competed. By way of example, German, Italian, and Slovenian researchers in this book design a comprehensive panorama of a new democratic culture of remembrance. They show the far-reaching consequences for public remembrance and museum and history education in an international and interdisciplinary perspective.

Socialism Debates ; 1: Socialism in the 21st Century? ¤ The growing doubt as to whether a democratic-capitalist system can withstand the climate change and the upcoming transformations in the labor market, brings socialism new acceptance. A good reason to hold debates about how it could look like in the 21st century. The "New Zurich Newspaper", not necessarily suspected of progressive orientation, fears a "New Desire for Socialism". For a new socialist option speaks, that the historically unique economic-ecological crisis has set a societal transformation in motion, which must be used by left forces. A socialism of the 21st century, which reflects its own history and its diverse failures, stands therefore not only for the search for a emergency brake that must stop the climate change and the new wars. But realistic ways out of the epochal economic-ecological crises must be developed. The authors discuss in this volume the following questions: Does socialism in the 21st century have a future? Does it offer solutions for the pressing present problems? Which social forces could carry new socialist projects? Are there approaches for successful socialist politics?

Current Status and Perspectives of Cooperation with Universities and Scientific Institutions in Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania: Coordination Meeting in the Rectors' Conference of Universities on February 28, 1994 ¤ Gliederung: Agenda - p. 7; Conversation protocol (recorded by Schreiterer, Ulrich) - p. 8; Conversation participants p. 16-18; Cooperation relationships of German universities with universities and scientific institutions in the Baltic states (compiled by Muehle, Eduard and Smolarczyk, Rudolf) - p. 19-59; Practical hints (compiled by Kaschlun, Gunhild) - p. 60-80. (PHF/Ma.)

Health - Work - Prevention: Proceedings of the 3rd Congress for Occupational Health Management ¤ Through work-related illnesses in the context of psychological and physical stress, the most common cause of illness worldwide is caused by work. Against this backdrop, the SRH Fernhochschule – The Mobile University hosted the international BGM Congress for the third time on the topic of

Corruption in Sports: Conferences and Colloquia ¤ Corruption in sports has various manifestations and raises complex legal questions. The texts deal with, among other things, bribery at major events, sports betting fraud, sports sponsorship, and doping. Researchers, practitioners, athletes, and federation representatives present their views on the topics of corruption and compliance. With contributions fromChristin Armenat, Ioanna Ginou, Prof. Dr. PD Elisa Hoven, RiOLG Prof. Dr. Matthias Jahn, Silke Kassner, RiOLG Dr. Rainer Koch, Prof. Dr. Dr. h.c. Michael Kubiciel, Prof. Dr. Reinhard Merkel, Prof. Dr. Carsten Momsen, VRiLG Prof. Dr. Jan F. Orth, LL.M., Prof. Dr. Dr. h.c. Mark Pieth, Prof. Dr. Thomas Rönnau, RA Dr. Markus Rübenstahl, Mag. iur., RA Prof. Dr. Michael Tsambikakis, FAStrafR u FAMedR

Psychoanalysis and University: On the Connection of Academic Teaching and Analytic Practice ¤ The relationship between psychoanalysis and university has always been very tense, as well as the training of clinical psychoanalysts in an academic framework. Psychoanalysis has indeed conquered a number of positions at universities, but increasingly difficulty in defending them permanently. The authors of the present volume show that there are still various and international attempts to institutionalize psychoanalysis at the university and to give (becoming) psychoanalysts the opportunity to combine academic with psychoanalytic qualifications. Through their historically founded approaches, they enable a differentiated understanding of both the principal and historically conditioned problems that arise when combining academic research and psychoanalytic theory and practice, and show new solution approaches. In addition, the original text of Freud's Memorandum 'Should psychoanalysis be taught at the university?' is included in the book, which was only available for a long time in a back-translation from Hungarian and English. With contributions from Gertraud Diem-Wille, Stephan Doering, Patrizia Giampieri-Deutsch, Fritz Lackinger, Marianne Leuzinger-Bohleber, August Ruhs, Michael Schröter, Mark Solms and Martin Teising

The Relations between the European Union and China ¤ The European Union and China are the two largest trading powers in the world. The book examines the relationship between the EU and China on the one hand and the development of China on the other, inter alia, with regard to the so-called Silk Road Initiative, the transformation of the Chinese growth model or the human rights issue.

Garden futures : designing with nature ¤ Gardens have always been places of relaxation, enjoyment, and production. As expressions of identities, dreams, and visions, they have deep cultural roots and great symbolic significance. If the garden has been increasingly in the focus of social interest in recent years, then not only as a romantic refuge, but also as a testing ground for ideas of the future. This book examines the garden as a place where we shape our relationship with nature. .. The garden also as a testing ground for concepts of social justice and a more sustainable future.

Milieu – Revisited : Strategies of Qualitative Milieu Analysis ¤ The book provides a systematic approach to research strategies and methods that can be used to conduct qualitative milieu analyses. In addition to the conceptual contributions, the exemplary studies provide an overview of the current practice of qualitative research on milieus. The content of this book is based on questions that first emerged in the debate on the concept of milieu in connection with inequality and social structure research in the 1980s: How can inequalities between, for example, ethnic groups and genders be defined and treated in the most meaningful way? Should they be referred to as horizontal in contrast to vertical inequalities and what significance do these designations have again? Must "new" inequality-relevant manifestations announce or announce the spatial metaphor? Should they be replaced by alternative, also spatial metaphors such as from center and periphery? Can they be analyzed as a superficial phenomenon of class antagonism or are they to be considered as a secondary phenomenon of new social divisions? With contributions from: Steffen Amling, Ralf Bohnsack, Julia Franz, Nora Friederike Hoffmann, Andrea Lange-Vester, Stella Müller, Bernd Rebstein, Joachim Renn, Lisa-Marian Schmidt, Christel Teiwes-Kügler, Dariuš Zifonun and Jens Zimmermann. The editors Stella Müller is a sociologist and is promoting at the research focus Macro sociology and Transnational Processes at the University of Duisburg-Essen. At the Georg-August-University of Göttingen, she is working as a scientific referent at the Equal Opportunities Office. Jens Zimmermann is a political scientist and is working as a scientific assistant at the Chair of International Politics and Theories of Global Orders at the Goethe University Frankfurt am Main. He is promoting to activism in social movements.

The Forced Paradise of Aging? : Questions for a Critical Gerontology ; [Conference of the Section Age(s) and Society of the German Society for Sociology (DGS) on the topic The Forced Paradise of Aging? Questions for a Critical Gerontology, July 8 and 9, 2005 at the Vienna University of Economics and Business] ¤ This book is dedicated to the questions that are currently being raised in social gerontology, when it comes to determining its scientific status and the political relevance of its research. Its subject, aging, has become a public issue to an unprecedented extent, receiving a multifaceted and contradictory treatment. A mix of idealization and devaluation, of utilitarian optimism and deficit anxiety runs through the many discussions and publications on aging. The social gerontology itself is not left untouched by the breaks and contradictions in the societal assessments. Especially not when it addresses the questions of benefits and costs, privileges and disadvantages, opportunities and risks. Compared to the first edition, further developments, additions, and new topics and methods have been incorporated, in which the heterogeneity of the entire subject matter has become even more apparent.

Photogrammetry - Laser Scanning - Optical 3D Measurement Technology : Contributions of the Oldenburg 3D Days 2005 ; [the Institute for Applied Photogrammetry and Geoinformatics of the University of Applied Sciences in Oldenburg organized the 4th Oldenburg 3D Days from 02.02 to 03.02.2005] ¤ This work contains the revised conference contributions of the 4th Oldenburg 3D Days "Optical 3D Measurement Technology - Photogrammetry - Laser Scanning", which took place under the direction of Prof. Luhmann from 02.02 to 03.02.2005 at the University of Applied Sciences Oldenburg

NS-Architecture: Power and Symbol Politics: [Contributions of an interdisciplinary symposium supported by the International Center for Culture and Technology Research (IZKT) "NS-Architecture: Power Politics and Symbolism" at the University of Stuttgart, which was held in June 2009 by the editors in conjunction with the architectural historian Werner Durth from the TU Darmstadt] ¤ In the self-presentation of the NS regime, architecture and urban planning played a key role - their power and symbol politics were correspondingly significant. Architecture was considered that

Innovation through Communication : Communication as Innovation Factor for Organizations ¤ The present collection documents the contributions of a conference of the same name, held at the Technical University of Kaiserslautern. The focus of the conference was on the innovation potential generated by strategic corporate communication in culture and non-profit organizations. Based on the need for an interdisciplinary management approach and specific competences of the management level and employees, authors from the fields of culture, media and communication theory, psychology, economics, law, administration and education deal with the topic. The approaches presented here sensitize for the need of a more comprehensive and thus contemporary view and contribute to a new orientation. Professor Dr. Thomas Heinze was the executive director of the Institute for Cultural Management at the FernUniversität Hagen and is now Professor Ordinario at the Free University of Bozen. Verena Lewinski-Reuter is a lawyer and cultural manager. She is currently active as a specialist and science lecturer, author and lecturer. Kerstin Steimle is a research assistant in the Fernstudiengang 'Management of Culture and Non-Profit Organizations' at the Distance and International Studies Center (DISC) of the Technical University of Kaiserslautern.

Guideline of the University - Quality of Teaching: Conference of the Humboldt University of Berlin and the Rectors' Conference; Berlin, June 25/26, 1999 ¤ The conference documented in the framework of the quality assurance project includes the following individual contributions: VORTRAGSZYKLUS 1. Guideline and evaluation of study and teaching from the perspective of science and politics (Mayer, Evelies: Teaching and study on the test stand - What can we know, what do we want to do? - Hertel, Ingolf: Accountability and quality assurance - Cornerstones of university autonomy. The state on the way from regulator to moderator. - Sahm, Jürgen: Unity of research and teaching - Guideline of a university study. - Weiss, Cornelius: The guideline of universities in change). - VORTRAGSZYKLUS 2. Teaching evaluation in international comparison. Concepts and practical experiences (Vroeijenstijn, A. I.: External Quality Assessment (EQA) in the Netherlands. The 3rd Generation 2000-2006. - Alderman, Geoffrey: Audit, Assessment and Academic Autonomy Revisited. - Henze, Jürgen: Notes on quality assurance measures at Australian universities. - Rühl, Thomas: Evaluation experiences in the USA). - VORTRAGSZYKLUS 3. Possibilities and limitations of evaluation. Expectations - experiences - developments (Daniel, Hans-Dieter: Experiences from evaluation projects in Kassel and Mannheim. - Habel, Edna: Evaluation at North Rhine-Westphalian universities - A workshop report. - Engel, Uwe: Determinants of student quality judgments. About variation causes, distortions and responsibilities. - Michaelis, Elisabeth: Possibilities and limitations of evaluation. Expectations - experiences - developments) (HoF/Text adopted)

Quality of University Education: Course and Results of a Colloquium at the University of Kassel ¤ At the University of Kassel, a total of 26 projects have been established, each dealing with different themes, methods, and forms of innovation, improvement, and evaluation of teaching and teaching research. The goal of the colloquium 'Quality of University Education', which is documented in the present volume, was to bring together the participants of these projects and provide them with a forum for opinion and experience exchange, for discussion with other interested and experienced people inside and outside the University of Kassel, and not least to determine their own position in a rather confusing university landscape. Contributions: - Introduction - Gorzka, Gabriele: Opening and welcome to the colloquium 'Quality of Teaching'. - Oehler, Christoph: On the current debate about the quality of university education (see individual contribution). - Winkler, Helmut: Quality of university education - What is it?. - Paschke, Egon: The quality of teaching. - Preisser, Ruediger: Teaching course criteria as the first step in evaluating teaching at the Technical University of Berlin. - Webler, Wolff-Dietrich: Evaluation of teaching: practical experiences and methodological guidelines. - Winkler, Helmut: Overview of the projects in the promotion program for the improvement of teaching and teaching research at the GhK. - Baldauf, Beate/Oehler, Christoph/Winkler, Helmut/Gruenig, Baerbel: Reports from the working groups. - Mayer, Evelies: Expectations and proposals of the Hessian State Government for the improvement of the quality of university education (see individual contribution). - Winkler, Helmut: Summary of the plenary discussion with the Hessian Minister of Science. (PHF/uebern.)

A World Without God? : Religion and Ethics in State, School and Society ¤ The religions have it hard in the world today, but the world has it hard with the religions too. On the one hand, the process of secularization is advancing, on the other hand, religious fundamentalism is increasing. Against this backdrop, discussions about religion and ethics in state, school, and society are taking place everywhere. Although the topic affects all countries and cultures, it is discussed by each individually. There is hardly any European or global discussion. In the present volume, models from secularist-oriented France and confessionally-shaped Germany are compared and, in doing so, questions are asked about common European perspectives. The practice of LER instruction (Life Help - Ethics - Religion) in Brandenburg, which is mainly rejected in West Germany, looks different from the French model of the secular school without religious instruction compared to the Bavarian model of a strictly confessionally-shaped school with crucifixes in the classroom. Potsdam seems to be closer to Paris than to Munich.

Aachen Expert Days 2018: Faultless and yet defective: Additional irregularities, tolerable or to be eliminated defects ¤ The 44th Aachen Expert Days deal with the topic: "Additional irregularities, tolerable or to be eliminated defects". In buildings erected under time and cost pressure in manual single-piece production, deviations from the specified requirements cannot be ruled out. There is no zero tolerance, both in manual single-piece production and in industrial production. Which deviations are "in the nature of the work" unavoidable, still contractually justifiable and therefore tolerable? Which are to be classified as no longer tolerable? How can planners and executors orient themselves when contract contents are only determined "by interpretation" in retrospect? The activity of the expert at the interface between law and technology is an important part of the overall legal assessment. Therefore, contributions from the fields of wood construction, concrete surfaces, plaster and natural stone are also dealt with, as well as legal aspects. A lecture deals with the hitherto underestimated environmental impacts of defect elimination, which can significantly impair sustainability. In the current topic, the problems surrounding the commercial depreciation are taken up and technical procedures discussed. Is it even a technical topic or only an unrealistic wishful thinking? Important innovations in building technical regulations - an overview -- Additional irregularities and tolerability from a legal point of view; Cost statements in court expert opinions -- Trivialities - reduction - performance; subjective value properties, radiation factors, reduction in case of impossibility, unreasonableness or disproportionality -- Tolerance limits: Are matching as a basis for evaluating optical properties suitable? -- Moisture in roof insulation materials - Report from research -- Roof coverings: Unevenness in seam widths, material thicknesses, flatness, slopes and appearance -- Wood surfaces: Cracks, branches, discoloration and machining marks -- Coverings from natural stone, tiles, paving: New manufacturing techniques and increased consumer expectations -- Plaster, coatings: Unevenness, importance of gaps in the filling of joints, spots, cavities, blooming, peeling, cracks -- Reinforced concrete components: flawless after production, transport and assembly? -- Exposed concrete: Temporal changes in appearance; feasibility of optical target ideas -- Commercial depreciation: technical and legal contradictions -- Commercial depreciation: Usual in rectifications - Legal considerations -- Commercial depreciation: Technical procedures? -- Commercial depreciation: (Not) a topic for property valuation -- Reduction in case of preservation or exchange? Considerations under sustainability aspects -- Blessing and curse of quality classes in regulations; Variant formation -- Mold in building components: Insulation of interior spaces - Report from research

What Europe Do We Want? : Solidarity in Politics : The 19th Hannah-Arendt Days 2016 ¤ At least since the financial crisis of 2007/08, the European Union has also been in a crisis of solidarity – austerity policy, Brexit, and the closure of EU external borders are clear symptoms of this. What are the challenges of European politics, and how could a future European community look like? These questions were controversially discussed at the 19th Hannah-Arendt Days in Hanover. The analyses of problems and proposals presented there are now collected in this volume. The contributions by Marianne Kneuer, Hans-Jürgen Urban, Friedhelm Hengsbach, Ulrike Guérot, etc. are based on Hannah Arendt's 'Thinking Without a Parapet' and also include utopian ideas, for example, for a European republic beyond national states. Following Arendt's book On Revolution and her considerations on Vita activa, in which the determination of politics as communal action in freedom is at the center, the authors of the anthology formulate concepts for a politics of genuine togetherness. Instead of being an economic and monetary union, as hoped, Europe should be designed in such a way that it actually deserves the name Solidarity Community: a solidary European community that understands itself not as 'United States of Europe', but as a European republic.

Hochhausstadt Frankfurt : Bauten und Visionen seit 1945 ; [anlässlich der Ausstellung "Himmelstürmend. Hochhausstadt Frankfurt", 8. November 2014 - 19. April 1015, Deutsches Architekturmuseum, Dezernat für Kultur und Wissenschaft, Stadt Frankfurt am Main] : buildings and visions since 1945 ¤ How and why did Frankfurt grow upwards? Hochhausstadt Frankfurt / High-Rise City Frankfurt poses this question and provides an overview of the high-rise history of the city: from the post-war reconstruction of 1945 to the current era of global financial markets.

Handwerk becomes modern : from manufacturing at Bauhaus ¤ It must have been quite loud and dusty in the workshops at Bauhaus Dessau. Here, hammers were struck, planes were planed, saws were sawed, and looms were woven. The publication Handwerk wird modern. From manufacturing at Bauhaus, Bauhaus is questioned from the perspective of craftsmanship. There was no concept that was more fiercely debated. The workshops were transition spaces: between factory and craft business, between free experiment and industrial piecework. From this field of tension, Bauhaus tried to redefine craftsmanship as a utopia, but also in coexistence with industrial culture. How current these debates are again today, contemporary design theorists and practitioners position themselves and provide new insights into the understanding of craftsmanship in the 21st century

Lifelong Learning and Educational Biographical Research: Concepts and Research in the European Discourse ¤ Lifelong learning has established itself as an educational policy concept in the most important European states over the past few years. That the basic research on lifelong learning processes has by no means kept pace with this, but rather requires a multitude of research efforts and discussions, has become apparent through the different perspectives on learning processes over a lifetime in European contexts. In addition, a look at the different conditions of lifelong learning under a biographical theoretical perspective in various European states is interesting. This publication expands the research perspective of biographical research to a European level and combines the educational policy concept of 'Lifelong Learning' with basic theoretical research approaches.

Children - Bodies - Identities : Theoretical and Empirical Approaches to Cultural Practice and Social Change ¤ In today's societies, child identities and body practices multiply. The present book brings together studies from the context of more recent childhood and youth research projects, which are particularly concerned with identity developments and representations in cultural practice and social change.

University Economics - Analyses of Internal Control Problems and Macroeconomic Effects ¤ The number and variety of economic problems in the higher education sector have increased significantly in recent years - not least due to dwindling resources. This was the occasion for the Educational Economic Committee to deal with higher education economic issues at its 27th annual conference, which took place in March 2002 at the Friedrich Schiller University in Jena. The contributions of this conference are compiled in the present volume. The essays are dedicated to internal organizational, personnel policy or production theoretical problems of the university, on the other hand, the macroeconomic consequences of alternative financing systems of a complete university system are considered. In this, not only theoretical considerations are presented, but also comprehensive empirical studies that clearly emphasize the importance of the presented higher education economic problems and solution approaches.

Future Tasks of Wastewater Disposal in Rural Areas: Symposium on October 9, 2003 in Weimar ¤ Foreword In Thuringia, there are approximately 200,000 small sewage treatment plants, most of which are in very poor structural condition. The wastewater is either indirectly introduced through so-called

Chances and Risks of Smart Cams in Public Space ¤ The conference proceedings address technical, legal, and political issues of the increasing penetration of urban life by various image capture techniques for the first time comprehensively. In addition to surveillance cameras from security authorities, private Smart Cams carried by individuals are emerging, which are often unnoticed and ready to capture at any time, attached to clothing or glasses, behind windshields or in drones. The volume contains scientific contributions to the individual techniques, the motivations of users, and the rights of those unintentionally captured. The conference debate on user interests and personality protection, including proposals for conflict resolution, is also documented. Since the conference was conducted jointly by the ChaRiSma project funded by the BMBF and the Data Protection Advisory Board of the Deutsche Bahn Group, security concerns play a central role as a motive for camera use. In addition to legal and political decision-makers, developers of data protection-friendly technology are also addressed. With contributions from: Prof. Dr. oec. HSG Oliver Bendel, Dr. Alexander Bergfink, RAin Claudia Bischof, Prof. Dr. Dr. Volker Boehme-Neßler, Prof. Dr. Susanne Boll-Westermann, RA Bernd H. Harder, Klaus-Dieter Hommel, Dirk Kühnert, Chris Newiger, Dirk Paulmann, Bettina Robrecht, Dr. Edgar Rose, RA Dr. Thomas Schwenke, Maja Smoltczyk, RAin Jana Spilker, Fabian Stindt, Prof. Dr. Jürgen Taeger, Franz Xaver Vogl and Michael Ziesak

Atem. Gestalterische, ökologische und soziale Dimensionen ¤ During breathing - in the process of constant exchange and crossing of boundaries between the organism and its environment - air as an «immaterial» material becomes active. For the first time, this anthology brings together studies on breath from the perspective of the arts and humanities, as well as experimental scientific and design practices. Focusing on the period from 1900 to the present day, the publication covers an era during which air has become a precarious medium: whether in the context of climate change or global pandemic, space technology or gas warfare, air is now co-created and manipulated by humans. Against this backdrop, breath appears as an elusive yet vital substance that reveals the interconnections between the physical, symbolic, technological and social realms

Gerechte Medizin? : Analyses and Impulses from Theory and Practice ¤ Justice issues in the healthcare sector are gaining increased urgency in the light of rising medical costs, an ageing society as well as the tides of migration that have been increasing recently. How can we allocate scarce medical resources as justly as possible, and what role do traditional concepts of justice play in this context? Who should be responsible for that? How can decisions regarding the allocation be ethically justified?The contributions to this volume explore these and similar questions from the perspectives of medicine, health economics and ethics, and provide concrete insights into various fields of medical practice. It becomes apparent that the problem of scarce resources cannot be solved by rationalisation measures alone in the future. We must therefore think in the broadest terms about not only the ‘ethics of waste avoidance’, but also the ‘ethics of rationing’.With contributions byEva Czermak, Gebhard Falzberger, Peter G. Kirchschläger, Wolfgang Kröll, Aandrea Laslop, Leopold Neuhold, August Österle, Sigrid Pilz, Johann Platzer, Walter Schaupp, Jürgen Wallner

Foreign women - women in foreign lands : studies on foreignness and gender in the Hebrew Bible and the Ancient Near East in the first millennium BCE ¤ International scholars from various disciplines and methodological approaches investigate gender-specific constructions of foreignness in the Old Testament, Egypt, and Mesopotamia. They show that when combined, foreignness and gender can take on very different forms. The contributions of this volume investigate specific questions, individual female figures, and individual phenomena as model cases. The collection is a preliminary and basic work for further study of gender-specific concepts of foreignness/strangeness in the ancient Mediterranean cultures of the first millennium BCE. The volume presents a collection of papers read during three workshops held in Leipzig (2016), Jerusalem (2017), and Vienna (2018). International scholars from different disciplines and methodological approaches explored gender-specific constructions of foreignness/strangeness in the Old Testament, Egypt, and Mesopotamia from their particular perspectives. They showed that when combined, strangeness/foreignness and gender can take on very different forms. Various processes of the »othering« of women are of importance, which differ from the »othering« of men. The contributions investigate specific questions, individual female figures and individual phenomena as model cases. The basic question was when, where, how and for what purpose the categories of foreignness and gender were connected and activated in literary tradition. The collection is a preliminary and basic work for further study of gender-specific concepts of foreignness/strangeness in the ancient Mediterranean cultures of the first millennium BCE.Survey of contentsLars Allolio-Näcke: How to Become an Alien (Woman)? – Sara Japhet: Marriage with Foreign Women: Yes or No? – Nili Wazana: Rahab, the Unlikely Foreign Woman of Jericho (Joshua 2) – Marianne Grohmann: The Philistine Woman from Timnah in Judges 14:1–15:8 – Angelika Berlejung: Solomon's Soulmate: The Queen of Sheba as Foreign Woman – Daniel Bodi: When Yhwh's Wife, Jerusalem, Became a Strange Woman: Inversion of Values in Ezekiel 16 in Light of Ištar Cult – From Spouse to Brothel Boss (ʾiššâ zônâ šallāṭet) – Stefan Fischer: Foreign Women in the Book of Proverbs – Jan Dietrich: The Image of the Foreign Woman in Proverbs 1–9 – Hans-Peter Mathys: Phoenicians and Money Bags. Observations on Prov 7 – Hans-Peter Mathys: The Valiant Housewife of Prov 31:10–31: A Phoenician Businesswoman – Jutta Hausmann: Pharaoh's Daughter and Ruth – Cornerstones in the History of Israel – Agnethe Siquans: A Moabite Woman as the 'Right Son': Ruth as Naomi's and Boaz's Daughter – Kristin Joachimsen: Esther in Shushan: Narrative Constructions of Otherness related to Gender, Ethnicity and Social Status within the Persian Empire – Franziska Naether: Ancient Expats? Wise Women and Witches in Egyptian Literary Sources – Angelika Berlejung: Forever Foreign? Marriage Rules in Urban Babylonia and their Impact on the Exiles and Returnees

From the Sound of Images ¤ Interaction, approach, and exchange between visual art and music run like a red thread through the 20th century. Images do not sound, music eludes visibility, and yet both derive essential impulses and innovations from each other. Abstract painting, which brought liberation from color and form, led many artists like composers to proceed (polyphony at Klee); in the famous artist friendship between Schoenberg and Kandinsky, there is talk of "color hearing," but already Runge and Schwind built their images in the 19th century according to the model of the sonata first movement form. The author follows the lines of connection and interfaces between the two arts, keywords such as "color light music," "sound sculpture," "plastic sound," "graphic music" etc. are to be mentioned. The text is the revised and streamlined version of a lavish exhibition catalog (Music in the Art of the 20th Century, Staatsgalerie Stuttgart 1985) and is perfectly suited as an introduction to this complex topic. Corresponding illustration. (3) (LK/S: Voss-Krueger)

Reform of the Healthcare System — or: In Which Healthcare System Do We Want to Live? : A Disputation ¤ In the context of overall societal relationships, the monetary problems of statutory health insurance exert a great pressure on the healthcare system in its internal order and structure, its areas of care, functional methods, and professions. Therefore, the internal structures of the healthcare system with its numerous institutions, but also the effectiveness, efficiency, and quality of the services provided are in the focus of critical consideration.

Urban Land Management in City and Region : Urban Agriculture, Urban Gardening and Agribusiness ¤ Neighborhood gardens and intercultural gardens, planted tree disks and facades with fruit for self-harvesting, temporary vegetable beds on vacant lots and blooming street islands are interpreted as expressions of a new urban agriculture. Not only orchards and fields on the outskirts of the city, but also self-harvesting fields and the use of temporary forests as short-rotation plantations are now part of the productive urban landscapes described as agricultural and horticultural used urban and regional green spaces. Agriculture and horticulture in the city seem to be in vogue, and the number of new projects is growing continuously. But also in the specialist discussions, numerous contributions deal with innovative approaches for a sustainable and future-proof urban development with the phenomenon of urban gardening and urban agriculture. This volume considers the relevance of the topic for the future viability of cities and urban regions on the basis of current research results and practice examples. New challenges are identified for the municipal handling of agriculture and gardens.

Interfaces (in) of Media Economics ¤ The digital world is characterized by interfaces. In the form of user interfaces or interface systems, these are often of a technical nature. However, social interfaces also exist between individuals via internet services when looking at social media. Decision-making processes such as media selection, for example, on video-on-demand platforms are shaped by media psychological aspects. Media economics as a scientific discipline addresses these changed framework conditions and fields of research. Therefore, interdisciplinary work is intensified with communication science, advertising communication, and journalism. The 22 contributions in this conference volume offer a current snapshot of the research field of media economics and media management

Paul Schmitthenner 1884 - 1972 : [this catalog book appears on the occasion of the exhibition "Beauty rests in order. Paul Schmitthenner 1884 - 1972" from August 16 to November 9, 2003] ¤ As a design teacher of the Stuttgart School, Paul Schmitthenner was one of the leading architects of his time between the world wars. His settlements with virtuosically staged cityscapes - Staaken near Berlin (1914-17), Plaue near Brandenburg, Ooswinkel near Baden-Baden - make it forgotten that standardized floor plans and building components were used for the first time here. The characteristics of the residential buildings that established his reputation were regional sensitivity, material justice, subtle room sequences, and masterful details. The Schmitthenner house, which played with the memory of Goethe's garden house in Weimar, significantly shaped the ideal of stylishly restrained living culture. Paul Schmitthenner was not a friend of modern avant-garde, as it manifested itself in the Weißenhofsiedlung in Stuttgart. After he identified himself with the Third Reich in 1933, he later became an opponent of Nazi state architecture and made no secret of it in public. His repeatedly printed lecture 'The Gentle Law in Architecture' (1941) reminded us of the secret of measure and number in body and space, of which modern art knows nothing more in its boundlessness.

Spaces of Action and Remembrance: The Evangelical Lutheran Church in Bavaria and National Socialism ¤ Did churches have spaces for action during the NS time, how were they used and where was there voluntary adaptation? The volume explores the church's behavioral spectrum under the NS dictatorship. Using the example of the Bavarian state church under National Socialism, the contributions compare, on the one hand, the attitudes of church protagonists, church leadership personnel, and the actions of bishops. On the other hand, they investigate the different action variants of individual church communities. Thus, a comprehensive picture emerges that shows the boundaries and spaces of church action. Furthermore, the volume brings the church's handling of its own role in National Socialism into focus and reconstructs the historical development of church memory since the end of the war.

Genus - Sexus - Gender ¤ This volume brings together the latest empirical research on the connections between grammatical gender, natural gender, and the social category of gender. This trio operates on various levels: lexically and semantically, morphologically, syntactically, pragmatically, and in texts and discourse. These categories prove to be deeply entrenched within the German lexis and grammar. They reflect old orders of gender but also how they have transformed.

Leadership and Organization of the Armed Forces in the Democratic-Parliamentary State ¤ The Churches under the Basic Law Frontmatter -- Content -- Opening of the conference on October 5, 1967 -- First item on the agenda: The Churches under the Basic Law -- Second item on the agenda: Leadership and Organization of the Armed Forces in the Democratic-Parliamentary State -- List of speakers -- List of members of the Association of German Constitutional Law Teachers -- Statutes

Autonomous Systems and Work: Perspectives, Challenges, and Limits of Artificial Intelligence in the Workplace ¤ Intelligent planning systems and smart robots: In the future, autonomous systems based on the principles of artificial intelligence will also gain a foothold in the world of work. This raises not only new questions about the consequences for jobs and qualifications - the actual application possibilities of these systems and the resulting labor policy and ethical problems are still unclear. This volume makes an interdisciplinary contribution to the ongoing discourse.

European Spa Towns and Fashion Resorts of the 19th Century: International Expert Meeting of the German National Committee of ICOMOS, the State Office for the Preservation of Monuments Baden-Württemberg at the Regional Government Stuttgart and the City of Baden-Baden Baden-Baden, 25-27 November 2010 ¤ World resorts as World Heritage? - In the 19th century, there are a handful of places in Europe that develop into communication centers for an international clientele: nobles and citizens, industrialists and artists, the healthy and the sick seek these places annually for several weeks and months and shape social life with their demands and interests: spa houses, casinos, music pavilions, grand hotels, villas, society baths, horse racing tracks, sports fields, mountain railways - all of this emerges in the exchange relationship between supply and demand. Access is available to everyone who can afford it. - - In November 2010, the German National Committee of ICOMOS, together with the State Office for the Preservation of Monuments Baden-Württemberg and the City of Baden-Baden, held an international expert meeting in Baden-Baden, which dealt with the profile and significance of these internationally shaped spa towns. The occasion was provided by the thinking of several spa towns in Europe about an application for inclusion in the UNESCO World Heritage List. With the event, an initial impulse for a joint application was to be given. - - In seventeen contributions, which are documented in this volume, answers were sought to various questions: What do the spa towns say about the social conditions and changes in the 19th century? To what extent do they anticipate the Europe of the 20th century? Are there the same phenomena at the same time at different locations? Where are the differences? Is there a typical physiognomy of the spa towns? What is the relationship between intangible and tangible cultural heritage? END

The Fantastic Film : History and Function in the Media Society ¤ Klappentext: The Fantastic is not only a thematic area in the texts and films of the genre, but always also refers to specific properties and possibilities of the medium, not least of the film, and acquires its own medial qualities. The book shows at central examples, how in the medium of the Fantastic, problem potential of the time is grasped, processed and worked on in a specifically way, especially questions about the reality of man and the experienceability of his world.

Streitfall Zweisprachigkeit : [... gathers selected contributions to a conference that took place in October 2007 ... at the University of Hamburg] ¤ The question of whether bilingualism of migrants is a positive, individual as well as socially useful competence is controversial. The conference offers a forum for interdisciplinary and international exchange on the latest research results on this question - and thus also on the objectification of the debates on the 'Streitfall Zweisprachigkeit'.

Continuity and Change in Communist State Theory ¤ Friedrich-Christian Schroeder, Boris Meißner, Klaus Westen (Editors): Continuity and Change in Communist State Theory. Berlin-Verlag, Berlin 1985. 151 pages, 25 Marks

Plan 09 : Forum of Current Architecture in Cologne, 09/25 - 10/02/2009 ; Urbanism III, plan academy, cross architecture, City as Process, En Passant, Open Source Planning, Common Good City Gap, Temporary Paradise II, Guerrilla Gardening, Mobile Green, Park Unit, Durable Architecture, Lean City, Cultural Library, Talking Spaces, Nomad Bank, Six Right + 1, Paris New York Shanghai, meeting point: University of Media ¤ Urbanismis III - Self Made City or City as Process - - The central theme is, in continuation of the focal points of plan07 and plan08, for the third and presumably last time Urbanism. The Plan Trilogy accompanies the beginning of the truly 'urban' century: Since 2007, for the first time in history, more people live in cities than in the countryside. At the same time, we observe a new drive of 'city-making': Urbanism is increasingly taking place in indeterminate processes and in self-organization. Urbanism 'from below', initiatives like 'City from Below' and other open networks are today the driving forces.

Agglomerations - Situation and Perspectives : 8th Young Forum of the ARL, June 1-3, 2005 in Gelsenkirchen ¤ Agglomeration areas have long been considered centers of economic, political, and cultural life. This is particularly true for Germany, which, with a population density of 231 inhabitants per square kilometer, ranks among the most densely populated European countries. Currently, spatial planning policy, spatial planning, and spatial research are facing special and diverse challenges in the agglomeration areas. The combination of deindustrialization, demographic and social change, and regional structural change leads to strong upheavals in this type of space, which, in terms of their effects and the resulting action requirements, are still discussed too little. Against this background, the Young Forum 2005 of the Academy for Spatial Research and Land Planning dealt with the situation and perspectives of the federal German agglomeration areas at its conference from June 1 to 3, 2005 in Gelsenkirchen. In addition to basic questions, four thematic areas were particularly addressed:

Resilience for the VUCA World: Developing Individual and Organizational Resilience ¤ VUCA (volatility, uncertainty, complexity, ambiguity) determines our environment, in both private and corporate contexts. Crises are on the agenda, so that crisis anticipation, adaptation, regeneration from, and learning from the crisis are becoming increasingly important for a successful life and work design. This crisis competence is called resilience. Coaches, executives, and entrepreneurs receive a comprehensive overview of approaches to resilience in this anthology. The content: • Holistic approaches to individual and organizational resilience • VUCA world as a constant of future working worlds • Measurement of resilience strength of individuals, teams, and organizations • Neurobiological and medical foundations of resilience • Individual resilience strengthening • Practical examples of resilience promotion The target groups Coaches, consultants, executives The editor Prof. Dr. Jutta Heller is a coach, author, and consultant for individual and organizational resilience. She has been self-employed for over 25 years and has been training resilience consultants since 2015. Her main focus is on companies to support the development of resilience for individuals, teams, and the entire organization. She was the initiator and organizer of the Erdinger Coaching Congress of the University of Applied Management from 2014 to 2017. She is the 1st chairwoman of ORES - Association for Organizational Resilience - which, among other things, promotes research on organizational resilience. Holistic approaches to individual and organizational resilience -- VUCA world as a constant of future working worlds -- Measurement of resilience strength of individuals, teams, and organizations -- Neurobiological and medical foundations of resilience -- Individual resilience strengthening -- Practical examples of resilience promotion

New Challenges to Service Marketing ¤ Challenge to the behavioral scientific foundations of service marketing -- Emotional work in services: concept, consequences, intervention -- The use of videography in service management — An analysis of „crazy types“ -- The construct atmosphere in football stadiums — Conceptualization and operationalization -- Determinants of relationship commitment of service customers -- Entrepreneurial challenges to service marketing -- „What is beautiful is good“: The influence of employee attractiveness on pre-encounter expectation formation of service customers -- The relationship between perceived costs and loyalty intention: A theoretical and empirical analysis at the example of car services -- Employee pride in the call center — A theoretically-conceptual consideration based on the Affective Events Theory AET -- To own or not to own! A property rights perspective on services in technology licensing -- Challenges to the conceptual foundations of service research -- Development lines and influence of service research — A quantitative approach -- Validity of the characteristics of services — a question of the reference object -- Performance theory and Service-Dominant Logic for Marketing — a critical comparison -- Challenges to the action-oriented framework of service marketing -- Product-related services as a profiling instrument for brand providers -- Internationalization of services — Success factors depending on different service types -- Value creation-related peculiarities of young knowledge-intensive service providers -- Strategic proliferation through integrated service production — An entrepreneur-function-based analysis in the service sector. The tertiarization of the economy is advancing dynamically in the highly developed industrial nations. At the same time, the competition intensity is increasing in increasingly global service markets. The marketing science is therefore increasingly facing the challenges of service marketing. Since 1991, marketing researchers from Germany, Austria, and Switzerland have been dealing with topics of service research in the framework of an annual workshop. The present volume documents the contributions to the 12th Service Workshop, which was held in March 2007 by the Institute for Marketing and Service Research at the University of Rostock. The authors approach the current research questions of service marketing from different perspectives. All contributions are characterized, however, by the fact that the presented concepts and solution proposals offer a wide range of suggestions for further research, but also for science-interested practice beyond the respective branches.

A Thousand Times "Why"? Improving Educational Quality in Preschool Institutions: Documentation of a Conference of the German Institute for Urban Studies (Difu) in Cooperation with the German City League (DST), the German Telekom Foundation, and the Working Group Conferences Youth Welfare on January 14/15, 2010 in Berlin ¤ Early childhood education is thematically at the interface of social pedagogical expertise and municipal political responsibility. It aims, in addition to knowledge transfer, to enable children to successfully navigate transitions and to promote their resilience. This volume documents contributions and statements from representatives of science and municipal practice at a Difu conference on the topic. A particular focus is on the project

Crimes of the Wehrmacht : Dimensions of the War of Annihilation 1941 - 1944 ¤ The war of the Soviet Union differed from all wars of European modernity, also from those that the German Wehrmacht led during the Second World War in other countries. It was a war that targeted not only another army, but also parts of the civilian population. The Jewish population was to be murdered, non-Jewish civilians were to be decimated by hunger and terror and employed for forced labor. This criminal conduct did not arise from the escalation of the war situation, but was already part of the war plans. For what happened concretely during the German occupation in the East, the war plans were, however, only a determining factor. Furthermore, each individual case was shaped by concrete action conditions, determined by current influences and influenced by the behavior and action patterns of the actors.

Alternative Concepts of Social Security ¤ The present volume contains the papers presented at the annual conference of the Committee on Social Policy in 1997. Hans Jürgen Rösner deals with the structural and organizational principles of social security. As functions that have to fulfill a new paradigm, integration, consensus promotion, risk insurance, productivity promotion, and the survival ability of the security system are highlighted. Roland Eisen is concerned with alternatives of care insurance. The models of private voluntary insurance, private compulsory insurance, state social insurance, and social assistance are discussed. In addition, the author assigns them the solutions chosen in 12 member states of the European Union. A more in-depth comparison of the German, English, and Danish systems follows. Johannes Schwarze examines the American and German old-age security system with regard to the level of security, old-age poverty, and income distribution. The institutional comparison shows that the American old-age security system is strongly oriented towards avoiding old-age poverty, while the German system aims at securing living standards over a broad income range. However, the empirical comparison of the income situation of the elderly population shows that the German system better fulfills both the goal of poverty avoidance and the goal of securing living standards in old age. Richard Hauser analyzes concepts of minimum security for the elderly in twelve EU member states. Based on a systematization of the regulations existing in the countries, institutionally based hypotheses about their effectiveness are formulated. The empirical analysis based on data from the Luxembourg Income Study Project, however, shows that poverty in old age occurs in all countries despite the diverse minimum regulations.

Quality Development in a Diversified University System: Documentation of a Symposium, Science Center Bonn, January 9, 1997 ¤ This publication documents the symposium on the questions "Evaluation - Quality Improvement", which took place on January 9, 1997 at the Science Center Bonn of the Stifterverband for German Science. Over 300 rectors, deans, representatives from ministries and students attended the event to exchange views on quality development. In addition to the lectures, the poster exhibition formed the core of the symposium. Universities and faculties presented their posters, showing the successes of their efforts to improve quality in study design. Table of Contents: Introduction: Erhardt, Manfred, Secretary General of the Stifterverband. - Lectures: Lüthje, Jürgen: Procedures and elements of systemic quality development: Examples from the University of Hamburg. - Hortschansky, Klaus: Quality development in research, teaching and organization: The Philosophical Faculty of the University of Münster. - Profile formation, competition and cooperation: The Universities of Mannheim and Heidelberg - 1 Part: Ulmer, Peter: Legal framework, backgrounds and perspectives of cooperation. - 2 Part: Frankenberg, Peter: The practice of cooperation. - Poster exhibition: Group I: Evaluation: Study programs / departments / subjects. - Group II: "Third-party funds" for teaching and other performance incentives. - Group III: Evaluation of courses and further quality development procedures. - Group IV: From ISO 9000 to Total Quality Management (TQM). - Panel discussion: Quality development at universities - A way out of the educational policy defensive? - Statements (Lämmert, Eberhardt, Free University of Berlin. - Müller-Böling, Detlef, Center for Higher Education Development, Gütersloh. - Kolbeck, Matthias, University of Hamburg. - Fischer, Werner, Karlsruhe University of Applied Sciences. - Winterfeldt, Ekkehard, University of Hanover. - Meyer, Hans Joachim, Ministry of Science and Art, Saxony) - Discussion - Closing word: Erhardt, Manfred (HOF/taken over)

Enterprise of Mercy : Identity and Change in Social Service Provision ; Frameworks - Perspectives - Best Practice Examples ¤ Cliffnotes: The structural change in the voluntary welfare sector has reached the institutions of social service provision. They are increasingly reorganizing themselves and redefining their external relationships. At the same time, a wave of management professionalization has set in. This collection presents concrete examples of the efforts of social service organizations and welfare associations to meet these challenges. Based on these projects, the authors ask about the value of concepts such as vision, communication, efficiency, or dynamics. Furthermore, the book contains the demand to also modernize one's own ideas of management. The book, which arose on the occasion of the 125th anniversary of the Liebenau Foundation (Disability and Elderly Care), is a benefit for all executives in the voluntary welfare sector, as it presents perspectives for learning- and change-capable organizations through case examples and pleads for a new 'culture of service'. In addition to practitioners, scholars from theology, welfare research, and management science are heard in the book.

Health - Ethics - Economics: Economic and Moral-Economic Perspectives of the Healthcare System ¤ In the shadow of highly encouraging medical and medical-technical progress, the healthcare system is exposed to growing financial burdens. In the face of the emerging development of technical, demographic, and not least legal framework conditions, dramatic conflicts over the dwindling funds are foreseeable. Despite the obvious inefficiencies of the existing system, economists' proposals for improvement have so far been implemented only to a limited extent; some even meet with unanimous rejection from doctors, ethicists, and experts from other disciplines. -- Some of the objections presented can be easily refuted: While medical care (unlike

Baugruppenarchitektur in Freiburg : from Experiment to Rule ; [Exhibition and Book ... within the framework of the Architecture Summer 2005] ¤ Herausgeber Initiatorengruppe / Architects' Chamber Baden-Württemberg/ Chamber Group Freiburg and Chamber Group Breisgau - Black Forest - Emmendingen / Architecture Forum Freiburg / Matthias Betz, Hubert Burdenski, Meinhard Hansen, Gerhard Kerner, Thomas Melder, Otmar Veit, Lorenz Wehrle

Optica : optical instruments at the court of the Landgraves of Hesse-Kassel ; [on the occasion of the exhibition "Optica. Reconstruction of the Optical Room at the Landgrave Karl's Art House" in the West Pavilion of the Orangery from September 1, 2011 to February 26, 2012] ¤ History -- Telescope -- Telescope -- Astronomy -- Microscope -- Lens, Mirror -- Magic Lantern

Bauen und Zeigen : from History and Presence of the Karlsruhe Art Gallery ; [on the occasion of the exhibition "Bauen und Zeigen. From History and Presence of the Karlsruhe Art Gallery" at the State Art Gallery Karlsruhe from June 5 to September 21, 2014] ¤ Information from the publisher's announcement - - Bauen und Zeigen : From History and Presence of the Karlsruhe Art Gallery - - This publication tells the history of the Karlsruhe Art Gallery in a different way: not as the history of the collections, but as the history of architecture and museum presentation. In 1846, it was opened as a Gesamtkunstwerk from architecture, painting, and sculpture. BAUEN UND ZEIGEN gives insights into the history of an institution that is constantly changing. The catalog contains 19 contributions from authors in art and architectural history, archaeology, ancient philology, history, and architecture, as well as two photographic series on the gallery by Candida Höfer and Barbara Klemm.

Economic Areas of the Future : Development of Areas for Knowledge-Intensive Companies ; Documentation of a Specialist Conference of the German Institute for Urbanistics and the City of Heidelberg on January 24 and 25, 2013 in Heidelberg ¤ In the last few decades, the spectrum of company locations has expanded significantly against the backdrop of the structural change described at the beginning. It goes far beyond the traditional image of production-oriented areas, which is associated with the term industrial areas. In particular, the area offers for knowledge-intensive companies were the focus of the specialist conference Economic Areas of the Future, whose contributions are documented in this volume. The following guiding questions were discussed at the event: Which location factors are important for knowledge-intensive companies, what role can spatial proximity play in a increasingly globalized world? What strategies and approaches are there to develop areas for knowledge-intensive companies? How can impulses from universities and research institutions be used for area development? How can conversion areas be used for the development of locations for knowledge-intensive companies?

Quality of Life in Old Age: Gerontological and Ethical Perspectives on Aging and Dementia ¤ In the ethical discourses on successful aging, questions about the good life and corresponding quality of life are at the center of interest. Interdisciplinary gerontological research examines how, in social communication processes, both widely accepted and controversially discussed models and evaluations of life in old age are formed. These conceptions of quality of life in old age also have an impact on the handling of ethical conflicts in medicine and care. Therefore, this volume integrates the gerontological and medical-ethical questions and deepens this interconnection exemplarily by the example of dealing with dementia.

Supply Chain Management and Advanced Planning Systems: A Tutorial ¤ Supply Chain Management and Advanced Planning Systems: A Tutorial -- Koordinationsansatz für ausgewählte Module von Advanced Planning and Scheduling-Systemen -- Master Planning in Supply Chains -- LP Modelling and Simulation of Supply Chain Networks -- Bewertung unterschiedlicher Beschaffungsstrategien für Risk-Hedging Supply Chains unter Berücksichtigung intermodaler Transportprozesse -- Coverage of Shelf Life in APS Systems -- Strategische Supply-Chain Entscheidungen in der Stahlindustrie - Eine Fallstudie -- Koordination in einer internen Supply Chain zwischen Produktions- und Vertriebsgesellschaften eines international tätigen Süßwarenherstellers -- Abbildungsfehler in zeitdiskreten Optimierungsmodellen — Auftreten und Maßnahmen zu ihrer Behebung -- Belegungsplanung einer Make&Pack-Anlage: eine Fallstudie aus der Konsumgüterindustrie -- Optimierung der Südzucker Rübenlogistik mittels iterativer linearer Programmierung -- Zum Einsatz von Chaku-Chaku-Systemen in der Montage konsumentennaher Erzeugnisse — eine Fallstudie bei Rahmenauftragsfertigung -- Product and Raw Material Storage at Omnova Solutions: A Case Study -- Fallstudie zur Logistikkostenrechnung: Darstellung und vergleichende Analyse verschiedener Verfahren -- IT-Integration of Terminal Operations Planning -- Das Reparaturspiel als Formalisierung von Planung unter Zufallseinflüssen, angewendet in der Flugplanung -- A Decision Support System for Airline Crew Management: Crew Scheduling and Rescheduling -- Die Auswirkungen von Verspätungen in Verkehrsnetzen — Ansätze einer Analyse auf der Grundlage der Max-Plus Algebra -- Heuristische Lösungsverfahren für das Probabilistic Traveling Salesman Problem -- Ein Planungstool zur Schulzeitstaffelung -- Entwicklung eines interaktiven Scheduling-Support-Systems für verfahrenstechnische Prozesse -- Optimierung von Warteschlangensystemen in Call Centern auf Basis von Kennzahlenapproximation -- Das kapazitierte Standortproblem: Branch-and-Price und die Wahl der Verzweigungsvariable -- Lagrange-Ansätze zur Lösung des Transportproblems mit Fixkosten -- Solving Complex QAP-Instances by a PC-LAN -- Optimization of Process Chain Models with Response Surface Methodology and the ProC/B Toolset. Das Buch präsentiert Beispiele zur Nutzung quantitativer Methoden in Supply Chain Management und Logistik aus den Bereichen des Operations Research und der Wirtschaftsinformatik.

Legislation as a Means of Perestroika: Wish and Reality ¤ The contributions of the collective volume analyze the legislative activity on different legal fields within the framework of the Soviet reform from a legal, economic, and political/social science perspective; the focus is on the legal novelties of 1988/89. In particular, the authors deal with the complex of business law (company law, labor law, cooperative law, foreign trade law), with the striving for "more democracy" (constitutional and electoral law amendments), with the development of "socialist rule of law" (judicial reform proposals) as well as with the transformation of social law in the sense of a "strong social policy". The volume concludes with a balance of the development of law in the Soviet Union.

Gender Showcase: Current Contributions to Social Science Gender Research ¤ Gender has established itself as an analytical category in recent years. However, it by no means occupies a central place in the mainstream of the various social science disciplines in Germany today. Against this background, the Berlin Institute for Applied Innovation and Future Research (IAIZ e.V.) in cooperation with the Office for Women's Promotion and Equality of the University of Applied Sciences Northeast Lower Saxony hosted the conference

The right to work for persons with disabilities : international perspectives ¤ The UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) has existed for over ten years. What is the state of play with regard to disabled individuals’ human right to work as stipulated by the CRPD? How open, inclusive and accessible are the job market and working environments for people with disabilities?This volume contains contributions to an international conference which took place in Kassel, Germany in March 2017. They address the right to work according to article 27 of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and the conditions of its realisation in thorough and concrete terms from a jurisprudential, sociological, political and practical perspective.With contributions byHeinz-Willi Bach, Siobhan Barron, Verena Bentele, Jerome Bickenbach, José Carlos do Carmo, Fong Chan, Yi-Chun Chou, Alo Dutta, Eberhard Eichenhofer, Delia Ferri, Wolf Arne Frankenstein, Marie-Renée Hector, Marianne Hirschberg, Martin Kronauer, Madan Kundu, Klaus Lachwitz, Friedrich Mehrhoff, Jürgen Menze, Eva Nachtschatt, Roy Sainsbury, Markus Schäfers, Mario Schreiner, Nai-Yi Sun, Bert Wagener, Gudrun Wansing, Felix Welti, Philine Zölls-Kaser.The preface, the foreword and the contributions by Eichenhofer, Welti/Nachtschatt, Kronauer, Mehrhoff, Zölls-Kaser, Frankenstein, Bach, Wagener, Sun and Schreiner were translated from German into English by oneword GmbH, Böblingen.

Queer to the Norm : Living Beyond a Gay or Lesbian Identity ¤ Schwullesbische Emanzipationsmovements have in their early years taken up the identity attributions by science and common sense and turned them positively in their sense. This self-assured act can however turn out to be a trap, in that it confirms such exclusions and itself excludes other groups of people.

The German Empire in Controversy ¤ The volume provides an important contribution to the ongoing debates about the German Empire (1871-1918). Renowned experts on the German Empire from international backgrounds provide an overview of the current state of research and raise new, guiding questions. The book is aligned along four axes, marking the themes and problems that have been the focus of controversies about the Empire in recent years: the location of the Empire in German history; the relationship between society, politics, and culture; forms of military violence with their focus on World War I, and finally the transnational entanglement of Germany in the age of the

The East Germans in the Media : the Image of the Others after 1990. [... Project Workshop in December 2007 at the Institute for History of the University of Vienna ...] ¤ Media shape opinions. This applies in particular to German reunification and the social process of reunification after 1990. The need for mutual information was just as great as the curiosity on both sides - but traditional identities and new conflict situations created in West German media at the same time a wide space for questionable media attributions to the East Germans. The authors of this collective volume investigate in six contributions on an empirical basis how the East Germans are represented in the media of the old Federal Republic and the united Germany and what effects this has on those thus constructed. It is thus at the same time a building block for a German-German perception history after the end of the two-state system.

Transfer and Law: Founding Myths, War Theater, and Techniques of Institutional Subjugation ¤ Behind the contributions stands the question of the tension between the brilliant stagings, the silent practices, and the justification strategies of institutions. Historical examples on the one hand, selected theoretical discussions on the other hand, are intended to outline contours of another institutional theory.

Dialogmarketing Perspectives 2013/2014: Proceedings of the 8th Interdisciplinary Congress for Dialogmarketing ¤ Innovative industries – and dialog marketing is definitely one of them – require intensive and practice-oriented research, which is why the German Dialog Marketing Association has made it its task for many years to promote the exchange between science and practice. The collection of essays Dialog Marketing Perspectives appears in 2013/2014 for the eighth time and brings together current specialist contributions and research projects on the topics of dialog marketing. It is based on the 8th interdisciplinary scientific congress for dialog marketing, which the DDV held in September 2013 at the University of Hamburg. The content (selection) - Emotions in cross-media dialogue - Social CRM - CRM between theory and practical implementation - Customer Journey Analysis - Change Management in the online age - Gamification in corporate practice The target groups · Lecturers and students of economics, business psychology, and interdisciplinary fields with a research focus on dialog marketing · Specialist and management staff in the dialog marketing industry The publisher The DDV is the communicative interface between business, politics, science, and consumers and represents the interests of service providers and advertising-driven companies in the entire dialog marketing industry. Emotions in cross-media dialogue -- Social CRM -- CRM between theory and practical implementation -- Customer Journey Analysis -- Change Management in the online age -- Gamification in corporate practice.

High-Quality Forest Propagation Material in Climate Change: Symposium of the FitForClim Consortium from June 14 to 15, 2016 in Chorin ¤ Forest tree breeding utilizes hidden genetic potential to maintain the future adaptability and performance of forests. At the conference „High-Quality Forest Propagation Material in Climate Change“, especially the possibilities of forest tree breeding were discussed in view of changing climatic conditions and the possibilities of assigning new use zones for forest propagation material. This volume publishes selected lectures and poster contributions of the conference. The volume is particularly aimed at scientists and practitioners from the fields of forest tree breeding, forest genetics, and forestry.

Apostle of Beauty ¤ He could almost be called a polymath: as a scholar who was curious, educated, and successful in many fields. Born in Partenkirchen in 1845, Max Schultze spent his working life between 1872 and 1912 as the architect of the House of Thurn and Taxis in Regensburg and created something grand, lasting, and above all sustainable. Schloss St. Emmeram owes him its current appearance. The essence of his work leads us further into various fields and different themes. In fact, his activities in photography, painting, drawing, but also in homeland and nature conservation were 'only' hobbies. His complex work, however, shows a professional, a busy artist, a versatile interested and active person who approached all his occupations with the same enthusiasm. Approximately 100 years after the death of Max Schultze, the exhibition in Regensburg and the exhibition catalog extensively illuminate his life. More than 40 authors from the fields of science, nature conservation, photography, etc. have compiled their research results. Much has come to light, been acquired, and numerous archival materials have been examined and evaluated. This diverse work represents a time that was characterized by conservatism and yet stood for a new beginning like no other. Max Schultze was a child of this exciting, innovative, and torn era

Education, Training and Gender: Masculinities in Focus of Gender Studies; [Annual Conference 2009 of the Commission 'Pedagogical Anthropology' in the German Society for Educational Science] ¤ The educational science has taken up the theoretical discussions, which in other humanities and social sciences disciplines have been led about the difference between 'sex' and 'gender', about the radical deconstruction of Judith Butler and about questions of performativity and intersectionality, and has connected to them. 'Doing gender' has led to studies that reconstruct the construction of gender through practices. In parallel, an explicit masculinity research has developed in recent years, which has organized itself in interdisciplinary working relationships and strongly follows the theoretical work of Connell, but also Bourdieu's concept of 'masculine habitus'. In the framework of educational science, works on male socialization, on unbounded masculinity and on fatherhood have emerged. The present volume deals with the connection between education, training and gender in interdisciplinary perspectives, in which, in addition to educational science, sociology and literary science are represented.

Blind for History? : Arab Encounters with National Socialism ¤ In this volume, a circle of experts expresses itself comprehensively in ten contributions for the first time on the encounter of the Arab world with National Socialism. This also includes the forgotten stories of North African colonial soldiers who served as "cannon fodder" in the fight against Nazi Germany, critical Arab evaluations of National Socialism, or the fates of Arabs and Muslims who died in German concentration and prisoner-of-war camps. British journalist Robert Fisk called the Arabs "blind to history" a few years ago when it came to their relationship with National Socialism and its crimes against the Jews. But being "blind to history" would also mean not asking the question of contemporary Arab perspectives on this time. The fragments of the common history of Arabs and Jews with National Socialism are also massively instrumentalized in the political conflict on both sides today.

Traffic Development in Urban Regions: Effects of Spatial and Economic Trends; Action Approaches; Documentation of a Seminar of the German Institute for Urban Studies on June 26 and 27, 1996 in Berlin ¤ The publication documents the presentations of the seminar, with which the German Institute for Urban Studies opened a series of events under the motto "Science and Municipal Practice in Dialogue". In the seminar, first research results from the joint project "Ecologically Compatible Mobility" were presented and discussed. The presented results were linked to the presentation and discussion of approaches by the responsible actors from a series of cities and from the economy. In the center were not only current and future trends in the influencing factors of the traffic phenomenon such as spatial structures and economic-technical structural change. Rather, it went further to primarily assess strategies and measures for ecologically compatible mobility.

Scope of the General Clause in Art. 19 Sec. 4 of the Bonn Basic Law ¤ Kabinettsfrage and State of Emergency in Legislation according to the Bonn Basic Law Frontmatter -- Content -- I. Opening -- II. First Agenda Item: Kabinettsfrage and State of Emergency in Legislation according to the Bonn Basic Law -- III. Second Agenda Item. Scope of the General Clause in Art. 19 Sec. 4 of the Bonn Basic Law -- IV. List of Speakers -- V. List of Members of the Association of German Public Law Scholars -- VI. Statutes

Engineering Education and Structural Changes at the Workplace of the Late 20th Century: Proceedings of the 24th International Symposium 'Engineering Education '95' ¤ The proceedings volume contains a cross-section of the various solution approaches from the field of technical education. The contributions reflect the situation of a Europe that is increasingly coming together in the late 20th century. - Content: FLEXIBLE LINK BETWEEN PRACTICE AND EDUCATION IN KNOWLEDGE TRANSFER (e.g. Brosch, P./Friedrich, H./Hermann, R.: Evaluation of teaching in the laboratory practical course. - Eppler, H.: Self-determined learning in the architecture study. - Hittmair, O.: History, principles, and practice in the natural-scientific-technical knowledge transfer. - Jansen, J.: First experiences from interdisciplinary teaching in engineering education. - Liebig, V.: University and business as complementary learning organizations. - Trautwein, M.: Cooperation between university and practice in electronic networks). - THE QUALITY OF TECHNICAL EDUCATION UNDER THE IMPACT OF EXPANSION (e.g. Berdelsmann, H.-D.: Pan-European mobility of students and graduates - The new EU program 'LEONARDO DA VINCI'. - Dobrovska, D.: How students perceive their studies. - Melezinek, A.: A contribution to the didactic quality of teaching: The IGIP qualification profile 'The European Engineering Educator - The European Engineer Educator ING-PAED IGIP'. - Schelling, G.: The importance of engineering education in the Austrian University of Applied Sciences system). - ENGINEERING EDUCATION IN THE FIELD BETWEEN RESEARCH AND TEACHING (e.g. Fischer, W./Voss, H.-P.: Didactic innovations at universities of applied sciences in Baden-Württemberg: Report on the first day of teaching). - DISTANCE LEARNING AS A POSSIBILITY OF CONTINUING AND FURTHER EDUCATION FOR THE PROFESSIONAL PERSON IN TECHNICAL PROFESSIONS (e.g. Brunner, H./Klose, J./Siegert, P./Lehmann, H.: Dresden model. A project for the University of Applied Sciences distance learning. - Moran, J.: Educating civil engineers on the World Wide Web. - Sommer, K.-H.: Distance learning and distance education: Emergency aid or optimal teaching/learning form?). - MAN AND TECHNOLOGY (e.g. Duchna, O./Rückert, M.: New approaches to technology impact and potential assessment. - Luck, W.: Responsibility and ethos of natural scientists and engineers. - Rinneberg, C.: Understanding prosperity anew - a challenge to the self-image of engineering education). - CURRICULUM DEVELOPMENT IN THE ENGINEERING SCIENCES (e.g. Barsony, J.: Management courses in engineering education. - Crus ...

Gender Constructions in East and West: Biographical Perspectives ¤ In this book, the relationships between the constructs 'gender' and 'biography' are investigated from a theoretical and empirical perspective within the East-West theme. The approach of this volume is to undertake a long overdue paradigm shift and use the transformations that took place after 1989 to question not only East German and Eastern, but also West German and Western self-evidences to the same extent.

War and Politics 1618 - 1648 : European Problems and Perspectives ¤ War and Politics 1618-1648". European Problems and Perspectives. Ed. by Konrad Repgen in collaboration with Elisabeth Müller-Luckner. R. Oldenbourg Publishing House, Munich 1988. 454 p., bound, 98,- DM

Flight: Challenges for Social Work ¤ In this volume, new requirements in various fields of action are described and discussed, which fundamentally and inevitably arise in dealing with refugees: people with traumatic experiences need concrete help, unaccompanied minor refugees must be taken in by offers of child and youth welfare, racism, stigmatization, and discrimination must be addressed from a professional side. In addition to theoretical classifications of the refugee discourse, the contributions provide answers to current questions and develop practice-relevant access to the topic.
