The content • Theoretical classifications and critical perspectives • Social work practice questions The target groups • Students, lecturers, and researchers in education, pedagogy, and social work • Practitioners and practitioners in various fields of social work with refugees. The editors Johanna Bröse is a research assistant at the Institute for Education at the University of Tübingen. Dr. Stefan Faas is a professor at the Institute for Childhood, Youth, and Family at the PH Schwäbisch-Gmünd. Dr. Barbara Stauber is a professor at the Institute for Education at the University of Tübingen. Flight – Challenges for Social Work. - Theoretical classifications and critical perspectives: „Considering the Suffering of Others“. Flight, Solidarity, and Postcolonial Social Work -- Accepting Complexity – Reflecting Interconnections of Sexism and Racism Against a Hostile Consensus -- Refugees, National Welfare State, and the Tasks of Social Work -- Social Work in „Ordinary Nationalism“ Under National-State Premises -- Action Capability and Heteronomy – A Competence-Theoretical Perspective on Refugee-Related Education Discontinuities -- The Refugee – Crosser of Political Normality -- Social Work Practice Questions: Children and Families with a Refugee Background in Daycare Centers – Social Pedagogical Practice and Reflection in the Context of Knowledge, Non-Knowledge, and Pressure to Act -- Children, Young People, and Families with a Refugee Background – Starting Point and Potentials of Child and Youth Welfare -- Unaccompanied Minor Refugees – Challenge and Opportunity for Child and Youth Welfare -- School in the Context of Flight -- Therapy and Counseling in the Context of Flight and Trauma -- Now I'm Talking! – The TALK Project: Art and Empowerment Against Racism and Discrimination -- Migration and Labor Market -- Requirements for Humanitarian Aid for Refugees Today. Ambivalences, Dilemmas, Principles.

1945 - Defeat, Liberation, New Beginnings: Twelve European Countries after the End of the Nazi Regime ¤ The large-format, opulently illustrated catalog for the 2015 commemorative exhibition on the 70th anniversary of German capitulation at the German Historical Museum in Berlin provides information on the effects of the war and the upheaval in the post-war period in 12 European countries. Review: Large-format, with very well-printed, partly also colored images, opulently illustrated and attractively designed catalog for the large commemorative exhibition running until the end of October 2015 on the 70th anniversary of German capitulation at the German Historical Museum in Berlin. In short articles on 12 Western and Eastern European countries including the Soviet Union, young historians describe the destruction left by the war, how it affected politics and society, what changes brought the first post-war years, and how people coped with the upheaval. In addition, there are plenty of photos, maps, and detailed explanations of exhibition pieces. In the appendix, a brief selection of literature, grouped by country. No index, no chronology. Apart from the somewhat brief introduction as a reader-friendly overview, recommended alongside the internationally designed presentations by I. Buruma (2015) and K. Lowe (2014). For Germany, see e.g. Theo Sommer (2005). (2)

Bildverarbeitung für die Medizin 2006 : Algorithms Systems Applications Proceedings of the Workshop from March 19 – 21, 2006 in Hamburg ¤ Bildanalyse -- Segmentation -- Registration -- Visualization -- Navigation and Tracking -- Visible Light -- Simulation and Planning -- Endoscopy and minimally invasive Surgery -- Free Topics. In recent years, the workshop

Attraktivität durch internationale Kompatibilität : zur Zulassung ausländischer Studierender insbesondere zu Graduierten- und Promotionsstudien in Deutschland; Recommendation of the 179th Plenum of the German Rectors' Conference, Berlin, 9 July 1996 ¤ On the basis of past activities and an analysis of the current situation, recommendations are given for the improvement of the study of foreigners at German universities. It corresponds to the results of the HRK survey that less improvement is required in the basic study than in the main and in the advanced studies as well as in the introduction to the promotion. Therefore, this target group is at the center of the explanations. Table of Contents: II. Situation III. Causes IV. Target groups V. Goals of the compatible design of German study structures VI. Basic features of the Anglo-American study system in comparison to the German system VII. Consequences (1. Promotion studies 2. Graduate studies 3. Advanced and supplementary studies 4. Graduation degrees (Master) VIII. Recommendations. (HoF/ Text adopted/Ko.)
Ghettorents : Compensation Policy, Jurisprudence and Historical Research ¤ The German Bundestag unanimously passed the

Gottfried Kellers Moderne : Band 1, Kellers Erzählen : Structures – Functions – Reflections ¤ The collection, emerging from the 2019 Zurich Jubilee Congress, unlocks Keller's narrative work as a laboratory of transitory poetics. Keller not only reinterpreted literary genres like the legend but, with the bildungsroman and the novella, also shaped the forms that psychologically gauge the modern subject. These contributions explore Keller’s texts as evidence of a

Automated Driving 2021: From Assisted to Autonomous Driving 7th International ATZ-Conference ¤ Infrastructure -- Customer Experience -- Software/Development Processes -- Insurance Topics -- Law -- Development Performance -- Sensor Fusion -- Data-Driven Development. The content of the conference proceedings for the ATZlive event "Automated Driving" highlights the drivers of automated driving: Artificial Intelligence, Machine- or Deep-Learning. The interaction between artificial and human intelligence, as well as the ability of humans and machines to cooperate, must be designed and made usable for future mobility in new interaction levels. For this, it is necessary for society to accept this development. Against this background, methods, tools, and processes gain relevance, as do sensors and connectivity. The content: Infrastructure.- Customer Experience.- Software/Development Processes.- Insurance Topics.- Law.- Development Performance.- Sensor Fusion.- Data-Driven Development. The target groups are vehicle and engine engineers - function developers, software and IT engineers from industry and applied research and teaching - analysts, consulting companies, insurers - technicians and students seeking current expertise in connection with questions of their field of work - professors and lecturers at universities and colleges with a focus on automotive and engine technology The organizer ATZlive stands for top quality, high level of expertise in the field of information and is part of Springer Fachmedien Wiesbaden GmbH, a part of Springer Nature. Here, under one roof, the expertise of the most renowned economic, scientific, and technical publishers in Germany is united.

Dietrich Bonhoeffer and Hans Joachim Iwand – Critical Theologians in Service of the Church ¤ Contributions by Lüpke: Dr. Johannes von Lüpke is Professor of Systematic Theology at the Kirchliche Hochschule Wuppertal/Bethel. Contributions by Tietz: Dr. theol. Christiane Tietz is Professor of Systematic Theology at the Institute for Hermeneutics and Religious Philosophy at the University of Zurich and Chair of the German-speaking Section of the International Bonhoeffer Society. Hans Joachim Iwand (1899–1960) and Dietrich Bonhoeffer (1906–1945) are among the most significant evangelical theologians of the 20th century. Their life paths show interesting connections: Both engaged critically with the theology and (church-) politics of their time and committed themselves to the Confessing Church. The present collection of essays, which originated from a symposium held by the Hans Iwand Foundation in Dortmund in 2014, examines similarities and differences in biographical terms as well as in terms of theological themes that determined the life's work of Iwand and Bonhoeffer. This is not only a historical comparison of theology, but the goal is also to deepen the insight into the peculiarity of their theological thinking and to derive impulses from it that will challenge and help us theologically today. The topics treated include the commitment to peace, the understanding of mandates and orders, the preaching of the law, the concept of a right to resistance, the respective sin and reality understanding, the way of speaking about the 'mature world', the reception of Nietzsche, the connection between confession, forgiveness of sins, and the Eucharist, the importance of eschatology also in view of 'salvation for this world', the concept of theological ethics, and the respective church understanding. In a prospect, the authors discuss the question of what should be discussed with Bonhoeffer and Iwand in view of the current situation of church and theology. Contributions by Neddens: Dr. theol. Christian Johannes Neddens is pastor of the Independent Evangelical-Lutheran Church in Brunsbrock and Stellenfelde as well as youth pastor and emergency chaplain. Contributions by den Hertog: Dr. Gerard den Hertog is Professor of Systematic Theology at the Theologische Universiteit Apeldoorn.

Between Enlightenment, Policey and Administration: On the Genesis of the Medical System 1750-1850 ¤ The emergence of the medical system in Germany is characterized by several profound changes of the late absolutist territorial state. Tendencies towards centralization and regulation are evident in the field of medicine and public health of the population in the 18th century. The progressive processes in the shaping of the medical system cannot be located solely in the field of medicine, nor in that of administration or police, but are - as moments of a far-reaching political and social transformation - a mixture of different discursive strands, administrative practices, and government techniques. The eleven contributions of the volume deal with three focal points: 1. Medical police as an interdiscourse between police, enlightenment, and medicine 2. The development of medical competence, the control of healing persons, and the exclusion of unauthorized healers 3. Care and self-care

Monuments of Concrete : Bunkers in Cities and Landscapes ¤ To be found in Europe. Again and again, there have been attempts to demolish these often monumental buildings, to give them a new use or to preserve them as memorials and museums. However, the question of how to deal appropriately with these memorial sites is still leading to controversial discussions, as the bunkers' ruins, left behind by the Third Reich, are indeed part of the most difficult heritage of German history. - - In the present volume, which owes its origin to an international conference, organized by the University of Oldenburg in cooperation with the Johannes a Lasso Library in Emden, art historians, architects, exhibition makers, and artists approach the complex topic from completely different perspectives. They address the question of where the increasing interest in these concrete giants comes from, what makes them fascinating, and how they can be used appropriately. This is exemplified by treating bunker facilities, among others, in Frankfurt/M., Emden, Kiel, Braunschweig, Bug/Rügen, Schweinfurt, and Berlin as well as Vienna and London

Education Mobility: Studies on the Individualization of Working-Class Daughters in Modernity ¤ The contributions deal with mobility processes of women, exclusively those of working-class daughters, against the backdrop of individualization and modernization processes. Their mobility is often prompted by school as an instance of individualization, where ... the social origin culture often experiences a contradiction to the requirements of higher school with its demands for education, intellectuality, and theoretical ability. Therefore, socialization and education processes must be reflected both in connection with reproduction and with the change of social structure. The individual essays deal with the following topics: 1) A historical consideration of education processes of proletarian women. 2) A feminist engagement with the terminology of previous research when it speaks of 'working-class women'. 3) An attempt to describe the way of ascent as a way with processes of alienation and re-appropriation using a deep hermeneutic analysis of fairy tales. 4) A description of the connection between gender-specific socialization, education ascent, and gender identity. 5) A comparison of the biographies of two working-class daughters studying. 6) A study on the connection between study subject, gender, and social origin, using the example of distance students. 7) A comparison of the study behavior of working-class and academic daughters. 8) Interview material for the comparison of the study situation of working-class sons and daughters at a university.

Does the City Make You Sick? : On Dealing with Health and Illness ; [Public Lectures and Workshop Discussions at the University of Hamburg ..., Organized by the Hamburg Working Group for Regional History in October 1992] ¤ Over twenty contributions by architects, natural and social scientists, historians, and physicians illuminate a broad spectrum of problems of urban life and attempts to cope with them in the past and present. This includes, for example, the investigation of health hazards caused by traffic and industrial waste, reports on the noise and smoke plague in the 19th and 20th centuries, urban health care and attempts at ecological renewal of urban quarters, as well as psychological aspects of urban lifestyle, communication conditions, aging, and death in the city.

Between Inner Emigration and Exile: German-Speaking Writers 1933-1945 ¤ This volume seeks to unite two traditionally divided research areas, "exile literature" and "inner emigration," and to interrelate the divergent experiences of writers who were exiled and writers who remained in Germany. It discusses the potentially resistant nature of German literature both inside and outside the German Reich and examines the relevance of the terms "inner" and "outer" emigration.

Luginsland. Architecture with a View : [Exhibition] ¤ The building type of 'view architecture' emerged in the course of tourist developments in the 19th century and has increasingly gained attractiveness. On the one hand, view buildings are created that - having wandered into the cities - serve as visitor platforms for curiosity and location marketing; on the other hand, projects have gained a new meaning in the context of ecological interest, where the goal is the ascent and the view into the habitats of the forest, a goal that is also followed by the 'tree top trails'. The richly illustrated publication with photos, models, and plans sketches a panorama of architectural interventions from the last fifteen years. Topics such as architecture and landscape, ecology and habitat, or the history of seeing and looking out are dealt with just as much as the interplay between architecture and art or architecture and engineering. The criterion for the selection of towers, platforms, and small architecture was less their size and prominence than their architectural quality

Revolution and Counter-Revolution in European Image Publishing 1789 - 1889 ¤ This systematically compiled volume opens up - below 'high art' - an international image culture that has so far received little attention from specialists and art historians. All contributions focus on the particularly rich iconographic production of the 'Century of Revolutions' (ca. 1770-1871). From portrait and fashion prints to political allegories and caricatures, and from geographical maps to popular picture books, practically all print-based image genres of this extended 'threshold period' (Reinhart Koselleck) are examined in detail with regard to their own production and reception conditions, their potential for memory, and their European networking. The volume makes a fundamental contribution to an emerging interdisciplinary historical image science.

Anatomy of Exclusion : Theory and Practice of Critical Social Work ¤ In excerpts, the book shows current developments in the theory and practice of social work, by tracing the historical conditions of social work and making clear the complex relationships in which subjects are to be located. It becomes apparent that the changes that began in the 1970s and have continued to this day in the structure and content of social work are primarily neoliberal adjustments. As a consequence of this transformation, both the situation of clients and the situation of social work itself become increasingly precarious. Possibilities are shown for how professionals can build structures of counter-hegemonic critical practice for themselves and for the users of social work. The content • Institutional organization of poverty • The anatomy of society • Psychosocial destruction of the subject in neoliberalism • Perspectives of a critical practice of social work The target groups • Researchers in the research contexts of social work and social affairs • Students and lecturers in the departments of social work / social pedagogy • Professionals in social work and social pedagogy The authors Dr. Ingo Zimmermann is Professor of Social Work at the Catholic University of North Rhine-Westphalia, Münster. Jens Rüter is a research assistant in the field of network work / network research at the Catholic University of North Rhine-Westphalia, Münster. Dr. Burkhard Wiebel is an external employee at the Institute for Cognitive Neuroscience at the Ruhr University Bochum. Alisha Pilenko is a psychotherapist in private practice in Bochum. Dr. Frank Bettinger is Professor of Social Pedagogy at the Evangelical University of Darmstadt and Chairman of the Bremen Institute for Social Work + Development (BISA+E) at the University of Bremen. Institutional organization of poverty: Historical difference lines between care and social technology -- The anatomy of society -- Pathologies of society -- Psychosocial destruction of the subject in neoliberalism -- Perspectives of a critical practice of social work.

Überschuldung: Quo vadis? ¤ The discussion on the insolvency statute is rekindled due to the upcoming implementation of the directive on the preventive restructuring framework. On the occasion of this, the Heidelberg non-profit society for corporate restructuring GmbH hosted a workshop on the topic „Überschuldung: Quo vadis?“ together with the chair for insolvency law at Heidelberg University on October 1, 2019. This volume summarizes the essential results of the workshop and contains the written presentations of the speakers from science and practice. Special emphasis was placed on the workshop on the consideration of insolvency from the perspectives of the parties significantly involved in the insolvency proceedings as well as on the effects of the introduction of the preventive restructuring framework on the German insolvency concept. With contributions from Christopher Seagon, Andreas Piekenbrock, Christoph G. Paulus, Tammo Andersch, Helmut Balthasar, Frank Girotto, Wolfgang Herrmann, Helmut Zipperer, Ralf Zuleger, Thomas Harbrecht, Andrey Wroblewski, Lucas Flöther, Michael Pluta, Moritz Brinkmann, Yannic Arnold, Simone Slawik and Werner F. Ebke.

The \ ¤ After over a decade of relative stability, recent years have seen new momentum in EU budget politics. The Treaty of Lisbon introduced the broadest reform of budgetary procedures since the 1970s, while the financial and economic crisis has intensified scepticism towards European integration among citizens and decision-makers. As a result, the EU budget has become more controversial, more flexible and more fragmented. This volume brings together contributions from scholars and practitioners that address empirical and theoretical questions surrounding the new politics of the EU budget.With contributions by:Michael W. Bauer, Peter Becker, Stefan Becker, Gabriele Cipriani, Manuele Citi, Alessandro D'Alfsono, Alfredo De Feo, Magdalena Sapala, Linn Selle, Anne Vitrey, Uwe Wagschal, Georg Wenzelburger

Driver Assistance Systems 2017: From Assistance to Automated Driving - 3rd International ATZ Conference on Automated Driving ¤ The content focus of the conference proceedings for the ATZlive event Driver Assistance Systems 2017 lies among other things on new developments for automated driving. In connection with the electrification and networking of vehicles, new electrical/electronic architectures and flexible software platforms are emerging. Other topics include, for example, new driver assistance systems for premium passenger cars, brake and lane-change assistants for trucks, and high-resolution digital street maps. The content includes: Markets and users. Development themes. Research and practice. Series application. Simulation and testing. Vehicle dynamics. Software, IT, and security. The target groups are vehicle and engine engineers as well as students seeking current expertise in connection with questions of their field of work - professors and lecturers at universities and colleges with a focus on automotive and engine technology - experts, researchers, and development engineers in the automotive and supplier industry The organizer ATZlive stands for top quality, high level of expertise in the field of specialized information and is part of Springer Fachmedien Wiesbaden GmbH. It brings together under one roof the expertise of the most renowned economic, scientific, and technical publishers in Germany. Markets and users -- Development themes -- Research and practice -- Series application -- Simulation and testing -- Vehicle dynamics -- Software, IT, and security.

Werner Herzog ¤ Werner Herzog is a cult figure: Few other directors have inspired as many parodies on the internet. Herzog is controversial: Opinions about the man and his work often diverge widely. This book about one of the most influential directors of our time lets him speak for himself. With a 'Werner Herzog ABC', numerous unpublished images from the Herzog archive, a greeting from Oscar winner Chloé Zhao, and exclusive comic illustrations by Reinhard Kleist.

Believe against each other - research together? : Paradigm shift in early modern science cultures ¤ Den inhaltlich-thematischen Ausgangspunkt des Bandes bildet das sich verändernde Verhältnis von frühneuzeitlicher Astronomie und Physik zur christlichen Religion im Allgemeinen und zu ihren konfessionsspezifischen Ausprägungen im Besonderen. Vor diesem Hintergrund nehmen die versammelten Beiträge exemplarisch die entsprechenden, mit dem Wandel des Weltbildes verbundenen Prozesse anhand des zur Transkonfessionalität tendierenden Paradigmenwechsels in den frühneuzeitlichen Wissenschaftskulturen in den Blick. Dabei bieten die Welt, deren Bilder einen Wandel durchliefen, die Naturwissenschaften, die den Wandel vorantrieben, und die Theologien, die sich von einstigen Gewissheiten über Gott und Welt verabschiedeten, sich neu konstituierten und das Leben sowie die Naturforschung in der Frühen Neuzeit entscheidend mitbestimmten, eine dankbare Fläche für eine interkonfessionell vergleichende Untersuchung konfessioneller Spezifika.

Regional Labor Markets and Labor Market Policy in the New Federal States ¤ Content: 1. Technological Innovation and Regional Structural Change (Lange, Dieter) 2. Companies as Drivers of Employment (Storz, Peter - Valerius, Gabriele - Slawinski, Ursula - Muetze, Klaus - Weisshuhn, Peter) 3. Wissenschaftstheorie in Ökonomie und Wirtschaftsinformatik : Theoriebildung und -bewertung, Ontologien, Wissensmanagement ¤ In recent years, interest in scientific theory in business administration has increased significantly. In business informatics, scientific theoretical questions are also being discussed more intensively. This is partly due to changing conditions for scientific careers, the structural change of universities, and the increasing internationalization of research and teaching. The present volume, which is based on the results of the 2003 Annual Conference of the Scientific Commission for Scientific Theory in the Association of University Professors of Business Administration, provides a comprehensive overview of current topics in scientific theory in economics and business informatics. Some contributions relate to traditional questions of scientific theory, while others address scientific theoretical challenges related to current research topics. The focus is on:

Heiligkeiten : Constructions, Functions, and Transfer of Sanctity Concepts in Early and High Medieval Europe ¤ What functions did sanctities, saints, and hagiographies have in early and high medieval Europe? How were they constructed and how did the spatial transfer of sanctity concepts succeed? The authors of this volume examine the diversity of sanctities and the underlying conceptions. Through an analysis of narrative design strategies and the used representation media, they show how justification and argumentation strategies differ for different types of saints. The investigation includes both usage contexts as well as involved persons and groups and their interest in the functionalization of saint veneration and hagiographies. This approach enables the understanding of the formation of medieval discourse communities around saints and sanctities and the use of hagiographic texts in social, religious, societal, and religious-political questions. A special emphasis is placed on the conditions and evaluations of spatial transfer processes. In this way, the dynamics that sanctities unfolded in early and high medieval Europe become clear.

Blurred Boundaries between Journalism, Public Relations, Advertising, and Marketing: Current Findings from Theory and Practice ¤ The book analyzes the separation between editorial reporting and PR products, marketing, and advertising, which is generally required and is enshrined in legal regulations under the heading of the

Proceedings of the fifth HPI Cloud Symposium "Operating the Cloud" 2017 ¤ Version control is a widely used practice among software developers. It reduces the risk of changing their software and allows them to manage different configurations and to collaborate with others more efficiently. This is amplified by code sharing platforms such as GitHub or Bitbucket. Most version control systems track files (e.g., Git, Mercurial, and Subversion do), but some programming environments do not operate on files, but on objects instead (many Smalltalk implementations do). Users of such environments want to use version control for their objects anyway. Specialized version control systems, such as the ones available for Smalltalk systems (e.g., ENVY/Developer and Monticello), focus on a small subset of objects that can be versioned. Most of these systems concentrate on the tracking of methods, classes, and configurations of these. Other user-defined and user-built objects are either not eligible for version control at all, tracking them involves complicated workarounds, or a fixed, domain-unspecific serialization format is used that does not equally suit all kinds of objects. Moreover, these version control systems that are specific to a programming environment require their own code sharing platforms; popular, well-established platforms for file-based version control systems cannot be used or adapter solutions need to be implemented and maintained. To improve the situation for version control of arbitrary objects, a framework for tracking, converting, and storing of objects is presented in this report. It allows editions of objects to be stored in an exchangeable, existing backend version control system. The platforms of the backend version control system can thus be reused. Users and objects have control over how objects are captured for the purpose of version control. Domain-specific requirements can be implemented. The storage format (i.e. the file format, when file-based backend version control systems are used) can also vary from one object to another. Different editions of objects can be compared and sets of changes can be applied to graphs of objects. A generic way for capturing and restoring that supports most kinds of objects is described. It models each object as a collection of slots. Thus, users can begin to track their objects without first having to implement version control supplements for their own kinds of objects. The proposed architecture is evaluated using a prototype implementation that can be used to track objects in Squeak/Smalltalk with Git. The prototype improves the suboptimal standing of user objects with respect to version control described above and also simplifies some version control tasks for classes and methods as well. It also raises new problems, which are discussed in this report as well.

Continuing professional development - preparing for new roles in libraries : a voyage of discovery; Sixth World Conference on Continuing Professional Development and Workplace Learning for the Library and Information Professions; [10th - 13th August 2005, Oslo, Norway] ¤ Review text: "The book [...] documents the diversity of questions and solutions of Continuing Professional Development (CPD) activities in the respective countries and presents from a German perspective, as named in the subtitle, a voyage of discovery."Thomas Hapke in: Auskunft Nr. 27, 2/2007 Librarians and information workers the world over are faced with the constant challenge of remaining abreast of developments in their field. Rapid changes in technology and workplace roles threaten to make their skills obsolete unless they undertake constant professional development. This international collection presents a comprehensive overview of current continuing professional development theory and practice for those who manage and work in library and information services. Papers by academics and practitioners describe numerous innovative responses to emerging continuing education and training needs, including workplace learning; individual learning and learning organisations.

Animals - Pedagogical-Anthropological Reflections ¤ The book deals with the complex human-animal relationships and inquires about the role of animals in pedagogical-anthropological thinking. In the reflections, which also consider art-theoretical discourses, constructions are analyzed and located in pedagogical contexts. The content Human-animal relationships The animal as a construction in pedagogy The animal as a medium Animal-becoming/human-becoming in art and education The target groups Students and lecturers of pedagogy and anthropology as well as of social, art, and cultural sciences. The editors Dr. Johannes Bilstein is a professor at the Düsseldorf Academy of Arts. Dr. Kristin Westphal is a professor at the University of Koblenz-Landau.

Limits of Transgression : Controversies around Transculture, Transgender, and Transspecies ¤ Transgender, transculture, transnationality - concepts of trans are experiencing a political and scientific boom. In them, the demand for an opening of sociocultural identities is being made. However, the fluid boundaries of national, social, and bodily spaces are threatening to solidify again in traditions and neoracisms: So, values of the bourgeois small family as well as right-wing populist positions are not only repeatedly discussed, but reproduced in various media and social channels. The contributions of the volume therefore ask: Through which processes do trans concepts essentialize - and at which normative boundaries do they break?

Emissions from agricultural soils : KTBL/vTI conference from 8 to 10 December 2010 at the Bildungszentrum Kloster Banz in Bad Staffelstein ¤ The reduction of emissions is an important goal for air purification and the mitigation of climate change. While emissions from animal husbandry are already relatively well quantifiable, the height of emissions from soils is still afflicted with greater uncertainties. In particular, it is not clarified to what extent, in addition to direct emissions at the site, indirect emissions through the excretion of nitrate and resulting hydrogen sulfide formations at other sites are to be taken into account. The conference contributions provide information on nitrous oxide, ammonia, carbon dioxide, and methane emissions, as well as nitrogen oxides and volatile organic compounds. The state of knowledge, strategies, and practical solutions for reducing emissions, as well as findings on the fundamental emission-influencing factors, are presented (Source: KTBL).

Luxury and Decadence : Roman Life at the Gulf of Naples ; [Exhibitions at the LWL-Römisch-Germanic Museum in Haltern am See, 16.08.2007 - 25.11.2007,  Focke-Museum Bremen, 15.12.2007 - 08.06.2008, Museum Het Valkhof Nijmwegen, 23.08.2008 - 04.01.2009, Archäologische Staatssammlung München, 06.02.2009 - 30.08.2009] ¤ Luxury and Decadence are terms that immediately bring to mind an elevated Roman way of life. Excess, love of pomp, and hedonism of the Roman upper class can be shown nowhere more impressively than in the submerged cities and villas at the Gulf of Naples. The accompanying book to the exhibition sketches a multifaceted picture of the luxurious life of the Romans at the Gulf of Naples between extravagance and decadence Luxury and Decadence are terms that immediately bring to mind an elevated Roman way of life. Excess, love of pomp, and hedonism of the Roman upper class can be shown nowhere more impressively than in the submerged cities and villas at the Gulf of Naples. The accompanying book to the exhibition sketches a multifaceted picture of the luxurious life of the Romans at the Gulf of Naples between extravagance and decadence.

German and Soviet Societies in the First Post-War Decade : Traumas and Hopes ¤ This 9th bilingual volume of the Joint Research Committee on the Contemporary History of German-Russian Relations documents the 2016 colloquium “German and Soviet Societies in the First Post-War Decade: Traumas and Hopes.” In the second part, young historians from Russia and Germany present “New Perspectives on German-Russian Relations and Historical Interconnections in the 19th and 20th Centuries in a Global Context.”

Jewish History in Thuringia : Structures and Developments from the Middle Ages to the 20th Century ¤ In the last three decades, the research on the Jewish history of Thuringia has experienced a great surge. The volume provides an insight into the development of Jewish life in the region from the Middle Ages to the 20th century. The contributions deal with, among other things, the heyday of Jewish life in Thuringia in the Middle Ages, the development of rural Judaism in the Early Modern Period and the role of court Jews in the numerous Thuringian residences, the struggle for legal emancipation in the 19th century, the persecution and extermination during the time of the Third Reich and the new beginning of Jewish life in Thuringia after 1945. Based on selected thematic fields, the volume provides both a balance of previous research and an insight into current projects and a prospect on future research perspectives

Canon, Evaluation and Mediation: Literature in the Knowledge Society ¤ The present collection of essays deals with the theory and practice of literature mediation in the 'post-bourgeois' knowledge society and considers various aspects: It examines how 'extra-literary' factors such as power and economy steer the evaluation and canonization of contemporary literary works, what effect medial conditions, e.g. Web 2.0, can be attributed to, and how internal literary factors affect evaluation processes. In the first part, models and methodological basic questions of the evaluation and canon discussion are presented, while the second part examines canonization processes in institutions of the literary business. The question of what role evaluation actions and the concept of the canon play in current literature mediation is dealt with in the third part. The book is addressed to all those who deal with questions of canon formation, evaluation, and literature mediation in the literary business and literary science. The book presents the results of a conference held in the spring of 2010 by members of the Promotionskolleg 'Evaluation and Canon. Theory and Practice of Literature Mediation in the 'post-bourgeois' Knowledge Society', which aimed to track down the changed global societal conditions in terms of dealing with literature in a narrower and broader sense. The entirety of the contributions has an essayistic-exemplary character, which impressively shows – whether intended or not – that the common denominator of the underlying 'post-bourgeois' knowledge society has grown so large that one can hardly notice the commonalities anymore. This is also an observation of those who regularly deal with collections like the present one: The trend of conferences and their written results clearly shows in all directions – diversification is the magic word of the present (literaturkritik.de)

Prepositions in Polish : Contributions to a conference of the same name, Oldenburg, 8 to 11 February 2000 ¤ Linguists from Poland, France, Switzerland, Sweden, and Germany presented various aspects of prepositions in Polish as well as the general discussion on prepositions

Strangers in the City : Orders, Representations and Social Practices ; (13th - 15th century) ¤ Blurb: Whether pilgrims, Jews, merchants, Saracens or slaves: strangers play a significant role in the medieval city. This is reflected in order designs on normative, everyday practical and artistic levels, which are inspired and changed by strangers. With relational perception and the various attributions of difference, specific relationships of inclusion and exclusion are connected within urban society. Accordingly, the status and function of strangers change from political and economic partners or cultural and knowledge bearers to internal and external enemies. The range of their representations extends from the privileged personality to the dominated object. The volume analyzes these fields of tension interdisciplinarily with a focus on Italian cities between 1200 and 1500.

New from Building Technology, Building Law and Building Management : 11th Deggendorf Building Symposium at the Deggendorf University of Applied Sciences on March 12, 2010 ; an event of the Faculty of Civil Engineering at the Deggendorf University of Applied Sciences ... ¤ Contains, inter alia: "Treaded with feet" - Requirements for pavement surfaces / Hans Jörg Wagmann. Building diagnostics / Gernot Henrich

Climate Change and Coast: A Glimpse into the Greenhouse ; with 9 Tables ; [Workshop, Wilhelmshaven, 30.09./01.10.1991] ¤ A current status report, which shows the connections of the global change at the example of the southern North and Baltic Sea.

Exclusion in the Market Society ¤ The book analyzes the exclusion processes of the present. In addition to the theoretical and conceptual classification, concrete empirical works on excluding social processes are also shown. The book analyzes the exclusion processes of the present. In addition to the theoretical and conceptual classification, concrete empirical works on excluding social processes are also shown

Myths of the Nations: A European Panorama ¤ Blurb: Peoples and nations draw upon historical events to reassure themselves of their origins and identity. This is particularly evident in 19th-century Europe, as a result of the French Revolution and the Napoleonic Wars, which created a need for historical legitimation in the still young European nations. In part, long-past events are brought into the national memory, especially in paintings and graphics. They often acquire mythic dimensions in the process. For the first time, this book brings together, in a 17-country European comparison, historically significant events depicted in 19th-century representations.

Video : Playback, Editing and Streaming under Linux ¤ This official collection of papers on a focus topic at the LinuxTag 2005 describes in more than 15 contributions the various aspects of video technology under Linux. After presenting various players, it deals with aspects of coding as well as various application scenarios (digital video recorder, streaming in building automation etc.). A compendium on the 'State of the Art' by high-profile international authors

Sharing knowledge: scientific communication : 9th Congress of the IUK-Initiative of Scientific Professional Societies in Germany ¤ Ziele des erstmals von der Initiative Information und Kommunikation wissenschaftlicher Fachgesellschaften (IuK) zu ihrer Frühjahrstagung herausgegebenen referierten Tagungsbandes sind intensiver Diskurs über internetgestützte Techniken in der Kommunikation wissenschaftlicher Gruppen und Gemeinschaften sowie Momentaufnahme der Entwicklung digitaler Bibliotheken in der Bundesrepublik. Der Tagungsband vertieft die Webproceedings, die Dokumentationen aller Vorträge enthalten und unter http://www.iwi-iuk.org/iuk2003/ zugänglich sind

Living at work : [Trendbook Life and Work in the Future] ¤ We live in a time of transition, in a time of change from the industrial to the knowledge and service society. "Living at work" shows how our life in and with work is changing: Companies are reorganizing completely, their culture is determined by respect and responsibility, customers and suppliers are growing together more and more. A fascinating look into the world in which we will live tomorrow! With contributions from: - Ulrich Beck - Klaus Doppler - Matthias Horx - Werner Tiki Küstenmacher - Reinhard Sprenger and many others

The "@Nature of Man" in Neuroscience and Neuroethics : [Conference, which was held from October 20 - 21, 2006 in Freiburg ...] ¤ J. Clausen / O. Müller / G. Maio: Introduction: The "Nature of Man" in Neuroscience and Neuroethics F.-J. Bormann: The Nature of Man as a Basis for Morality? On the Relevance of the Concept of Nature for Bio- and Neuroethics Brain-Machine Interfaces A. Aertsen: Brain Machine-Interfacing through Implantable Electrodes in Humans T. Stieglitz: Neuroprostheses as Interfaces to the Peripheral and Central Nervous System: Prospects and Outlooks from the Perspective of Biomedical Technology J. Clausen: Brain-Computer Interfaces: Ethical-Anthropological Aspects of Neuroprosthetics Gernot Böhme: Duties to Oneself: On the Ethics of Bodily Existence in the Technological Civilization Clinical Questions A. Schulze-Bonhage: Decision Conflicts in Preoperative Diagnosis and Epilepsy Surgery G. Nikkhah: Empiricism and Science of Functional Neurosurgery: Chances, Risks, and Limits of Modern Biotechnology in the Operating Room K. Crone: Personal Identity as Orientation in Interventions in the Human Brain Optimizing Brain Functions M. Berger / C. Normann : Possibilities of Pharmacological Neuroenhancement J. S. Ach: Nanotechnology as Neuroenhancement: Possibilities, Visions, and Ethical-Anthropological Aspects W. Lesch: Memory Enhancement as Brain Doping? Orientation between Naturalness and Artificiality O. Müller: What Orientation Does the "Nature of Man" Provide in Borderline Questions of Neuroenhancement?

Integration of Water Framework Directive and Nature Conservation - Balance of Implementation, Conflict Potentials and Solution Approaches ¤ What is necessary for an effective implementation of the EU Water Framework Directive (WFD) and how can an increase in public acceptance be achieved? It increasingly shows that a coordinated and coordinated implementation of WFD and nature conservation measures, in particular from Natura 2000, are indispensable. The present volume of the NNA reports again a representative part of the contributions of the specialist conference "Water Framework Directive and Nature Conservation".(Source: Alfred Toepfer Academy for Nature Conservation / Internet).

Frederick Kiesler : function follows vision, vision follows reality ¤ The present collection of rare and partly unpublished texts by Friedrich Kiesler from 1925 to 1957 appears on the occasion of the exhibition "Function Follow Vision, Vision Follow Reality" curated by Luca Lo Pinto and Vanessa Joan Müller at the Kunsthalle Wien (May 27 - August 23, 2015). The exhibition, conceived jointly with the Austrian Friedrich and Lilian Kiesler Private Foundation, focuses on Kiesler's ideas on display and presents selected drawings by him in relation to contemporary art. The book contains exhibition views of the exhibition.

Im goldenen Schnitt : Niedersachsens longest excavation ; [in occasion of the special exhibition "Im goldenen Schnitt - Niedersachsens longest excavation" at the Lower Saxony State Museum in Hanover, August 23, 2013 to March 2, 2014] ¤ The Lower Saxony State Museum in Hanover presents the largest archaeological project in Lower Saxony: the excavations on the route of the North European Gas Pipeline (NEL). On the approximately 200 km long section through Lower Saxony, more than 150 largely unknown settlements and burial grounds have been discovered - a literally >>golden cut<< through around 11,000 years of history. The exhibition and the present volume explain how modern archaeology works, which technical tools and analysis procedures are used in the field and in the laboratory today, and they offer an exclusive look at the first finds and results of the research. The exhibition and the catalog present, inter alia, the Gessel treasure, one of the largest Bronze Age gold treasures ever found in Europe. - (Publisher's announcement)

Digital Romance Linguistics: Status and Perspectives ¤ The role of computer science in the humanities, including philology, is increasingly gaining weight. For Romance linguistics, this results in far-reaching changes and new perspectives, especially in methodological terms. The description of central aspects of these processes is the focus of the present volume, which brings together the contributions of the 34th Romance Colloquium. The thematic spectrum includes theoretical and methodological questions as well as the presentation and discussion of ongoing digital-based research projects from Old Romance to Contemporary Spanish.

Hear - Read - Speak : [Conference 6th...9th October 2005...Heidelberg] ¤ Hear -- Read -- Speak: These are basic competences of communication. The contributions of the book analyze these basic competences throughout the entire spectrum of speech science and speech education: from current research results to concrete suggestions for teaching. The contributions to hearing deal with, among other things, audiobooks, listening and not listening in conversations and the meaningfulness of perception. Reading is illuminated as "restoration of speech" under the aspects of reading instruction, reading competence and signification under the aspects of reading instruction, reading competence and signification. Speaking is represented by several articles on the voice, orthoepy and speech expression.

Where is the Tariff System Heading? ¤ A sober stocktaking of the current trends in tariff policy development: Trade unions in low-wage sectors and their efforts to end tariff-free conditions and to curb tariff erosion A sober stocktaking of the current trends in tariff policy development: Trade unions in low-wage sectors and their efforts to end tariff-free conditions and to curb tariff erosion.

Books, Publishers, Media ¤ For the first time, the book is made the medium of the thematic focus of the yearbook. For those exiled after 1933, it was not only an instrument of political enlightenment, but above all also a weapon in the anti-fascist struggle. The symbolic act of book burning by the National Socialists in May 1933 was immediately taken up by >other Germany< and strategically turned into an expression of cultural barbarism against National Socialism: The founding of the German Freedom Library in Paris in May 1934 exemplifies the claim of exile to preserve the humanistic tradition. The founding of book publishers and magazines symbolized a politically and literarily wide-ranging counter-publicity, and they created the conditions for the emergence of an exile literature, which, in terms of scope and rank, represents a singular phenomenon in world history. The contributions of the volume focus on the symbolic dimension of the book as well as the political function of magazines, achievements and working methods of the exile press, structures of the book trade, the reception of exile literature on the American book market, as well as the role of literary agents, not least the effects of the NS book theft and the publisher's continuation of the political exile after 1945

The Hamburg Beguines at St. Jacobi in Context of their Manuscripts and Culture ¤ BEGIN: From the Beguine convent at St. Jacobi in Hamburg, 14 Middle Low German manuscripts have been preserved, which provide a unique insight into the religious life of medieval women. The prayer books, together with archival materials from the convent such as the account books of the mistresses or wills, indicate an active role of the convent in late medieval Hamburg. From a religious profile perspective, the Hamburg prayer books in particular show cross-order influences of the Devotio moderna. This shows that this literature must be read in a geographically and religiously broader context. Already just liturgical and material similarities to traditions of North German dioceses and monasteries, e.g. monasteries in the Lüneburg Heath, illustrate how complex the networking of religious institutions was in the Late Middle Ages. Materially, the Hamburg codices lead into the hitherto little-known book culture of semi-religious women. END

Location Determination Political Education: Societal-Political Challenges, Civil Society and the Alleged Neutrality Requirement ¤ Where does Political Education stand? The volume takes a location determination of political education into account, considering societal-political challenges such as group-related hostility towards people, climate change, and didactic challenges such as the question of normativity as well as the alleged neutrality requirement of political education.

The Moving Image : Film and Art ¤ That the moving images of film can be considered from aesthetic and pictorial-theoretical perspectives may hardly surprise. It is all the more astonishing that art history has so far presented no comprehensive and systematic exploration of film. The authors' goal is therefore to demonstrate the sophisticated methodological and theoretical competence of art history as an image science, in order to present the exceptionally exciting range of their different approaches. Films by Antonioni, Lynch, Tarkovsky, and Renoir serve as the starting material for art-historical considerations of film history, film practices, and the socio-institutional and media-technical framework conditions of the cinematic apparatus.

On the Way to the Global University - International Marketing for Tomorrow : Proceedings of the 5th GATE-Germany Marketing Congress on July 7 and 8, 2011 at the Science Center Berlin ¤ The proceedings document the conference contributions of the 5th Marketing Congress of GATE-Germany, which took place in Bonn in July 2011. The focus was on the recruitment of students and scientists in international markets, instruments and basics of university marketing as well as the role of new media for the acquisition of university professionals and students. University representatives, international marketing experts and heads of the worldwide DAAD offices exchanged measures to convince international scientists and students of German teaching and research offers and discussed the role of university marketing in solving the shortage of skilled workers. Angela Borgwardt works as a freelance journalist, editor and moderator for various foundations and publishers with a focus on power analysis and conflict research, education and university policy as well as the consequences of social change.

Violence and Nonviolence in the Old Testament ¤ Violence as a theme in Old Testament research / Norbert Lohfink -- The layers of the Pentateuch and war / Norbert Lohfink -- Laments in Israel and Babylon : various interpretations of violence / Lothar Ruppert -- The message of the Servant of God : a way to overcome violence / Ernst Haag -- Impressions of a meeting / Raymund Schwager.

Systems for financing newly emerging private enterprises in transition economies : [Workshop on Financing Newly Emerging Private in Transition Economies in Paris on 29 - 30 January 1996] ¤ Ende Januar 1996 fand in Paris ein Treffen mehrerer Delegationen osteuropäischer Staaten statt. Im Mittelpunkt der Diskussion stand das Problem der Finanzierung neugegründeter Privatunternehmen. Die einzelnen Teilnehmer stellten ihre Lösungen vor und diskutierten mit Wirtschaftsexperten Westeuropas.

Visual Arguments: The Mysteries of Representation and the Computability of the World ¤ In the year 1610, King James I of England lamented that >nothing was left unexplored<, neither the >highest mysteries of God<, nor the >deepest mysteries that belong to the persons of kings and princes, who are gods on earth.< With these words, the monarch described the impending, fundamental shifts in the structure of power mediation. For the political systems of the time were based on state theories that had established themselves through the visual implementation in representation. It was the iconic quality of the image that formed the basis of the representation systems of the Early Modern period. Only these could represent the mysteries of power, as required, appropriately. To what extent this conception was stripped of legitimacy by the increasingly professionalized arts and sciences of the Early Modern period and what counter-strategies were developed, is shown by the volume from different perspectives. The contributions come from the disciplines of art history, cultural studies, and German studies and address the hitherto hardly discussed question of the discrepancy between the mysteries of power and the computability of the world. In this context, the image plays a central role as a site of conflict as well as a site of attempts at harmonization. Horst Bredekamp is an art historian and professor of art history at the Humboldt University of Berlin. Research focuses: Iconoclasm, Romanesque sculpture, Renaissance and Mannerist art, political iconography, art and technology, new media

Automobil-Sensorik 3 : Principles, Technologies, and Applications ¤ About the Book The sensorics takes on a significant and strongly growing importance in the automobile. In the wake of the rapid developments in the field of vehicle technology, such as automated driving and electromobility, more precise and robust sensor information is indispensable. These informations are used in complex control algorithms of vehicle electronics, especially for object recognition, system monitoring, drive control, stability, safety, and comfort enhancement. In addition to the optimization of established sensor principles, new and hybrid sensor concepts and technologies are increasingly gaining importance for the generation of this information. The resulting sensor systems are subject to high technical requirements and increasingly high demands in terms of costs, miniaturization, quality, and reliability. In this technical book, sensor principles and technologies are described that reflect the trend of current sensor developments for forward-looking vehicle application areas. The focus of this edition lies on sensor systems that are used in the areas of automated driving, electromobility, interior detection, and user recognition. Scenario-based validation of a hybrid radar model for testing and validation of automated driving functions -- Coreless magnetic current sensors for high-performance E-drives -- High-integrated current sensors for electric vehicles -- Model-based temperature monitoring of HV components in electric vehicles -- Approaches to optical state determination in lithium-ion batteries for use in electric vehicles -- Innovative H2 sensorics for fuel cell vehicles -- High-frequency sensorics for direct loading recognition of diesel particulate filters -- 3D sensorics based on a time-of-flight camera for contactless vehicle control -- Miniaturized 3D time-of-flight camera for interior monitoring and gesture control in the vehicle -- Intelligent contactless gesture sensors for future vehicle access systems -- Data fusion-based, thermodynamic sensor model for interior temperature measurement -- High-integrated motor position sensors for braking systems and electric drives -- Innovative 3D Hall sensors with intelligent energy management and stray field suppression -- Position detection using a sensor array of tunnel magnetoresistive vortex dots and learning signal processing.

Field of Future Education and Career Counseling: New Developments from Science and Practice ¤ 1. Wirkfaktor Gesellschaft 2. Fundament Theorie 3. Beratungsprozess und Wirkfaktoren 4. Ansätze, Instrumente und Modelle - from theory to practice 5. Manage knowledge and information 6. Develop quality 7. Live professionalism Marika Hammerer is an education, career, and vocational counselor, competence balance coach, supervisor (ÖVS), and trainer. Erika Kanelutti is a research assistant at the Austrian Institute for Vocational Education Research and co-founder of the field of education and career counseling is still little researched in the German-speaking area. The book is based on the specialist conference "Field of Future Education and Career Counseling. Practice meets research" from 2010. The contributions combine theoretically-scientific positions on concepts, contexts, and functions of education and career counseling with approaches, procedures, and instruments for counseling practice. The broad range of topics outlines the requirements that education and career counselors have to cope with - today and in the future.

Antisemitism after the Holocaust : Inventory and Forms of Appearance in German-speaking Countries ¤ Alphons Silbermann, Julius H. Schoeps (Editor): Antisemitism after the Holocaust. Inventory and Forms of Appearance in German-speaking Countries. Verlag Wissenschaft und Politik, Cologne 1986. 194 pages, 26 Marks

Architecture of Slovakia : Impulses and Reflections ; [on the occasion of the eponymous exhibition at the exhibition center of the Vienna Municipal Insurance Company AG in Vienna ; the exhibition is a co-production of the Vienna Municipal with the Slovak Association of Architects (SAS) ; exhibition duration: October 30, 2003 - February 29, 2004] ¤ *Further details Content: When recalling the geographical proximity of the capital cities Vienna and Bratislava, which are not even 50 kilometers or a short car ride apart, it becomes clear how little we know about this country. The catalog presents Slovak architecture in the 20th century, divided into 5 time periods. In addition to Bohuslav Fuchs, Vladimir Karfik, a long-time employee of Le Corbusier, or Bedrich Weinwurm, who have gained fame primarily through their work in Brno, it is necessary to present less well-known buildings in Bratislava and the interior of the country, such as the world-famous sanatoriums in the Tatra or the unique building situation in Pistian. Especially the first half of the past century was characterized by modernity, which worked here until 1948 due to the political circumstances. Due to the economic situation, the avant-garde was able to realize its ideas in an unprecedented density in the 1920s and 30s, which is why it is also called 'Bauhaus in the East' and emerged from the most committed art and architecture schools in Czech Republic and Slovakia. Author: Adolph Stiller Architect and architectural scientist, teaching and research activities in Geneva, Zurich, Paris, and Vienna, curator and designer of numerous architecture exhibitions and publications, various guest professorships, editor of the series 'Architecture in the Ringturm'

Reformation in Islam : Perspectives and Limits ¤ That Islam can only exist in the modern world, shaped by democracy, secularism, and progress, if it undergoes a reformation, is claimed by some and denied by others and is the subject of a debate that has been ongoing to this day and can be traced back at least to the early 20th century. This collection allows voices for and against a reformation in Islam to be heard and brings the debate into the light of current events and challenges, including the rise of Salafism. The content Introduction Reformation as a challenge Islam and Politics Reformation and the gender question Comparative perspectives The target groups Philosophers Theologians Social scientists Political and religious scientists Historians The editors Jörgen Erik Klußmann is a study leader at the Evangelical Academy in the Rhineland and part-time coach and trainer for sociocultural and religious sensitization as well as for systemic conflict transformation. Dr. Michael Kreutz is a political scientist and orientalist in Bochum with a focus on modern history of the Middle East and Southeast Europe, political history, Europe and Islam, religion and politics. Aladdin Sarhan is an Islamic scholar and expert in the State Protection Department of the Rhineland-Palatinate State Criminal Police Office. Introduction -- Reformation as a challenge -- Islam and Politics -- Reformation and the gender question -- Comparative perspectives

Lost Citizens? : Kurt Tucholsky and the Weltbühne Circle between Bourgeoisie and Workers' Movement : Documentation of the 2015 Annual Conference ¤ A 'lost citizen' – the Thomas Mann quote about the wannabe artist Tonio Kröger can be applied to most authors of the left-democratic weekly DIE WELTBÜHNE with slight modification. They were mostly of bourgeois origin, had studied – Carl von Ossietzky, the son of a petty bourgeois who grew up in poor conditions in Hamburg, was the exception that confirmed the rule. For this reason, also well-off writers from wealthy backgrounds, such as Kurt Tucholsky or Kurt Hiller, broke at least with their parents' houses and backgrounds in terms of political ideas, and like Ossietzky, sought an alliance with the industrial proletariat, which was separated from them by their way of life: a hope that soon shattered.

Growth Regions Beyond Metropolises: Opportunities, Potentials, and Strategies: Joint Event at the Congress for Location and Regional Management Euregia Bodensee in Friedrichshafen ¤ The new guiding images and action strategies for regional development in Germany address the changed spatial framework conditions, which have crystallized over the past few years against the backdrop of globalization and demographic change. A prominent position is taken by the guiding image

Societal Images in Transition: Sociological Perspectives in Germany ¤ The permanent interaction between society and sociology needs to be redefined. In light of the current cultural and technological changes and political transformations, the traditional arrangements of social integration and consensus-building at the end of the 20th century appear to be standing at the disposal. This not only necessitates the development of contemporary theoretical and analytical instruments, but also sketches the space for reflection, within which sociology develops at the beginning of the new century. Along the themes of theory and society, social inequality in the market society, and facets of civil society, the volume outlines the contours of a contemporary sociology and represents its analytical and diagnostic capabilities

Supporting Learning Processes with Digital Tools : Perspectives from the Didactics of Natural Science Subjects ¤ Publisher's information: Computers, interactive whiteboards, smartphones, or tablets offer new opportunities for teaching natural sciences. Students are experienced in handling technology – the best prerequisites for using it in class? Studies show that Germany is significantly behind other countries in using digital media or computers in school education. What is the reason for this? What additional value do digital tools offer in terms of subject didactics? What are the current discussions, experiences, and results from the subject didactics of natural sciences? The three editors Dr. Jenny Meßinger-Koppelt (Project Manager for Natural Sciences, Joachim Herz Foundation), Prof. Dr. Sascha Schanze (Institute for the Didactics of Natural Sciences, Leibniz University Hannover), and Prof. Dr. Jorge Groß (Didactics of Natural Sciences, Otto-Friedrich University Bamberg) have published a new book on these questions.

Service Modeling: Methods, Tools, and Industry Solutions ¤ Methods, languages, and tools for service modeling -- Approach to comprehensive creation and processing of service models -- Modeling of product platforms for logistics services -- Analyzing information flows in service networks -- Concept of a modeling language for software tool-supported modeling, configuration, and evaluation of hybrid performance bundles -- Development processes of hybrid performance bundles – Evaluation of modeling methods considering cyclic influencing factors -- Service reference models and order frameworks -- Reference model-based authoring services -- Order frameworks for hybrid value creation -- Modeling of technical customer service processes of machine and plant construction as part of hybrid products -- Modeling of IT and consulting services -- Explanation and modeling of fuzzy aspects in IT-based service processes -- Service orientation in process management – Analysis of the potential of service-oriented architectures based on process models. In response to the increasing competitive pressure, companies are facing – in addition to rationalization and differentiation measures – primarily customer binding. A central role is played here by the expansion and customer-individual design of service offerings. The model-based development and continuous improvement of services are therefore gaining more and more importance. The book provides an overview of the methods used and shows future development perspectives. The numerous examples from different industries focus on models for service development and provision and, on the other hand, models of information systems that support the development and/or provision of services. They consider all life cycle phases of services as well as all "dimensions" of the service concept, which serve as a basis for the development of resource, process, and product models.

Water without Borders : Contributions to the Day of Hydrology on March 22/23, 2012 at the Albert-Ludwigs-University Freiburg ; [TdH 2012] ¤ From the foreword: Hydrology and water management require an integrative approach and therefore often encounter disciplinary, methodological, and administrative boundaries. Therefore, inter- and transdisciplinarity has increasingly gained importance both in hydrological research and in water management applications. The Day of Hydrology 2012 is therefore under the motto Water without Borders. The conference addresses and discusses works that explore these physical and disciplinary boundary areas, apply methods across barriers, and show approaches to overcoming boundaries. The 123 contributions are divided into three thematic areas: Theme 1: Boundary areas (research, modeling); Theme 2: Cross-boundary transitions (management, planning); Theme 3: Boundary transcendence (application, governance).

The completion of the internal market ¤ Horst Siebert (Editor): The Completion of the Internal Market. Symposium 1989 of the Institute of World Economics at the University of Kiel. Publisher J. C. B. Mohr (Paul Siebeck), Tübingen 1990, 387 pages, 82 DM

The Concept of Refugee: Legal, Moral, and Political Controversies ¤ Introduction -- I. Experiential perspectives -- II. Well-founded fear – The refugee concept as a legal concept -- III. Refugees Welcome – Moral implications and the ambivalences of the welcoming culture -- IV. Freedom of movement is everybody's right – Refugees as political actors -- V. Summary and outlook. For years, refugees have been discussed again and again – about open and closed borders, justified and unjustified asylum claims, about reception and deportation. What rights refugees have and what obligations exist towards them is contested. The book analyzes central problems of these moral, legal, and political debates and the social practices of dealing with refugees. At the same time, it introduces basic concepts of current flight and refugee research and focuses on the concept of refugee itself in interdisciplinary research.

The Bath as a Place of Leisure: Spaces, Carriers, and Practices of Bathing Culture from Antiquity to the Present ¤ What do bathing culture and otium have to do with one another? How the two are linked has so far barely been dipped into by researchers. To change that, the present conference volume diachronically investigates the culture and practices of bathing along with its architecture from antiquity to modern times. Its methodological approach illuminates the subject from the trans-disciplinary perspectives of the history of art, archaeology, medieval studies, musicology and literary studies.Survey of contentsHans W. Hubert/Anja Grebe/Antonio Russo: Muße und Bad. Eine Einleitung – Matthias Nieberle: Das römische Baiae. Ein otium-Badeort par excellence? – Antonio Russo: Hammam oder balneum? Hochmittelalterliche Palastbäder in Süditalien. Eine Spurensuche – Gabriele Schichta: Nu ist daz bat so manigvalde: Das Gedicht von dem bade des 'Königs vom Odenwald' – Simone Westermann: »Lüsterner Zeitvertreib«? Baden als gemeinschaftliche Tätigkeit in literarischen und bildlichen Darstellungen in Italien im späten 14. Jahrhundert – Regina Schäfer: Treffpunkt und Ort der Muße – Bäder in Dörfern und (Klein-) Städten im Spätmittelalter – Anja Grebe: Die Kunst des Badens – Albrecht Dürers Bade-Darstellungen vor dem Hintergrund der spätmittelalterlichen Badekultur – Kristina Deutsch: Baden auf dem Tugendberg: Die stufetta der Burg Trausnitz in Landshut – Ulrich Coenen: Kurbäder und Kurarchitektur im 19. Jahrhundert – Eva Stöckler: Musik im Bad. Kur- und Badeanstalten als Orte musikalischer Inspiration: Johann Strauss (Sohn) in Ischl – Hans W. Hubert: Berg, Stein, Wasser, Licht: Die Therme Vals von Peter Zumthor

Parliament and Government in the Modern State ¤ Die Organisationsgewalt Frontmatter -- Content -- Opening of the Conference on October 10, 1957 -- First Point of Discussion: Parliament and Government in the Modern State -- Second Point of Discussion: The Organisational Power -- List of Speakers -- List of Members of the Association of German Constitutional Law Scholars -- Statute

Current Research in Soil Mechanics 2015: Proceedings of the 2nd German Conference on Soil Mechanics, Bochum ¤ Laws of matter and material behavior -- Soil as a multiphase system -- Application-related challenges in soil mechanics. The German Conference on Soil Mechanics has established itself as a forum for professional exchange and discussion of current issues after its successful inaugural event two years ago. The present second conference proceedings deal with the current topics: „Laws of matter and material behavior,

Reproduction of Inequality through Work and Family ¤ Intergenerational Transfers and Support Services - Precarious Life Situations: State Regulation versus Individual Coping - Family Life Situation and Life Chances of Children A key finding of inequality research is that when analyzing social inequality, not only the individual but also the household and family must be taken into account. Families are powerful institutions of lifelong intergenerational solidarity. The social networks of individual family members represent social capital for all other family members; education, income, and parental status are essential resources for children. Those who had better individual starting positions in childhood and youth are also at an advantage in adulthood. Those who have children have support resources in higher age. However, all these socially desired transfers, resources, and family solidarity are accompanied by - at least potentially - undesirable consequences for the social structure, reproduction, and possibly an increase in overall societal inequality. The present volume aims to contribute to the clarification of at least some of the relevant questions in this context. A key finding of inequality research is that when analyzing social inequality, not only the individual but also the household and family must be taken into account. Families are powerful institutions of lifelong intergenerational solidarity. The social networks of individual family members represent social capital for all other family members; education, income, and parental status are essential resources for children. Those who had better individual starting positions in childhood and youth are also at an advantage in adulthood. Those who have children have support resources in higher age. However, all these socially desired transfers, resources, and family solidarity are accompanied by - at least potentially - undesirable consequences for the social structure, reproduction, and possibly an increase in overall societal inequality. The present volume aims to contribute to the clarification of at least some of the relevant questions in this context.

Fiscal Policy and Public Debt ¤ Main description: The conference volume on the 2004 work conference of the Financial Science Committee on the topic "Fiscal Discipline and Public Debt" offers in four contributions a competent overview of explanations for the strained situation of public budgets and instruments for overcoming them. -- Hans Fehr and Gitte Halder (University of Würzburg) quantify with the help of an intertemporal equilibrium model the budget and welfare effects of demographic development in Germany. The analysis shows that the problems cannot be solved alone by increased birth and immigration rates and that further reforms of the social systems are necessary to secure their financing. -- Heinz Grossekettler (University of Münster) examines the requirements of the European Stability and Growth Pact for the coordination of the budget policy of EU member states. In international comparison, the German stability pact proves to be little functional and substantial improvements are called for. -- Reinhard Neck (University of Klagenfurt) extends the tax smoothing theory of Barros to explain the development of public debt by economic and political influence factors and checks these hypotheses econometrically using the example of Austria. -- Gunnar Schwarting (Mainz) notes a worrying financial situation of the German municipalities. Their management is expected neither by conventional consolidation concepts nor by the regulatory and market-oriented instruments currently under discussion, but rather by municipal capital market ratings.

The Relevance of Ilse Arlt's Thinking ¤ Ilse Arlt founded the first welfare school in Vienna in 1913, part of the then Danube Monarchy. She combined this with the project of a scientific 'people's care'. In addition to her notable pedagogical activity, she dealt with the scientific foundation of care in an original way, published on household management, need theory, and economic aspects of need and people's care. Her last major publication dates from 1958, a few years before her death. Her contributions fell into oblivion. Arlt's name remained known in the Austrian social work community, but her theoretical work was not received. With her commendable diploma thesis, Ursula Ertl (1995) created the basis for a renewed engagement with Ilse Arlt's thoughts. She found a wealth of interesting material in her research. Only a few publications picked up the ball (Staub-Bernasconi 1996, Frey 2005). In 2007, the Institute for Social Inclusion Research was founded at the FH St. Pölten as a social work research institute. The team decided to give the institute the name of Ilse Arlt. A colloquium was to be held to pay a detailed tribute to the patroness. The engagement with the texts of the pioneer of scientific social work became an intellectual pleasure. We now want to share this pleasure with a broader professional public. The present reader brings together the contributions to the 1st Ilse Arlt Colloquium and is intended to stimulate a broader reception. Current work is underway for a reissue of Arlt's most important theoretical and autobiographical writings, which we will soon present to the professional public. Dr. Peter Pantucek is the head of the Bachelor's program in Social Work and the Ilse Arlt Institute for Social Inclusion Research at the FH St. Pölten. Dr. Maria Maiss is a lecturer in Philosophy, Ethics, and Social Work Theory at the FH St. Pölten. Ilse Arlt, pioneer of Austrian social work, considered social work as a scientifically grounded profession. With her critical attitude towards the care of her time, her need theory, and her pedagogical activity, she provided original contributions that are still surprisingly relevant today. The present volume introduces Ilse Arlt's biography and her thinking and places her theoretical considerations in the context of current social work scientific discourses.

Who pays, orders : (Un-)Dependencies of media content from media financing ¤ The media needs to be independent, but it also needs funding. Money, however, is rarely given without expecting a return service, or at least without strings attached. Readers only pay for what they want; advertisements are only booked in matching context, and public broadcasters are fighting for the acceptance of their contribution-based funding. New forms of financing, such as crowd funding, donations and new public-law creations, are attempts to counteract this interdependency of media content and media funding. However, these new forms of financing also entail new (and old) interdependencies.This documentation of a conference at the University of Passau attempts to examine this hypothesis of the (inevitable) dependency of content on funding. Aiming for an independent media sector, individual and, especially, innovative forms of financing are discussed and illustrated.

Policey in local spaces : law enforcement and security personnel in communities and territories from the late Middle Ages to the early 19th century : [the working group "Policey/Police in premodern Europe" has ... after its two first working meetings  ... dedicated its third meeting in Stuttgart-Hohenheim on May 18, 2000 to this complex of topics] ¤ Klappentext: Between the late Middle Ages and the early 19th century, numerous officials and functionaries were active on site to maintain internal order and ensure security. The functional and institutional diversity of this personnel and its integration into very different local and regional power structures have made the research of this field of practical administrative activity more difficult. The working group "Policey/Police in premodern Europe" has therefore discussed relevant research results at a working meeting, whose contributions are presented here.

Romantic Epistemology of Knowledge : The Arts and Sciences around 1800 ¤ G. Brandstetter / G. Neumann: Introduction - G. Brandstetter: The Code of Terpsichore.
