Carlo Blasis and the relationship between anatomy and choreography in Romanticism - J. Barkhoff: Staging - Narration - his story. On the epistemology of knowledge in mesmerism and in E.T.A. Hoffmann's Das Sanctus - D. Borchmeyer: The rise and fall of central perspective - R. Borgards: "Head off". The signs and the time of pain in a medical debate around 1800 and Brentano's Kasperl and Anna -W. Hinderer: Dream discourses and dream texts in the context of Romanticism - A. Koschorke: Poiesis of the body. Johann Christian Reil's Romantic medicine - E. Matala de Mazza: "Alternating stimulation". Organic community and the poetics of stimulation in Novalis and Franz Anton Mesmer - A. Michaels: Science as a unity of religion, philosophy, and poetry. Indology as an early Romantic project of a holistic science - G. Neumann: E.T.A. Hoffmann's Princess Brambilla as a draft of 'epistemology of knowledge'. Science - Theater - Literature - H. Neumeyer: Unpredictable unconscious. On the soul of the criminal around 1800 - N. Pethes: Poetics/Knowledge. Conceptions of a problematic transfer - R. Simon: Matters of the heart (Jean Paul, Siebenkäs) - B. Söntgen: Threshold phenomena. Perspective-Hummel's space art - H. Thüring: The indeterminate feeling. Giacomo Leopardi's concept of life as (negative) epistemology of knowledge between the theory of pleasure and the poetics of the indeterminate - H. Uerlings: To represent. On a problem connection in Novalis - C. Welsh: "Sounds are keys to higher strings in us". Figures of thought on the transition between body and soul - S. Willer: Haki Kraki. On Romantic etymology

Spatial Planning Has a Future: Spatial Planning in the Field of Europeanization and Regionalization; 100th Meeting of the Hesse/Rhineland-Palatinate/Saarland Regional Working Group ¤ The volume documents the course and content of the jubilee meeting of the Hesse / Rhineland-Palatinate / Saarland regional working group of the ARL on the occasion of its 100th meeting. With the lectures, a wide arc is drawn in two senses: once from current developments of important determinants in planning to expected future trends; on the other hand, in spatial terms from the municipal or regional focus beyond the three countries to the European level. In this context, concrete demands are also worked out with a view to the further development and further harmonization of spatial development within the framework of European integration.

Remotivierung : from Morphology to Pragmatics ¤ In this volume, researchers in German linguistics examine remotivation processes in German in the fields of morphology, word formation, phraseology, and pragmatics, and discuss their theoretical classification within the framework of grammaticalization and lexicalization processes and their counter-processes. This volume stands like the 2010 volume edited by Rüdiger Harnisch and also published in the LIT series, Processes of linguistic strengthening – Types of formal resegmentation and semantic remotivation in the tradition of Passau remotivation research. Starting from morphological research on language change processes, it becomes apparent that there are additional systematically comparable and thus parameterizable and typifiable counter-forces sui generis, in which linguistic units are elevated in formal and semantic status and thus formally resegmented and semantically remotivated. In addition to the sign-based remotivations in the form of reanalyses and pleonasms, this volume is particularly devoted to usage-based remotivations in the form of recontextualization and shows the broad applicability of the overarching concept of remotivation across all linguistic levels – from the morpheme to the textual and discursive level

Mobility and Context : Future Developments of Mobile Communication in Law and Technology ; Documentation of the Foundation Conference (simultaneously EMR-Workshop) of the Alcatel-Lucent Foundation for Communication Research, the Institute for European Media Law (EMR), the State Media Authority (LFK) Baden-Württemberg and the State Centre for Political Education (lpb) Baden-Württemberg on May 10 and 11, 2007 at the State Media Authority (LFK) Baden-Württemberg, Stuttgart ¤ Mobile phone technology is no longer just for mobile phone calls and SMS exchange. Through assistance functions, access to the web and radio, location and context capture, mobile services become the central individual medium for the exchange and processing of all professional and everyday information. This opens up new possibilities for action and innovation opportunities, offers relief and relief, but also creates new dependencies, additional data trails and risks of misuse. The decisive question is therefore how the new usage possibilities must be legally designed and supplemented in order to keep both development and innovation opportunities open, as well as to win the necessary trust of the user and ensure the protection of general interests ... (Source: Text Book Cover / Publisher)

Social Aspects of Music Learning ¤ The investigation and description of music-related teaching and learning processes belong to the core themes of music education research. Questions about what, how, and what is learned, as well as which aspects are relevant in this context, etc., play a role in music education research competence as well as in philosophical considerations of education, comparative approaches, or historically oriented studies. The answers are correspondingly diverse. The 39th conference proceedings of the Music Education Research Working Group (AMPF) shines with its contributions to the annual conference in Bad Wildbad 2017 methodologically diverse in research, on the one hand, concrete specific questions about the social in musical learning processes. On the other hand, the contributions under this topic setting also go to societal and (education-) political considerations. In the overall view, it becomes apparent which tasks arise from focusing on social aspects of music learning for music education in research and practice.

Evangelical and German? : Diaspora Communities in the 20th Century between National Protestantism, Ethnic Politics, and Ecumenism ¤ In times when Germany is a target for immigration and flight from all parts of the world, it seems sensible to recall that this country has been primarily an emigration area for centuries and the history of many Germans has been shaped by emigration, flight, and exile until recent times. The essays offered in the present volume describe the handling of different types of evangelical diaspora communities with the political and social crises and breaks of the 20th century in their German homeland and host countries. The focus is on the years after World War I, National Socialism, World War II, and finally the time after 1945. It shows that evangelical diaspora communities had to redefine their relationship to their German homeland and the Evangelical Church in Germany repeatedly throughout the 20th century. With the theme of 'diaspora communities', ecclesiastical contemporary history research gains access to an interesting field of research that is connectable to current migration and global historical questions.

Migration in Europe : 64th Scientific Conference of the Association of German Economic Research Institutes on April 26 and 27, 2001 ¤ The demographic development in Germany over the next decades and the EU enlargement have led to a heated debate about the expected consequences for the economic development and economic policy of Germany. The conference contributions compiled here deal with the question of what significance labor migration will have in this context. So Henkel shows how urgently an increase in immigration is needed to counteract the decline in the working-age population and the resulting burden on the social security systems. -- In view of the integration of labor markets in the context of EU enlargement, Brücker and Flaig point out that the influence of unobserved, country-specific determinants of migration behavior brings great uncertainty. Walwei argues that the expected immigration does not justify a relaxation of efforts to strengthen the domestic labor force potential, and Bonin contradicts the expectation that future immigration must burden the public budgets. A positive contribution is all the more to be expected if the migration policy succeeds in achieving immigration of over-average qualified labor. In the question of possible positive effects of migration in the context of increased social mobility of the immigrating working population, Dietz shows to what extent uncertainties about the residence status or formal qualification requirements have hindered the social ascent of immigrants. Finally, von Löffelholz estimates that an intensification of the existing integration policy measures would induce very high social net gains

Female Science, Male Science : Symposium at the University of Oldenburg from June 15-16, 1983; Conference Contributions ¤ The symposium Female Science, Male Science, documented here, deals with the various dimensions of the role of women in the scientific community. On the one hand, the existing disadvantage of women in the university sector is shown and made clear that there can be no talk of the constitutionally guaranteed equal rights of man and woman. On the other hand, it is about the question of a female science, i.e., to what extent the female interest in knowledge can contribute to new scientific questions and beyond to other forms of work and communication.

Algorithmuskulturen : on the computational construction of reality ¤ High frequency trading, Google ranking, filter bubble - just three topical examples of the power of algorithms. This title presents a collection of contributions that deal with the historical emergence and wide distribution of algorithms that can be found in various aspects of social life today. They focus on the correlations between algorithmic and non-algorithmic actors and their significance for our daily lives and our social relationships and follow up on the mechanisms with which algorithms - products of a specific global access - frame reality while organizing the way how humans thinks about society. The contributions include case studies on social media, advertising and evaluation but also on mobile safety infrastructures, such as drones.

The Datified Animal: On the Animal Turn in Cultural and Media Studies ¤ As a result of the datification of animals and their medialization, new forms of togetherness emerge: animals, technology, and humans form a collaboration network. Notably, the enormous data masses transform the animal into a mediated transparency nature. This raises the question of who actually has the power of action and media competence. The contributions in this anthology take a look at these new, cross-species collaborations and socialities with their specific communication structures from an interdisciplinary perspective and investigate their technical and epistemological effects 1. Introduction -- Part I Observations – document – 2. Knowledge under Water. Registering and Regulating in the Aquarium Practice of the 19th Century -- 3. From Living Lenses and Seeing Tentacles. Datified Jellyfish -- Part II. Information – convey – 4. Datification as an Instrument of Liberation? How Livestock Farms Create a Post-Use Animal Narrative Using Social Media -- 5. With Other Eyes. The Use of Crittercams in Contemporary Art -- Part III. Number – measure – 6. Leg Machines. Humans, Animals, and Brain-Machine Interfaces as Hybrid Collectives -- 7. Living Memory. Bacteria as Data Storage -- 8. Animal Resistance -- Part IV. Interface – interact. 9. The Virtual Zoo. On the Way to the Zoological Data Garden -- 10. From Children and Kittens. Technical Interfaces and Their Agents -- 11. The Animal as a Model for Robots, and Robots as a Model for Animals

The Orient, the Foreigner : Positions of Contemporary Art and Literature ¤ The »Orient« as a cultural-geographical category is at the same time diffuse and overdetermined: changing between the clichés of tyranny and despotism on the one hand, sensuality and wisdom on the other. Although the idea of an oriental entity has been ideologically questioned, the topos is today not only idealized as a tourist destination in catalogs, but also in the current political situation as a picture of the Arab, oriental other mass-medially rewritten. In this context, art and literature have an important function as reflection media with which foreign images can be critically questioned. In ten interdisciplinary contributions, the present collection analyzes artistic and literary practices of the differentiation of the »oriental foreigner«.

Erkenntniswunsch und Diskretion : Eroticism in Biographical and Autobiographical Literature ; 3rd Siegen Colloquium Homosexuality and Literature ¤ Gerhard Härle, Maria Kalveram and Wolfgang Popp (eds.): "Erkenntniswunsch und Diskretion". Eroticism in biographical and autobiographical literature. Verlag rosa Winkel, Berlin 1992, 445 pages, hardcover, 48,- DM

Integrated Environmental Protection : A Challenge to Innovation Management ¤ Hartmut Kreikebaum (Editor): Integrated Environmental Protection. Betriebswirtschaftlicher Verlag Dr. Th. Gabler, Wiesbaden 1990, 200 pages, 48,- DM

Current Developments in Environmental Protection Law: Documentation of the 17th Leipzig Environmental Law Symposium of the Institute for Environmental and Planning Law of the University of Leipzig and the Helmholtz Centre for Environmental Research - UFZ on April 19 and 20, 2012 ¤ In light of the implementation of the European Industrial Emissions Directive into national law, a number of questions arise, particularly with regard to future permit requirements and the significance of BVT guidelines and conclusions. The documentation of the 17th Leipzig Environmental Law Symposium focuses on these questions. Several contributions deal with the requirements of the directive and its implementation, the corresponding draft law is presented in detail and critically evaluated from various sides. The remaining contributions are dedicated to other current issues in environmental protection law. On the one hand, air quality law and noise reduction planning are subjected to a balancing consideration. On the other hand, the conflicts between projects approved under environmental protection law and the requirements of spatial planning are examined in more detail. An overview of developments in case law rounds off the work. This volume is aimed at all those who are concerned with environmental protection law issues in science and practice. With contributions from: Pascale Cancik, Kurt Faßbender, Angelika Freifrau von Fritsch, Inken Garbe, Franz Guttenberger, Reinhard Hendler, Norbert Schieß, Ulrich Smeddinck, Wolfgang Köck, Holger Krahmer, Katharina Lehmann, Hartmut Schwarze, Andreas Theuer, Siegfried Waskow, Cornelia Ziehm

Mysticism, Metaphor, Image : Contributions of the VII. Makarios Symposium Göttingen 2007 ¤ German and Finnish theologians discuss the basic questions of Christian mysticism based on authors from the Orient. These authors from the Iraqi-Iranian sphere (Aphrahat the Persian manner, Babai the Great, St. Hierotheos, Isaac of Nineveh, Makarios), play a crucial role in the field of Christian-Oriental mysticism. At the same time they take contributions also beyond this geographic area and go to the mysticism in the German context after Luther (Brandt, Kant) and provide a review, a critical voice to the concept of mysticism and its positioning in the German theology
System Change and Reform in Eastern Economies ¤ Jürgen Backhaus (Editor): System Change and Reform in Eastern Economies. Metropolis-Verlag, Marburg 1991, 366 pages, 44.80 DM

War and Peace in the Horizon of Renaissance Humanism ¤ Franz Josef Worstbrock (Ed.): "War and Peace in the Horizon of Renaissance Humanism" (German Research Association, Reports of the Commission for Humanism Research, Vol. 13). Acta humaniora of VCH Publishing Company, Weinheim 1986. X, 212 p., 27 figs., 69,- DM

Women in Education: Documentation of the Expert Conference of the DGBV Working Group "Women in Educational Administration", from 18 to 19 November 1988 in Boppard ¤ Contains the following individual contributions: Rössler, Margret: Learning goal "Equality". - Flaake, Karin: The fear of one's own strength. On the ambivalent relationship of teachers to authority and power. - Lösener, Marie Luise: Unmarried mothers in education. - Ohly, Ursula: The "Cinderella Complex". Do women have a fear of their own independence?. - Liss-Mildenberger, Eva: Women's promotion - necessary or unnecessary?. - Kreienbaum, Maria Anna: Formal equality and discreet discrimination - research results on coeducation. - Appendix: Literature references, participant list, information about the German Society for Educational Administration. (PHF/overnight.)

Einkommens- und Vermögensverteilung in historischer Sicht : Studies on the Development of Economic Theory XXXVII ¤ Die fortwährende gesellschaftliche Debatte über die angeblich wachsende »Kluft zwischen Arm und Reich« ist höchst aktuell und durch das Buch Pikettys »Das Kapital im 21. Jahrhundert« befeuert worden. Verteilungsfragen – wer bekommt wovon und wieviel und warum – wurden in der Volkswirtschaftslehre immer wieder diskutiert. Im vorliegenden Band wird in vier Aufsätzen auf die verteilungstheoretischen und -politischen Perspektiven verschiedener Autoren eingegangen. -- Schon bei Adam Smith, dem »Adam der politischen Ökonomie«, spielte das Postulat der natürlichen oder moralischen Gleichheit eine bedeutende Rolle, vor allem, wenn man sein moralphilosophisches Hauptwerk, die »Theory of Moral Sentiments«, seinem ökonomischen Hauptwerk, dem »Wealth of Nations«, zur Seite stellt. Dabei blickte er vor allem auf den Effekt, den materielle Ungleichheit auf die Schaffung von Wohlstand, auf die Stabilität der öffentlichen Ordnung und auf die Pflege der allgemeinen Moralität ausübt. Spätere Generationen von Ökonomen haben sich dann vor allem mit der Frage beschäftigt, aus welchen Quellen Profite und Zinsen entspringen und ob diese dauerhaft sind. Neben funktionellen und der personellen Verteilungsfragen stellen sich solche auf der regionalen Ebene. Das wurde in den regionalökonomischen Arbeiten von August von Lösch behandelt. Ganz aktuell ist die Frage, wie sich die Digitalisierung und Verbreitung von KI auf die Verteilung auswirken wird. / »Income- and Wealth Distribution in Historical Perspective« -- The ongoing social debate about the »gap between rich and poor« is currently topical, though not new. This volume contains contributions to the treatment of distribution questions by Smith, Ricardo, Marx and von Lösch. In addition, there is also a contribution to the question of how computerization and digitization will affect income and assets. Ricardo already asked himself the question, what might happen in the future when machinery will make human labour dispensable.

Geographic Information Systems in Regional Planning : Documentation of the Workshop of the Academy for Spatial Research and Planning and the Greater Hannover Municipal Association ¤ The Geographic Information System (GIS) is gaining importance as a planning tool in regional planning. Various aspects of GIS applications, such as the quality and scope of spatially related base data, selection criteria and costs for a GIS introduction, cooperation issues, offers and services in the GIS sector, are of great concern to many users. In the framework of a workshop, practitioners, users, and experts dealt with the multitude of questions associated with the use of modern technology. The publication contains the presentations and statements of the event.

The Historical Jubilee: Genesis, Ordering Performance, and Staging History of an Institutional Mechanism ¤ The historical jubilee counts among those cultural self-evidences that are accepted and practiced all around and are therefore rarely questioned. Public and private memory and festival culture is almost unimaginable without jubilees. In each case, an individual sequence of events is prepared as a personal history from the overall complex of the transmitted history on the occasion of the jubilee cycle recurrence of the initial point, which is proven by sources or is only fictional. The historical jubilee is the symbol for this personal history. Through the reconnection to the past, the duration is signaled that means not only tradition but also implies a claim to validity for the future: The history staged in the jubilee is not a decline leading to a deadline, but a milestone filled with hopes and wishes. The automatism with which historical jubilees are celebrated by organizations and individuals lets the historical dimension of the jubilee cycle itself be forgotten. Here, the present volume starts, which originated from a conference within the framework of the Dresden Special Research Area 537 "Institutionalization and Historicity". Its goal is the historical derivation of a central institutional mechanism for modern memory culture.

Elementary School between the Demands of Individualization and Standardization : [13th Anniversary of the Commission "Elementary School Research and Pedagogy of the Primary Stage" of the German Society for Educational Science ; Conference Proceedings] ¤ The elementary school as the first compulsory educational institution for all children has been facing the challenge since its founding in 1920 to be fair to the individual development of each child as well as to the standardized expectations of society. In the wake of international comparison studies (TIMSS, PISA, IGLU) with worldwide standardized school performance, the double task of the elementary school as well as the problems and possible follow-up costs associated with its fulfillment have again received renewed attention in scientific reflection within and outside elementary school pedagogy. The contributions brought together in this volume deal with the typical demands of standardization and individualization for work in elementary school on the basis of new research-based findings. Prof. Dr. Margarete Götz holds the chair for elementary school pedagogy and elementary school didactics at the University of Würzburg. Karin Müller is a scientific assistant at the chair for elementary school pedagogy and elementary school didactics at the University of Würzburg. The elementary school as the first compulsory educational institution for all children has been facing the challenge since its founding in 1920 to be fair to the individual development of each child as well as to the standardized expectations of society. In the wake of international comparison studies (TIMSS, PISA, IGLU) with worldwide standardized school performance, the double task of the elementary school as well as the problems and possible follow-up costs associated with its fulfillment have again received renewed attention in scientific reflection within and outside elementary school pedagogy. The contributions brought together in this volume deal with the typical demands of standardization and individualization for work in elementary school on the basis of new research-based findings.

Social Pedagogical Professionalization in Crisis? ¤ Crisis are societal perceptions that contribute to the public awareness of various social problems, in order to be able to address them socially politically. Social pedagogy is involved in these crisis perceptions, not least because this brings about the conditions of its (un-)possible professional action, its qualification, political location but also coping. The book puts the question »social pedagogical professionalization in crisis?« on the one hand with contributions to fundamental research results, on the other hand with a view to political positioning in the focus. "The conference took place on March 18 and 19, 2021 with the title "Social Pedagogical Professionalization in Crisis?"." (Foreword)

Monuments in the Garden - the Garden as Monument: International Symposium from March 31 to April 2, 2011 in Schwetzingen ¤ The monument is a phenomenon that, in European garden art from the early modern period to the 19th century, has an equally important and changing significance. The spectrum ranges from the monument as a medium of politically dynastic programs in the princely gardens of Europe to historically relevant aspects of the monument, as an object and initial of preservation. - The present publication documents the results of an international symposium that took place in the background of the nomination of the electoral summer residence Schwetzingen for the UNESCO World Heritage List under the title "Monuments in the Garden - the Garden as Monument" in the spring of 2011 in Schwetzingen. It contains 22 contributions from renowned experts in the history of architecture, art, and garden art from eight European countries. With this, the conference volume presents the first comprehensive and systematic overall view of the complex of topics monument and garden.

Zukunftsfähige Perspektiven in der Landschaftsarchitektur für Gartenstädte : City – Country – Life ¤ Bruno Tauts Visionen für eine sozial-ökologische Stadtentwicklung -- Gartenstädte und Lebensreform -- Ungleiche Rivalen: W. Gropius, L. Fischer -- Relevanz der Gartenstadtidee für die heutige Planungspraxis -- Informelle Siedlungen am Fluss (Code Siedlung in Yogyakarta, Indonesien) -- Stadt-Land-Beziehungen in Thüringen -- Orte schaffen zum Leben und Gedeihen - die Rolle der Natur. Already since antiquity, people have been trying to combine the advantages of living in the countryside with those of city life. From the perspective of landscape architecture, the internationally represented contributors discuss the development of high-quality, green, and sustainable living at the interface between city and country. Different perspectives of current planning theory and practice are presented. Against the background of further planning disciplines and influencing factors and in search of the best solutions for the future of the garden city in the extended sense, the texts (in German and English) call for integrative and broadly inspired planning, development, negotiation, and implementation. The content Bruno Tauts Visionen für eine sozial-ökologische Stadtentwicklung Gartenstädte und Lebensreform Ungleiche Rivalen: W. Gropius, L. Fischer Relevanz der Gartenstadtidee für die heutige Planungspraxis Informelle Siedlungen am Fluss (Code Siedlung in Yogyakarta, Indonesien) Stadt-Land-Beziehungen in Thüringen Orte schaffen zum Leben und Gedeihen - die Rolle der Natur The target groups Lecturers and students of landscape architecture, architecture, urban planning, and sociology Experts in landscape architecture in administrations and housing companies The editor Prof. Dr. Nicole Uhrig teaches in the international master's program at the Anhalt University of Applied Sciences in the field of landscape architecture theory and design. She was also active as a freelance planner in practice.

Structural Change in Post-Mining Landscapes: Strategies for Sustainable Development ¤ The Saxon-Thuringian border region is particularly characterized by the typical development problems of post-mining landscapes. This includes not only the old lignite mines and facilities for the further processing of the extracted lignite, but also the legacies of uranium mining by the former Wismut AG. Therefore, the rehabilitation and development of these areas in the affected regions are a priority, cross-border task for regional planning in both countries. Accordingly, strategies are being developed for the necessary structural change that are intended to open up ways to sustainable development for these regions. This problem was dedicated to the joint regional planning conference for Saxony and Thuringia on July 15/16, 2000 in Altenburg, whose main lectures are reproduced in this volume.

Beyond Eurocentrism : Postcolonial Perspectives in History and Cultural Studies ¤ Shared Histories-- Europe in a Postcolonial World / Sebastian Conrad, Shalini Randeria -- Africa in History: The End of Universal Narratives / Steven Feierman -- Unthinkable History: The Minimization of the Haitian Revolution / Michel-Rolph Trouillot -- The Erasure of Difference: Colonialism and the Origins of Nationalism in Diderot and Herder / Anthony Pagden -- The World as Exhibition / Timothy Mitchell -- Beyond Occidentalism: On the Way to Non-Imperial Geohistorical Categories / Fernando Coronil -- When Was the 'Postcolonial'? Thinking at the Border / Stuart Hall -- Home-Made Hegemony / John L. Comaroff, Jean Comaroff -- Provincializing Europe: Postcoloniality and the Critique of History / Dipesh Chakrabarty -- Foucault's 'History of Sexuality' and the Colonial Order of Things / Ann Laura Stoler -- Ex Oriente Lux: Indology in the National Socialist State / Sheldon Pollock -- We, Not the Others: Germany and Colonialism / Andreas Ecker, Albert Wirz

Threatened Professionalism: Constraints and Current Challenges for Social Work ¤ What constellations, problems, and developments can threaten or constrain professionalism in social work? Under this question, the contributions of the volume focus on a previously rarely focused aspect of professions research. From the breadth of the entire field of action, examples are shown where problematic and ultimately disturbing effects on professional action are found. Threats and constraints are presented and analyzed in various ways in areas such as school social work, family work, adult psychiatry, and youth welfare. Content Scientific basis of social work professional identity welfare associations and professional associations organizational and legal framework conditions Target groups Lecturers and students of the departments of social work, social pedagogy, and educational science at universities of applied sciences and universities. The editors Dr. Roland Becker-Lenz is Professor at the University of Applied Sciences for Social Work in Northwest Switzerland and Private Lecturer for Sociology at the University of Basel. Dr. Stefan Busse is Professor at the Faculty of Social Work at the University of Applied Sciences Mittweida. Dr. Gudrun Ehlert is Professor at the Faculty of Social Work at the University of Applied Sciences Mittweida. Dr. Silke Müller-Hermann is a Research Assistant at the University of Applied Sciences for Social Work in Northwest Switzerland. Dealing with boundaries of professional social work in adult psychiatry -- Development of large welfare associations in Germany -- Awareness of work, recognition, identity -- Juvenile justice and social pedagogical professionalism in conflict -- Economization and economization discourses in social work Threats to the core of professionalism -- School social work -- Labor market integration -- Professionalization in the context of help and control.

Democracy and Association : Potentials of Democratic Education in Youth Work ¤ If it is assumed that democracy can be learned and must be learned, the question arises: Where does man become a democrat? Wibke Riekmann pursues the thesis that, from a theoretical point of view, it is the association that is neglected by educational science. However, the empirical evidence seems to contradict this assumption. Service orientation and familialization lead the associations in a different direction. The author reconstructs the democratic self-awareness of associations at four exemplary selected associations of youth work in history and present. It shows that the associations do not fully exploit their democratic potential and reflect too little. The perception of the association as a formative institution is thus at the beginning for the associations themselves, but also for educational science and politics

New Spaces for Art : International Architecture Competition Kunsthalle Mannheim ¤ 29 architecture firms from around the world participated in the 2012 competition for the new construction of the Kunsthalle Mannheim. As »a mirror of the current developments in world architecture«, the chairman of the jury evaluated the quality of the submitted designs. The publication presents numerous illustrations of the original plans, showcasing the diverse ideas of the architects and providing an overview of the current state of museum architecture. The winning design by the Hamburg-based architecture firm gmp (Gerkan, Marg and Partner) convinces with a striking appearance, a breathtaking spatial experience, and intelligent functional quality. By 2017, a »treasure house« for the Mannheim collection of modern and contemporary art will be built in the heart of Mannheim. The complex task of »museum« is a royal discipline that is also being intensively examined from a museological perspective. In nine text contributions, exhibition makers, museum planners, art historians, and architecture critics ask what it means to think of new spaces for art.

Hochschule und Region : Wirkungen und Wechselwirkungen ; [Documentation of a conference of the Evangelical Academy Loccum in cooperation with the Institute for Development Planning and Structural Research GmbH at the University of Hanover (IES) from June 18 to 20, 1997] ¤ The conference had the following goals and questions: It should re-examine the relationships between universities, cities, and regions - provide impulses for renewed scientific engagement with this topic - illuminate the various cooperation fields in the areas of culture, economy, and social affairs between universities, their seat cities, and regions, and discuss them with a view to practical improvement possibilities - show the communication needs and possible new communication structures between universities, seat cities, and regions. Content: Ermert, Karl: University and Region - Effects and Interactions (Introduction and Foreword). - UNIVERSITIES AND REGION IN LOWER SAXONY. On the relationship between science and research policy and economic and structural policy in Lower Saxony (Schuchardt, Helga. - Tacke, Alfred). - Statement for the universities (Jaudzims, Arno). - Statements for social groups (Birch, Ulf. - Koch, Thomas). - Statement from the perspective of state research and state development (Schramm, Werner). - RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN UNIVERSITY AND LOCATION/REGION - IDEA AND REALITY IN EXAMPLES I. Hamburg (Lüthje, Jürgen. - Rössel, Arne). - II. East Frisia (Jansen, Martha. - Hövelbernd, Erhard). - WORKING GROUP 1. Universities as a factor for the economy and labor market of a region (Back, Hans-Jürgen: Possible leading questions. - Becker, Wolfgang/Peters, Jürgen: Thesis paper. - Buck-Bechler, Gertraude: Working paper. - Kampmann, Ricarda: Theses for the expert opinion Regional Development Impulses of Universities. - Voigt, Eva: Technical University Ilmenau as endogenous development potential. - Back, Hans-Jürgen: Report from the working group). - WORKING GROUP 2. The contribution of knowledge and technology transfer as an instrument of regional anchoring of universities in a region (Kreutzmann, Gertrude: Structuring thoughts. - Appelrath, Hans-Jürgen: OFFIS as an example of an extramural institute with regional commitment. - Dückert, Thea: Theses. - Garen, Walter: The Ostfriesland University of Applied Sciences as a regional university. - Holtkamp, Gerold: Joint Technology Contact Point of the University of Applied Sciences and the University of Osnabrück. - Krutzinna, Manfred: Theses. - Kreutzmann, Gertrude: Report from the working group). - WORKING GROUP 3. Universities as a social and cultural factor in a region (Bramke, Werner: Universities as a social and cultural ...

Social Work and Urban Development: Research Perspectives, Fields of Action, Challenges ¤ Social work and urban development from different research perspectives -- fields of action of social work in urban and neighborhood development -- challenges of professional social work in the urban and neighborhood context. The contributing authors of this anthology present concepts of social work in urban development from a partial, intermediate, reflexive spatial, and planning-related perspective and provide insights into the chances and limitations of their implementation through case examples. The history of social work is closely linked to the development of the city. In this process, different positions of professional action and research have emerged. Furthermore, future challenges such as the Right-to-the-City movements, guiding images such as social sustainability, and approaches to planning-related social work are highlighted. For the second edition, additional contributions were included to present newly positioning arguments to the specialist audience. The content Social work and urban development from different research perspectives Fields of action of social work in urban and neighborhood development Challenges of professional social work in the urban and neighborhood context The target groups Lecturers and students of social work, sociology, geography, and related disciplines Actors from the practice of community work, neighborhood management, urban planning and development, and local politics The editors Dr. Matthias Drilling heads the Institute of Social Planning and Urban Development at the University of Applied Sciences for Social Work in Basel. Patrick Oehler, M.A. Community Development, is a research assistant and project leader at the Institute of Social Planning and Urban Development at the University of Applied Sciences for Social Work in Basel.

Faith : Understanding Faith in Early Christianity and in its Jewish and Hellenistic-Roman Environment ¤ Faith became the central religious concept and the dominant designation of the God-relationship in early Christianity. No Jewish or Greek-Roman writing before or alongside the New Testament uses the field of words

Baukunst von morgen! : Hamburg's Churches of the Post-War Period ; Otto Bartning, 1953 ; [Catalogue for the eponymous exhibition of the Hamburg Monument Protection Office and the Free Academy of Arts Hamburg, 6 September - 7 October 2007] ¤ They seemed sometimes like they were from another time - alien structures in the war-torn Hamburg. Opinions on modern church buildings were far apart back then. Architect Otto Bartning saw them in his speech to the German Association of Architects in 1953 as the "Baukunst von morgen!". Some longed for their familiar historical spaces back, while others welcomed the new beginning of modernity with enthusiasm. Outstanding works of architecture emerged with the churches of the 1950s to 1970s in Hamburg. With their sculptural building bodies, visionary space designs, and great window images and lighting concepts, the churches enrich the cultural landscape of the Hanseatic city. The Hamburg Monument Protection Office draws attention to the peculiarities and beauties of these important and indispensable works of architecture in this richly illustrated book. - - The dwindling financial and membership strength of the two major confessions also puts the post-war churches back in the discussion: Many are being questioned today, and some are threatened with demolition. The more important it is to focus attention on these historical sites and document their significance as religious, social, and cultural spaces for the city.

With Sword or Firm Faith: Luther and the Witches ¤ The Medieval Crime Museum Rothenburg dedicates a large and impressive special exhibition to the witchcraft and witch belief from its early beginnings to the end of the great witch hunts in the 17th century. The focus lies on Martin Luther's confrontation with witchcraft in sermons and table talks; however, this has only secondary importance for his overall work. Luther grew up in a pious environment shaped by superstition and fear and believed, like his contemporaries, in sorcery and witchcraft. As a theologian, he demonized ghostly apparitions, excommunicated witches, and threatened them with judicial consequences. At the same time, he was committed to curbing the witch belief. The richly illustrated companion volume to the exhibition brings together essays on the historical backgrounds of witchcraft and presents 120 impressive objects, from writings on witchcraft to engravings to tools of torture. Informative and visually appealing; usable beyond the jubilee year 2017

Future Elbe - River Landscape and Settlement Area : 1. IÖR-Symposium on October 14/15, 1993 in Dresden ¤ The contributions deal with the state of the Elbe and its landscape area, spatial planning and landscape ecological tasks, the economic development of the Elbe area and the controversial discussion in recent times on the expansion as a shipping route. In a concluding podium discussion, the conflicting views of the spatial planners and water engineers, respectively, and the opponents and supporters of an expansion were particularly highlighted. In the case of an expansion, there is a particular erosion hazard for the Elbe, which can be well grasped by modern computer technology. Discussion topics were the necessity of the Elbe expansion in view of future traffic development, the predictability of the effects and the appropriateness of the planning procedures as well as the costs and benefits of the expansion.

The World and Us: The External Relations of the European Union ¤ The European Union is, starting with the financial and sovereign debt crisis, occupied with the management of profound crises, whose causes partly lie within itself, in its policy or in political developments of its member states, partly but also outside, as is the case with migration movements. The collection of essays addresses itself to external policy questions in this context and examines the competences and instruments of the EU as well as the practice and the limits of the EU's external policy action. The authors turn to the individual policy fields of asylum policy, neighborhood policy, defense policy, trade policy, and investment arbitration. It is to be analyzed with this how the EU can reinvent itself through external action. At the same time, the book wants to contribute to a discussion about whether the Union also follows its own constitutional principles in a contradiction-free manner in its external action. With contributions from Dr. Roland Bank, Prof. Dr. Sigrid Boysen, Prof. Dr. Marc Bungenberg, LL.M. (Lausanne), Prof. Dr. Johan Callewaert, Prof. Dr. Sebastian Graf von Kielmansegg, Prof. Dr. Stefan Kadelbach, LL.M. (Virginia), Prof. Dr. Markus Krajewski, Prof. Dr. Stefanie Schmahl, LL.M. (Barcelona), Prof. Dr. Kirsten Schmalenbach, Dr. Roman Schmidt-Radefeldt, Prof. Dr. Wolfgang Weiß

German as a Means of Communication in Europe ¤ BEGIN Frontmatter -- CONTENT -- Preface by the editors / Born, Joachim / Stickel, Gerhard -- Opening of the annual conference on March 24, 1992 / Grosse, Siegfried -- What is the value of the German language? / Coulmas, Florian -- Homogeneous and heterogeneous currents: Impressions from the distant south of the German language and the new Europe / Clyne, Michael -- Empirical studies on the position of the German language in Europe in economy, science, and politics / Amnion, Ulrich -- German as an official and working language in the European Community / Burkert, Michael -- German in the translator's daily life of the EC Commission / Volz, Walter -- Communication stress in EC institutions / Donat, Marcell von -- "Eurotexts" On the emergence of legal texts under the multilingual conditions of the Brussels EC institutions / Schütte, Wilfried -- "Speak, so that I can see you" Observations on the relationship between language and politics in the GDR past / Thierse, Wolfgang -- German cultural policy and goals of language promotion / Schiriner, Horst -- Prolegomena to future foreign language teaching in Europe / Berchem, Theodor -- The official languages of Switzerland. Teresa Zurdo -- German as a means of communication in East-Central Europe - the example of Hungary / Földes, Csaba -- The role of German in the French education system / David, Jean -- German as one of the means of communication in Eastern Europe - the example of the USSR (Russian Federation) / Domaschnew, Anatolij I. -- German in a unifying Europe - from the perspective of the Goethe-Institut / Eickheim, Hubert -- German as a foreign language. A demarcation / Ickler, Theodor -- The Institute for the German Language in 1992 -- Backmatter END

Europeans in the Levant: Between Politics, Science, and Religion (19th - 20th Century) ¤ The essays investigate the involvement of European powers and their official and unofficial representatives in the rediscovery of the Holy Land and the Levant in the 19th century, when the region became a plaything of the international political scene. The focus is on the back-and-forth between the powers, interest groups, and actors on the ground and the local populations. Hitherto neglected aspects of social, educational, and religious history are incorporated, and religious and national interests are revealed that often continue to the present day. Table of Contents Dominique Trimbur: Introduction: between politics, science, and religion: Europeans in the Levant (19th-20th centuries) Dominique Trimbur: Historical overview of the Levant, 1840-1948 Markus Kirchhoff: German Palestine research in the last quarter of the 19th century. The beginnings and program of the German Association for the Exploration of Palestine Jérôme Bocquet: French and German missionaries in the Levant: French Lazarists in Damascus and Germany, from the journey of William II to the establishment of the Mandate Roland Löffler: The slow metamorphosis of a mission and education institution into a social service provider. The history of the Syrian Orphanage of the Schneller family in Jerusalem 1860-1945 Bertrand Lamure: French pilgrimages to Palestine in the 19th century: Catholic crusade and patriotism Barbara Haider-Wilson: The General Commission for the Holy Land in Vienna - a rediscovery of the 19th century Elena Astafieva: Imaginary and real presence of Russia in the Near East in the second half of the 19th century (French contributions with German summaries and vice versa.)

Violence in the Middle Ages : Realities - Imaginations ¤ Sword fighting, blood feuds, torture - these are images full of cruelty and brutality that cling to the >dark< Middle Ages. But how do they relate to the actual violence of the era? What status did physical violence have for the different groups of medieval society? And how did the Middle Ages itself imagine its violence? A history of violence in the Middle Ages cannot be simply extracted from the text and image documents, because they follow certain representation conventions. A proper understanding of medieval violence requires knowledge of the conceptions and fantasies that drove their actors - feud lords, crusaders, flagellants - to acts of violence against themselves and others. In an interdisciplinary collaboration of archaeology, history, art history, and ethnology, the book develops a new history of medieval violence

Cities for All ¤ In honor of the two city directors Martin Neuffer and Rudolf Koldewey of the state capital Hanover, the symposium took place in June 2005. The visionary ideas and development possibilities of Martin Neuffer ("Cities for All - Draft of a City Policy" as a programmatic title of one of his books) and the rather sober and pragmatic thinking and acting of Rudolf Koldewey formed the intellectual field of tension in which the individual contributions of this documentation are located. As a result, the current challenges to urban planning and urban development are clearly shown against the background of partly far-reaching changes in the urban development policy framework from the perspective of local politics, urban research, planning administration, and administrative modernization.

10 Years of Austria's EU Membership: Balance and Outlook ¤ Noted experts present in 20 contributions the advantages and disadvantages of Austria's EU membership from a legal perspective. They focused on those aspects which were of particular interest in the accession negotiations. Starting from the constitutional legal foundations of EU membership with a total amendment of the federal constitution, they deal with the following topics: the participation of the federal government and the states in EU projects, Austria's participation in the common foreign and security policy in the context of permanent neutrality, and the relationship between EU law and Austrian national law. Subsequently, they explain the transit traffic and (foreigner) basic traffic, the preservation of environmental standards, agricultural and agricultural structure policy, the anonymity of bank accounts and savings deposits, access to universities and universities, and the preservation of social standards. Written for: Libraries, Researchers, Universities Keywords: 10 years of EU membership European law European law studies International law Austria

Globalization and the Future of the Social Market Economy ¤ Globalization forces us to think about which of the institutions in our society, which have been established over many years, must be subject to changes. The Social Market Economy with its social networks and its variety of arrangements, which are intended to secure as many incomes as possible downwards, is under pressure due to the increasing international competition. More flexibility instead of rigidity, more risk-taking instead of risk aversion and more entrepreneurial initiative instead of bureaucratic spirit is required. Reductions in the systems of social security are unavoidable, because their financing has long since overburdened the public budgets.

Varusschlacht im Osnabrücker Land : Museum und Park Kalkriese ¤ Reich illustrierter Begleitband zur Dauerausstellung im "Museum und Park Kalkriese" über archäologische Forschungen und neue wissenschaftliche Erkenntnisse zur Varusschlacht

Aesthetics of Digital Media: Current Perspectives ¤ In an increasingly comprehensive way, digital technologies and social media determine selection, form, and content of perception - and produce new (un-)visibility again and again. Cultural practices as a repertoire of signs, symbols, and behaviors are subject to constant transformation and meaning change. This development dynamics in the field of auto-operational forms and cultural practice demands a new categorization and questioning of the aesthetics of visually supported digital media. How do the concept and definition of the aesthetic change in the age of digitalization and what does aesthetic experience mean in the context of digital media?

Martin Luther : Problems of his Time ; [Ernst Walter Zeeden on the 14th May 1986] ¤ Volker Press, Dieter Stievermann (Ed.): "Martin Luther. Problems of his Time" (Late Middle Ages and Early Modern Period, Vol. 16). Klett-Cotta Publishing Group, Stuttgart 1986. 301 p., bound, 124,- DM

Lying with Pictures ¤ Starting from the question of lie and deception, one of the fundamental themes of image scientific knowledge, the use of images in media, public and everyday life is analyzed. ... The anthology refers to a lecture series that took place in Koblenz in 2005 under the title ?Lying Images?. The series was created at the University of Koblenz in cooperation with the State Center for Political Education Rhineland-Palatinate and refers to the exhibition of the same name designed by the House of History in Bonn.

Ecology, Economy, and Jurisprudence ¤ Environmental economics and environmental policy / Joachim Klaus -- Basic problems of environmental protection from a legal perspective / Rüdiger Breuer -- Environmental certificates / Alfred Endres -- Environmental certificates / Alexander Blankenagel -- Environmental policy in practice / Lutz Wicke -- Environmental policy in practice / Andreas Troge -- Environmental protection tested by the social market economy / Edgar Michael Wenz

The Autonomous University - a Success Model? : IX. University Reform Symposium November 28, 2013 Goethe University Frankfurt am Main ¤ Against the backdrop of an increasingly intense international competition for the

Future of Work - Human Perspective: Current Research Findings and Good Practices ¤ This academic book describes the opportunities and risks for employees and executives in a modern working world. Overarching developments such as demographic change, increasing digitalization and globalization, as well as the resulting value shift, change the organizational environments and thus also the understanding of work. The contributing authors focus on the human being and discuss the effects of these changes on individual work, how satisfied employees are currently with their work contents and environments, and how they want to work in the future. Furthermore, they investigate which framework conditions, structures, office forms, and models organizations must develop in the future to design the workplace of the future as productive, motivating, and healthy. The future competence requirements for employees are considered, and the leadership role in New Work is analyzed. The division of contributions into three different categories - scientific contributions, practice reports, and personal viewpoints - allows for a diverse reading access to the topic. The content The Journey to New Work How we will work in the future New Work - New Leadership? Is there still a future for the office? The Editors Prof. Dr. Sebastian Wörwag is Rector of the FHS St.Gallen University of Applied Sciences. In his research work, he deals with changes in the working world. Prof. Dr. Alexandra Cloots is Co-Leader of the HR Panel New Work at the FHS St.Gallen University of Applied Sciences. Her field of expertise is the innovative design of organizations and leadership in the age of New & Smart Work The Journey to New Work -- How we will work in the future -- New Work - New Leadership? -- Is there still a future for the office? END

Competition for Public Remembrance : Memory Cultures in the Potsdam and Brandenburg Area ¤ Public remembrance is characterized by competition. Private memory communities try to assert themselves against public remembrance, occupy new spaces, or override prevailing rituals. They demand a different remembering, spark debates, and question existing values. The contributors ask in the context of Public History about the dominant and marginalized actors, the historical backgrounds of the competitions, as well as solutions for existing conflicts. They present particularly for Potsdam various approaches on how memory spaces can be occupied analogously or digitally and new dialogues can be opened.

Kant's Metaphysics and Philosophy of Religion ¤ This volume contains contributions to Kant's theoretical and practical philosophy, his philosophy of religion, and overarching metaphysical problems, as well as contributions to the fate of critical metaphysics in immediate post-Kantian philosophy. An interesting conclusion is formed by investigations into Kant's impact in the non-German language area.

From Medicinal Product to Food? : On the Distinction between Medicinal and Food Products in European and German Law ¤ The distinction between food and medicinal products is of significant legal and economic importance. The authors of the contributions in the present volume investigate current legal developments in Europe and Germany from a legal, nutritional physiological, and pharmaceutical perspective. (Source: Text Book Cover / Publisher)

Turkey Research in the German-speaking Area: Turbulences, Crises, and Resistances ¤ The authors of this collective volume investigate turbulences, crises, and resistances in the history and present of Turkey. At the center stands the question of how social and political change is negotiated in art and literature, what influence it has on transnational migration movements, how it changes the urban space, and what role academic freedom plays. Alone three military coups shaped the history of the country in the second half of the 20th century. The subsequent neoliberal agenda of the 1980s had not only economic, but far-reaching social and cultural consequences. The volume follows an interdisciplinary and epoch-spanning approach that examines interactions between culture and politics on the one hand and illuminates societal structures in their historical changeability on the other. Content Culture and Society Migration and Transnationalism Urban Spaces Academic Freedom Target groups Lecturers and students of politics, culture, history, and Islamic studies as well as sociology, Turkology, and anthropology Experts in (political) practice Editors Johanna Chovanec, M.A., University of Vienna Gabriele Cloeters M.A., University of Hamburg Dr. Onur İnal, University of Vienna Dr. Charlotte Joppien, University of Hamburg Urszula Woźniak M.A., Humboldt University of Berlin. Culture and Society -- Migration and Transnationalism -- Urban Spaces -- Academic Freedom.

Innovative Products and Services in Mobility: Technical and Business Aspects ¤ Management trends in the (international) automotive industry -- Evaluation of integrated product bundles -- Alternative drives, driver assistance systems, and networked vehicles -- Mobility in urban spaces. At the 8th Science Forum Mobility at the University of Duisburg-Essen, it was discussed in June 2016 how innovative mobility products and services can be designed to ensure individual and integrated customer communication. The conference proceedings present solution approaches that have emerged at the interfaces of business and engineering research. In addition to networked information offerings, intermodal traffic concepts, and innovative driver assistance systems, advanced car-sharing models and supplementary digital service offerings can increase the value of mobility solutions. The content Management trends in the (international) automotive industry Evaluation of integrated product bundles Alternative drives, driver assistance systems, and networked vehicles Mobility in urban spaces The target groups Lecturers and students of economics and engineering sciences with a focus on (automotive) mobility Senior executives and management consultants in the automotive industry The editors The conference proceedings are published by Prof. Dr. Heike Proff and Dr. Thomas M. Fojcik with the involvement of Prof. Dr. Margret Borchert, Prof. Dr. Angelika Heinzel, Klaus Krumme, Prof. Dr. Rainer Leisten, Prof. Dr.-Ing. Bernd Noche, Prof. Dr.-Ing. J. Alexander Schmidt, Prof. Dr. Gertrud Schmitz, Prof. Dr. Jörg Schönharting, Prof. Dr.-Ing. Dieter Schramm, Prof. Dr. Andreas Wömpener, all University of Duisburg-Essen.

Enhancement : Critical Theory and Psychoanalytic Practice ¤ People have never been enough. Since they began to differentiate themselves from other animals, they invented tools and eventually large machines to tame natural forces, use resources better, and make life more comfortable. What is now called Enhancement only continues an ancient tradition. In order to grow in line with the demands of everyday and working life, drugs are increasingly used to enhance performance. And brain-machine interfaces already belong to the treatment options in some areas of medicine. But what images of humans, perfection requirements, and psychological conflicts does Enhancement transport? Should psychotherapy be helpful in this development? Or is it time for a full brake? The authors illuminate these questions using critical theory and psychoanalytic instruments from an interdisciplinary perspective. They show the different facets and chances, but also the illusions and limitations of Enhancement, as well as its inextricable entanglement with the logic of the market. With contributions from Bernd Ahrbeck, Steffen Elsner, Kristina Flint, Gesa Foken, Thomas Fuchs, Christoph Henning, Joachim Küchenhoff, Elfriede Löchel, Jens Paulsen, Clara Schließler and Henning Teschke.

Sex Work : Prostitution – Worlds and Myths ; [... in occasion of the exhibition "Sex Work. Prostitution - Worlds and Myths" at the Museum of Work, Hamburg ... Women's Museum, Bonn ...] ¤ // Sperrgebiet and Herbertstraße, Reeperbahn and "La Merced", women and men on the street or in the brothel, "Dock seagulls" in the harbor: prostitution has many faces. Behind them, there are even more stories waiting to be told. "Sex Work" tells these stories: about work and private life of sex workers, about the fight for legal equality and social recognition, about the handling of prostitution in Europe and overseas, about the myth of fast money. Over 100 contributions and experience reports shed light on the backgrounds of a billion-dollar, traditional service industry. "Sex Work" - this term goes back to the American sex workers' movement and their demand for legal and social equality. Sex work is a traditional service and is today a significant economic factor: approximately 200,000 women work in the sex industry here, the annual turnover is estimated at around 14 billion euros. Prostitution is today recognized as a profession and is legal. The law of 2002 abolished the discrimination of prostitution as immoral. Sex workers can now enter the statutory health and pension insurance. This exhibition casts a glance behind the scenes, shows what often remains invisible in the shadow of voyeurism: a world of work between illusion and reality, it scratches at clichés without the moral finger, asks: Is sex work a profession like any other? Is there the big, fast money? How do sex workers see their work?

Profession of Meaning Stiftung ¤ Meaning Stiftung has always been in expert groups, from religious virtuosos to artistic 'geniuses' and up to scientific experts. Furthermore, in modern society, meaning stiftung has become a field of practice for various professions (e.g. theologians and pastoral care workers, doctors, psychologists and psychotherapists, or journalists). The analysis of this field is at the center of the book. Meaning Stiftung has always been in expert groups, from religious virtuosos to artistic 'geniuses' and up to scientific experts. Furthermore, in modern society, meaning stiftung has become a field of practice for various professions (e.g. theologians and pastoral care workers, doctors, psychologists and psychotherapists, or journalists). The analysis of this field is at the center of the book. Dr. Dr. Michael N. Ebertz is a professor at the Catholic University of Applied Sciences Freiburg. Dr. Rainer Schützeichel represents the professorship of microsociology and qualitative methods at the University of Hagen.

The Politicization of the Utopian in the 18th Century: From Utopian System Design to the Age of Revolution ¤ Blurb: The classical utopian tradition initiated by Thomas More has represented the claim to validity of a regulative principle or an ideal. This changed fundamentally in the 18th century. How the Enlightenment introduced the problem of practical reality change into the utopian discourse and thereby produced forms of legitimation of social practice anticipating the 19th century, is the systematic interest in knowledge of the contributions collected in this volume. They originated from the symposium on the topic "The Politicization of the Utopian in the 18th Century", which took place in the spring of 1995 at the Interdisciplinary Center for the Research of European Enlightenment in Halle.

Relationship between the legislature and the judiciary : contributions to the 6th Seoul-Freiburg Law Faculties Symposium ¤ The volume contains the lectures of the 6th Seoul-Freiburg Law-Faculties Symposium, which took place in Freiburg i. Br. in June 2016. Since its beginning in the year 1996, the partnership between the Law School of the Seoul National University and the Faculty of Law of the Albert-Ludwigs University has borne various fruits, significantly contributing to mutual understanding of legal thinking and legal research in both legal cultures and legal systems, and thus continuing the equally old and valuable tradition of close connection between Korean and German law. Like the preceding symposia, the 2016 symposium dealt with the general theme 'Relationship between the Legislature and the Judiciary' with a fundamental problem, whose specific manifestations in constitutional law, legal theory, private law, criminal law, commercial law, and administrative law were the subject of lectures and discussions. With contributions from: Un Jong Pak, Matthias Jestaedt, Ralf Poscher, Hong Sik Cho, Kye Joung Lee, Frank Schäfer, Jinsu Yune, Jan von Hein, Sank Won Lee, Ok-Rial Song, Boris Paal, Maximilian Haedicke, Seongwook Heo, Dongjin Lee

Two Years Later: Municipal Experiences in Implementing the TAG (§§ 22-24a SGB VIII) : Documentation of the 9th Berlin Conference on Youth Welfare on November 2-3, 2006 in Berlin ¤ On January 1, 2005, the Law on the Quality-Oriented and Needs-Based Expansion of Daycare came into effect and thus made ongoing developments in the expansion of childcare binding. In many municipalities, the development and renovation process had already been underway beforehand. On this conference, the current implementation status of the TAG was discussed two years after its entry into force. The German Youth Institute e. V. presented its evaluation results in this regard. The focus of the event was on the presentation and discussion of successful municipal examples of childcare from various cities and districts in East and West. In particular, the following aspects were referred to: Qualified needs-based planning, flexible service forms, daycare, as well as quality development and personnel development.

Forum Mergers & Acquisitions 2011 : Contributions from a legal and economic science perspective ¤ The topic of Mergers Acquisitions is of high relevance for science and practice. The challenge lies particularly in interdisciplinary questions that regularly arise in the context of such transactions. The MA Alumni Germany e.V. has therefore launched the conference Mergers Acquisitions in the field of tension between legal and economic sciences - Current findings from research and practice in order to initiate a cross-disciplinary discourse. In the framework of the first conference 2010, ten contributions emerged, in which legal and economic scientists critically deal with the topic of MA.

Excellence in Legal Education : On the Way to a Legal Science Didactics ¤ The first volume of the "Schriften zur rechtswissenschaftlichen Didaktik" contains a stocktaking and critical reflection of previous approaches, projects, and framework conditions for improving legal education and teaching. This creates the basis for a qualified exchange on the way of teaching and learning in legal science, which has been lacking so far.

Between Dream and Trauma: Urban Planning of the Post-War Modern ¤ Vision, guidelines, plans, and practical examples for the reconstruction (mainly) of German cities after the destruction caused by air raids in the Second World War. (Erdmann Steinmetz) "Light - cheerful - natural - festive - colorful - radiant", was a target vision for the reconstruction of the cities destroyed (mainly) in the 2nd World War, in order to "complete the work of the bombs" and to realize a visionary new beginning - a concept that was hardly implemented. In this volume, 15 authors present guidelines and examples - including Berlin, Hanover, Hamburg, Saarbrücken, ("socialist") Dresden - under political, social, and aesthetic conditions and discuss the causes of the current trend towards demolition and reconstruction. The work, equipped with numerous small-format images and plans as well as extensive literature references, also aims to provide a "contemporary view of the structure and shape of our everyday living environment". It offers, beyond the professional framework, essential and interesting possibilities. (2) (Erdmann Steinmetz)

Language and Law ¤ The conference proceedings aim to stimulate the interdisciplinary discussion between language and law sciences once again, and against the backdrop of current social developments. The selected topics are illuminated from both linguistic and legal perspectives, i.e. by language scientists and lawyers, respectively: the relationship between language, law, public and politics, communication in court, a partly linguistic and philosophical view of relevant legal statements, questions of interpretation, especially in the face of the complex intertextuality of law, historical and current (related to European integration) changes in legal and language systems, the benefits of linguistics for criminology, as well as causes and solutions for the difficulty of understanding laws

Russia and Germany - Neighbors in Europe ¤ In the first part, contributions to the development of post-communist Russia and the handling of the Soviet heritage are presented. This deals with the emergence of new states on the territory of the former USSR, the state rebirth of Russia and the acceptance of the new state by the population as well as historical peculiarities of post-communist democracy in Russia. In the second part, it deals with the economic and social transformation in Russia and Germany. The economic development of Russia within the CIS, the overcoming of the division in a united Germany, and long-term growth prospects of the new federal states from an order-theoretical perspective are treated. In a concluding part, problems and perspectives of Russia's westward integration are discussed. (BIOst-Wpt)
Historical Museums Today ¤ Enth.: Historical Museum or City Museum? Participation and the Self-Understanding of the History Museum Hannover / Jan W. Huntebrinker

Administration and its Law ¤ The present volume contains the lectures held within the framework of the 2018 annual conference of the German Section of the International Institute of Public Administration Sciences in Leipzig. The conference was held under the general theme „Administration and its Law“. The aim of the volume is to consider the relationship between administration and administrative jurisdiction under various aspects as well as the role of law as an instrument of administration control, and – in a third block – to discuss different aspects of the – going beyond the mere effect of norms – relationship between national administrations and EU law. Contributions were made by high-ranking persons from administrative jurisdiction, including the President of the BVerwG Prof. Dr. Rennert, and from administration as well as researchers from law and political science.

Plakativ! : Advertising in Posters 1885 to 1965; The Nuremberg Poster Collection ...; [on the occasion of the exhibition Plakativ! Advertising in Posters 1885 - 1965, Germanisches Nationalmuseum, Nuremberg 19 November 2009 to 11 April 2010] ¤ Maggi, Coca-Cola, Osram, Persil, Nivea, Palmers, Agfa or VW: Based on the

Area and Protected Area Management by Foundations, Associations, and Societies ¤ Voluntary engagement is a crucial pillar for nature conservation in Germany. The first nature conservation associations were founded over 100 years ago, and the acquisition of areas by associations for the protection of threatened areas has been taking place for a long time. Following German reunification in 1990, for example, the sale of former state property of the GDR also led to the transfer of nature conservation areas (so-called national natural heritage) to foundations and associations, which as new area owners took on various obligations. Many successes in nature conservation are due to this continuous voluntary effort. These circumstances prompted the BfN to hold a conference on the island of Vilm in 2015, at which various foundations, associations, and organizations presented their successes in area and site protection explicitly. This volume summarizes the results of the conference and makes them known to a broader public.

New Perspectives in Guardianship and Custodianship Law : 9th Göttingen Workshop on Family Law 2010 ¤ The present volume contains the papers of the 9th Göttingen Workshop on Family Law, held on December 10, 2010, which dealt with the current revision of the Guardianship Law. The opening presentation was on the need for reform in Guardianship and Custodianship Law (Gisela Zenz), followed by an explanation of the government's draft bill (Thomas Meyer). Subsequently, the question was addressed of whether and to what extent the Law on Guardianship can be used as a model for the new Guardianship Law (Dieter Schwab). The next contribution called for a change in perspective from the legislator to the ward, discussing the selection of the appropriate guardian for the individual ward (Barbara Seidenstücker). Finally, the structural problems on the side of the youth welfare offices were shown (Hans-Werner Pütz) and the neglected problem in the legislative process was highlighted, which consequences arise from the draft bill for the supplementary guardianship (Thomas Meysen). Volume 9 of the series Göttingen Juristische Schriften The series is published by the Faculty of Law of the Georg-August-University and makes events at the faculty accessible to an interested public.

Education and Standards: Critique of the 'De-Standardization' of the German Education System ¤ In rare consensus and in great haste, the ministers of education and senators have decided to develop national education standards, to concretize them in selected areas, to declare their introduction binding, and to monitor their implementation. It is more or less clearly expected that Germany or the respective federal state will perform better in similar performance comparisons in the near future. However, after a more detailed analysis of the concepts formulated under the heading of education standards, it becomes apparent that many questions are either unresolved or decided in a way that gives rise to concerns. In this volume, a critique of these concepts is attempted as a scientific evaluation of their chances and risks. Most contributions to this volume were initially formulated as expert opinions on behalf of the GEW, internally discussed, and discussed on a larger, public conference. The GEW itself has clearly positioned itself in the public debate on the drafts. Furthermore, several education scientists have asked which risks could arise from the favoring of standards and, in particular, from the related concretizations, and how this relates to the chances that could be or should be associated with such an approach. With contributions from Isabell van Ackeren, Wolfgang Böttcher, Marianne Demmer, Gewerkschaft Erziehung und Wissenschaft, Ursula Helmke, Ludwig Huber, Eva Jablonka, Eiko Jürgens, Christine Keitel, Hermann Lange, Christa Lohmann, Rudolf Messner, Arne Paulsen, Wilfried Plöger, Matthias von Saldern, Andreas Schleicher, and Jörg Schlömerkemper

How Much Pluralism Does Humanity Need? : A University Seeks Its Identity ¤ In this volume, scholars from the new federal states engage with the scientific legacy of teacher training in the former GDR, exemplified by the Magdeburg Pedagogical University. The basis is formed by contributions from a colloquium held on April 1 and 2, 1992, at this university under the title of this volume. In an appendix, documents are added as an example of teacher training, which illuminate the training situation before the turn and at the same time show the ideological burden of the subject. Appendix I. Training and Research Profile of the Magdeburg Pedagogical University (as of July 1992) Appendix II. Teaching programs for the training of diploma teachers of general polytechnic secondary schools in the subject of pedagogy at universities and colleges of the GDR. Berlin 1982 - Study guidance: Foundations of Pedagogy. Magdeburg 1984 and 1987 - Study guide: Pedagogy II. Part: Systematic Pedagogy. Magdeburg March 1989

Told Orders - Orders of Telling : Studies on Texts from the Middle Ages to the Early Modern Period ¤ As narrative texts unfold worlds, they also design orders. Furthermore, they must be designed in an orderly manner in telling, so that the concept of 'order' applied to narrative texts is relevant in a double sense: as orders of telling as well as told orders. 'Order' is understood as a dynamic concept that can only be grasped in its plurality and is strongly tied to the social action spaces of its negotiation. Since orders aim, inter alia, to establish and organize communities, shape perception, generate meaning, offer sense, and enable knowledge. Accordingly, the order conceptions designed in told worlds can be read as a specific expression of cultural knowledge. The primary interest of the volume is to test 'order' as a category of narratological analysis and to inquire, through the double formula mentioned in the title, how order conceptions of societies are productively negotiated through orderly telling in texts of the Middle Ages and the Early Modern Period, and in what form narrative literature can claim to be part of the formation of a sociocultural world.

Thematic Focus: "Populism" and Democracy : Osnabrück Peace Talks 2017 - Musica Pro Pace 2017 - Contributions to Peace Research ¤ Brexit, Trump and ›Populism‹ - Recent global political events and developments condensed into three keywords, discussed by former Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer with political scientists: the UK's withdrawal from the EU, the presidency of Donald Trump, and the growing trend towards isolationist and nationalist ›Retro‹ parties in Europe. Is a turning point looming? The frequent verdict on this - Populism! - warns of threats to the constitutional democracy. But is the appeal to the ›people‹ anti-democratic? After all, no politician wants to be called ›populist‹, yet no politician, no politician, renounces the declaration that the ›people‹ or ›the people in our country‹ are the main driving force behind their actions. Does democracy also offer space for ›populism‹?

20 Years Garden Monument Conservation : Location Determination : Documentation of the 20th Cologne Conversation on Architecture and Monument Conservation in Cologne, May 11, 2015 ¤ ... On the occasion of our 20th Cologne Conversation, we would like to throw a look back not only on the development of the last 20 years of garden monument conservation in the Rhineland, but also to shed light on current problems, topics, and monument groups from the large field of garden monument conservation that are currently particularly challenging and engaging us. We would like to offer a plenum for further education and professional information exchange to those who are actively involved in garden monument conservation today and contribute their experiences, in order to discuss the current location of garden monument conservation ... (From the introduction by Ludger J. Sutthoff)
Historical Interpretation on Old Maps: Archaeology and History ¤ Historical interpretations

Business Administration and Social Responsibility : with Corporate Social Responsibility to more Engagement ¤ Gesellschaftliche Verantwortung der Unternehmen Governance statt Government? The contribution of public business administration to the common good Social responsibility of companies as a business case? Social framework conditions of employment management Discounting through replication - company valuation Questions on the social responsibility of business administration
