Inclusion in School Sports : Suggestions and Reflections ¤ Since the ratification of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, inclusive education of children with and without special needs has become the norm in Germany. In the coming years, physical education teachers will increasingly focus on the question of what changes the inclusive physical education and extracurricular movement, play, and sports offers in the full-day school will bring. In the current teacher training, this topic is hardly anchored. The book brings together contributions from theory and practice, which were presented for the first time at the specialist conference 'All in Motion? Suggestions and Reflections on Inclusive School Sports' at the German Sport University Cologne in March 2015.

Purity and Authority in the Cultures of the Ancient Mediterranean ¤ Conceptions of purity and impurity are important structural elements of ancient religious traditions. In their simplest form, they regulate the physical presence of individuals and objects in sacred precincts or at other places where this seems socially required. Due to their potential for regulating inclusion and exclusion, conceptions of purity have always also had an – often implicit – significance for the formation and maintenance of human communities. With the religious, a political dimension is necessarily connected. In the present conference volume, it is investigated how communities of the ancient Mediterranean and their leaders dealt with this political potential.

In the Name of God... : Theology and Practice of Prayer in Christianity and Islam ¤ What does prayer achieve? What role does it play in the relationship between man and God, and what areas of overlap are there between Christian and Muslim prayer? Prayer is the central expression of religious faith in Christianity and Islam. But what does prayer 'achieve' - and with whom? What role does the community of faith play in this? Are there criteria for authentic prayer or areas of overlap between Christianity and Islam? Prayer texts are important sources for understanding God, the image of man, and the relationship between God and man in both religions. But even if there are numerous parallels and similarities between Christian and Muslim prayer, the trinitarian structure of Christian prayer is particularly problematic for Muslims.

From Studium generale to University Reform: The 'Oberaudorfer Gespräche' as a Forum for Trade Union University Policy 1950-1968; [Publication of the Center for Contemporary History of Education and Science at the University of Hanover] ¤ The edition of the almost forgotten 'Oberaudorfer Gespräche' opens a view into considerations for university reform, which were led by the university committee of the GEW in the DGB from 1950 to 1968. The 'general debate' initiated by the initiator of the conversations, the former state secretary Eduard Brenner, on the necessity of a university reform led to a variety of resolutions to take up the debate on university reform again, which had dried up in the post-war period. At first, the question of a 'studium generale' that should accompany the entire study was at the center. Inspired by life and offers at Anglo-Saxon campus universities, detailed plans for individual courses of study were worked out. In the following, the focal points shifted: They touched on examination reforms, general university didactics, the misery of non-ordinaries, the academization of teacher training for elementary school teachers. The explosion of old forms in favor of the 'team' idea, interdisciplinary training, and promotion of young scientists are worth highlighting. (HoF/Text adopted)

Robert Schuman : Political Realism and European Spirit ¤ “The peace of the world cannot be preserved without creative efforts corresponding to the magnitude of the threat,” so said Robert Schuman in the most famous speech of his life. Schuman's words remain of lasting relevance in our contemporary world: Since February 24 and the Russian attack on Ukraine, peace in Europe has been threatened as it has not been for a long time. How much Schuman's peace-making motivation and ideas can actually be an inspiration for today is shown by this volume, whose contributions from history, political science, and philosophy illuminate the life and politics of the

Learning Landscapes : new school buildings ; [Exhibition] July 26 to August 18, 2012, Renate Kammer Gallery ; [Catalogue] ¤ What is school and what is »child-friendly« architecture? A row of classrooms, the sound of the school bell, noisy children in long, narrow corridors, dusty display cases on hexagonal-tiled landing platforms, easy-to-maintain floors and heavy fire doors? For architect Marc-Olivier Mathez, school is »WorkCity«, a staging, a space that should not be subject to a societal will to discipline. Mathez began his school building projects with the »Grund- und Stadtteilschule Stübenhofer Weg«. In 2010, the architecture firm developed a pedagogical school architecture project in line with the Dutch architect Herman Hertzberger – simple building, spacious rooms, plenty of daylight and art light, open interior spaces without corridors, work and rest areas – a vision for the future of Germany. This catalogue book presents three of Mathez' innovative school architecture projects: the »Gymnasium Süderelbe« in Neugraben-Fischbek, the »Grund- und Stadtteilschule Stübenhofer Weg« in Kirchdorf-Süd and the »Integrative Grundschule Am Johannisland« in the »BGZ Neugraben-Fischbek«.

1848 and the Promise of Modernity ¤ J. Fohrmann / H. J. Schneider: Introduction - R. Kolk: 'Yes, the sight of rising young men is exhilarating.' The promise of youth between Vormärz and Modernity - K. Stüssel: Point, Point, Comma, Dash ... - Revolutions and the history of 'contemporary literature' - N. Oellers: Poets in the Paulskirche - V. Kaiser: Karl Marx. Representation and criticism as a promise to modernity - F. Breithaupt: Homo Oeconomicus (Young Germany, Psychology, Keller and Freytag) - J. Fohrmann: The invention of the intellectual - K. S. Calhoon: The Moon, the Mail, and the Province of German Literature - B. Fischer: Jewish emancipation and German nation: From Mendelssohn to Auerbach - J. Grossman: 'The mastery of language': Functions of Yiddish in German culture from Heine to Frenzel - B. Hahn: Precarious continuities - or from the place of the 'woman'

Shared Time : Catalogue for the Exhibition of the Württemberg State Library Stuttgart ¤ Time passes quickly, slowly, ticks our daily routine, seems to determine the course of things. We share it, but can only manage it to a limited extent. It forms a social infrastructure and remains difficult to understand. The Württemberg State Library presents exciting examples of the various manifestations of dealing with what we call time

Global Crisis - Regional Sustainability: Options for Future-Oriented Urban and Regional Development ¤ The global financial crisis of 2008/09 serves as the starting point for the considerations in this volume: Is it a systemic crisis that cannot be resolved in individual sectors of the economy and politics, but rather involves the fundamental problem of human management of the planet Earth? Then all efforts on a regional level to escape the crisis would be doomed to fail in the long term. Or is the regional level suitable to implement other economic and lifestyle options that can successfully counter the various crises of global development (economically, ecologically, socially) with independent sustainability paths? While the initial contributions to the volume deal with this fundamental question, the further contributions take a stance in favor of the possibilities of regional sustainability: Economic approaches to regional economic cycles Ecological and energetic contributions to sustainable settlement policy Approaches to social sustainability under the challenges of global demands Questions of control of regional and social sustainability Aspects of densification Reduction of local conflicts.

Social Entrepreneurship : Perspectives for Urban Development ; [Workshop "Social Entrepreneurs in Germany - Spatial Demands and Spatial Effects"] ¤ Although social innovation ability has become a topic of increasing discussion in political and scientific debates in recent years, its potential for urban development has been explored only to a limited extent so far. Social inequalities and spatial disparities, however, require new solution models in the face of the consequences of globalization and the withdrawal of the welfare state. In this context, people in industrialized countries are increasingly relying on individuals who, as 'Social Entrepreneurs', address social problems with innovative approaches and entrepreneurial means. The authors shed light on specific problem areas from a spatial perspective, discuss policy and development frameworks, outline the current state of knowledge, present practical examples, and highlight further research needs, focusing on Germany. Experts from various disciplines, as well as politicians, administrators, consulting institutions, funding organizations, and Social Entrepreneurs themselves, contribute to the discussion. Dr. Petra Jähnke, PD Dr. Gabriela B. Christmann, and Karsten Balgar are employed at the Leibniz Institute for Regional Development and Structural Planning (IRS) in Erkner.

Ecological Balance Assessment of Biogas Plants: Considering the Lower Saxony Conditions ¤ A motivation for this study is particularly the consideration of the Lower Saxony conditions in the ecological balance assessment. The biogas plant systems considered in the different regions of Lower Saxony differ primarily from each other in terms of the available or used substrate types. While in the agricultural region of South Lower Saxony no fertilizer as a substrate is available, the utilization of manure from local animal husbandry operations is not a problem for the plants in the processing and mixing region. The plant from the dairy farming region is characterized by the fact that grass silage from the prevailing grassland in the region is used as a substrate. The availability of alternative energy crops is lower in this region, as the arable land is occupied for the cultivation of animal feed. The choice of the used substrates has a significant impact on the results of the ecological balance. This effect is particularly evident with the substrates fertilizer and grass silage. The use of fertilizer has a positive effect on the ecological balance in two ways. On the one hand, there are almost no environmental impacts for the provision of fertilizer, as no environmental burden is assigned to production for the reasons mentioned in Section 4.3. As a second positive aspect, the treatment of fertilizer in the biogas plant is to be mentioned, which leads to a reduction in methane emissions compared to the reference system. In contrast, grass silage from grassland use results in higher potential ammonia emissions compared to the cultivation of energy crops in arable farming. Due to the fact that a nutrient balance is carried out by fertilization for the grass yields, the ammonia emissions must be taken into account in the ecological assessment. [...] (Source: Author)

Mythography in Modern Times : Models and Methods in Literature, Art, and Science ¤ Since antiquity, mythographic handbooks have played a significant role in the dissemination of mythological knowledge. The knowledge of ancient myths served literature, the arts, and sciences with a virtually inexhaustible supply of ideas, which have been expressed in various forms. That myths are ?readable? on a meaningful level, which goes beyond their superficial meaning, is by no means self-evident. It is the merit of the mythographers from antiquity to modern times to have experimented with forms of mythological allegoresis, which found their impact in the aforementioned areas. This integral view of modern mythography is the guiding idea of the present volume, which explores the topic through selected case studies.

Current Discourses in Social Economy III ¤ Economic issues, terminology, and concepts are gaining more importance in practice and scientific discourse of the social sector. The book deals with current issues from social economy and social management. It documents contributions from three specialist conferences of the Federal Association of Social Management/Social Economy (BAG SM/SW) e.V. from the years 2018 and 2019. The content Organizational networks weave: nodes and edges in children's and youth work manage Refugee integration management Effectiveness- and socially-oriented school social work The target groups Students and lecturers of social work/social economy/social management Professionals and management staff from the field of social work/social economy/social management The editor Prof. Dr. Ludger Kolhoff is head of the Master's program in social management at Ostfalia University of Applied Sciences - University of Braunschweig/Wolfenbüttel and chairman of the Federal Association of Social Management/Social Economy at universities e.V. Organizational networks weave: nodes and edges in children's and youth work manage -- Refugee integration management -- Effectiveness- and socially-oriented school social work.

EU Enlargement : New Chances for Europe?! : Proceedings of the 9th Leutherheider Forum of the Adalbert-Stiftung-Krefeld in cooperation with the Rhineland-Westphalian Institute for Economic Research Essen from January 16 to 19, 1997 ¤ The reform countries of Eastern Europe are knocking with force on the doors of the European Union. Ten countries have already submitted an application for membership in the community and will - although probably not all with equal priority - now enter the process of accession negotiations. The accession candidates see EU membership primarily as economic and political opportunities. But does not an enlargement also mean a chance for the EU itself? It would not be the first time that an institution is only able to implement overdue reforms from within under external pressure. The title of the conference, which this volume reports on, was therefore also "EU Enlargement - New Chances for Europe?!". In addition to the advantages, the risks of an enlargement were also discussed. In this fast-paced time, it has certainly become clearer since the conference (January 1997) regarding the schedule and procedure for the enlargement; however, little has changed in the fundamental problems.

Sensitive Language History Education : From Theory to Empiricism to Pragmatism ¤ Cover -- Title Page -- Imprint -- Table of Contents -- Christiane Bertram, Andrea Kolpatzik -- Introduction to the Conference Proceedings -- „Sensitive Language History Education

Be Clean ...! ¤ Be Clean ...! focuses on the numerous areas of life that have been increasingly influenced by hygiene measures and public health care since the 19th century. The steadily growing knowledge since the beginning of scientific hygiene research in the 18th century has led to better living conditions and a significantly higher life expectancy - at least in Europe and the >western world<. Topics of this catalog include, among other things, hygiene in everyday life, the medical-scientific field, and >Hygiene and Society<. This volume offers a wide range of scientific contributions, illustrated with large-format images, which deal with, for example, the history of the plague, the myth of (purifying) water, or the cultural history of public baths. Special aspects such as tropical hygiene, air purification, or the detours of racial hygiene are presented by recognized experts. Finally, the volume also deals with the psychological dimension of hygiene, e.g. in connection with beauty ideals or cleanliness neuroses. -An entertaining chapter of our cultural history -From the plague and cholera of the past to the cleanliness neurosis of the present

Labor Market and State Guidance: Reports and Discussions at the Conference of the Association of German Public Law Scholars in Heidelberg from 6 to 9 October 1999 ¤ State and Religion - Wilfried Fiedler ; Gerhard Robbers ; Michael Brenner Frontmatter -- Content -- Annual Conference 1999 -- 1949-1999 Address of the Chairman Christian Starck -- First Agenda Item: Labor Market and State Guidance -- Second Agenda Item: State and Religion -- List of Speakers -- List of Members of the Association of German Public Law Scholars -- Statutes
Television as a "Relationship Box" : Parasocial Relationships and Interactions with TV-Persons ¤ Table of Contents: BEGIN Klappentext: In the center of the book are both the

The Case Law of the ECJ and its Influence on National Private Law Orders ¤ The binding final decision on the interpretation of Union law lies with the ECJ. Regularly, such a decision affects the national legal orders. Often, the ECJ has to decide on the interpretation of directives that affect national private law in the context of a preliminary ruling procedure. The consequence of such a decision is regularly the change of the legal situation in the member states. The change of national private law can take place in different ways. In question is, for example, the change of national case law or laws in the member states. The present volume exemplarily shows how and in what way the case law of the Court of Justice has affected various areas of law from Spanish and German private law (e.g. sales law, consumer protection law and competition law. With contributions from Tatiana Arroyo Vendrell(University Carlos III of Madrid), Markus Artz (University of Bielefeld), Beate Gsell(Ludwig-Maximilians-University Munich), Carmen Jerez Delgado (Autonomous University of Madrid), Johann Kindl (University of Münster), Julia Ludwigkeit (University of Bielefeld), Natalia Mato Pacín (University Carlos III of Madrid), David Ramos Munoz (University Carlos III of Madrdi), Reiner Schulze (University of Münster)

Progress, Norm, and Nonconformity: Explorations of Everyday Life in the GDR ¤ Synopsis Ten years after the end of the GDR, it seems as if the memories are drifting further and further apart. How did people really live in the GDR? What was everyday life like between collectivism and individuality, between pay and honor, luxury and basic supply? A group of cultural scientists and historians has pursued these questions and has more closely examined important areas of everyday life. The objects being considered range from the small postage stamp, in which a whole country is reflected, to industrial large-scale enterprises that operated their own kindergartens, polyclinics, and cosmetics studios. The experiences of people are the starting point for all investigations, regardless of whether it is about the equal rights of women or the situation in trade and supply. Clearly recognizable, in addition to the

Corporate Governance and Corruption : economic-ethical and moral-economic perspectives of bribery and its combating ¤ Corruption is increasingly becoming a significant burden for the social and economic development of developing, emerging, and industrial countries. Among economists, the notion was long prevalent that it could show beneficial effects under certain conditions as a

The Vitality of Critical Social Theory: Documentation of the Work Conference on the Occasion of Theodor W. Adorno's 100th Birthday, July 4-6, 2003 at Johann Wolfgang Goethe University, Frankfurt am Main ¤ Is Adorno's work historically become and its impact past? Or can the vitality of his critical social theory and its motives be spoken of? This question, to be examined without illusions and without prejudice, was the focus of the Frankfurt Work Conference on the occasion of Adorno's 100th birthday. Representatives from all areas in which Adorno has had an impact present their work as examples. The range extends from faithful continuation to the attempt to work out what was left unexecuted by Adorno, to the content and methodical re-description of tasks up to the criticism of the limitations of the Adornian approach. Whoever wants to examine the initial question through material analyses and is not already theoretically decided will be involved in a varied and instructive way with the possible answers through this volume.
Experience with Generation Difference ¤ Table of Contents: BEGIN END

Vision.Stadt : Projects for the Urban Development of Oldenburg and the Competition "Leuchtzeichen" ; [documenting the exhibitions about the "Vision.Stadt" in the Mohrmann-Hall...as well as the exhibition of the "Leuchtzeichen"-designs in the GSG Oldenburg and the built Oldenburg Art Course "Leuchtzeichen" in the period from May to November 2005 ... "Century Step 05" ... from May 21, 2005 to November 27, 2005] ¤ [Tradition - Innovation - Vision ; this publication of the Building Department of the City of Oldenburg and the Project Management of Century Step 05 documents the exhibitions about the "Vision.Stadt" in the Mohrmann-Hall at Pferdemarkt as well as the exhibition of the "Leuchtzeichen"-designs in the GSG Oldenburg and the built Oldenburg Art Course "Leuchtzeichen" in the period from May to November 2005] / Frank-Egon Pantel ; Ralf Rummel-Suhrcke (Ed.)

Technological Knowledge: Emergence, Methods, Structures ¤ With the conference 'Technological Knowledge', acatech made a significant contribution to the discussion on formulating a self-understanding of technological sciences in its first year as the German Academy of Technical Sciences. The interdisciplinary contributions focused on questions of the emergence, method, and structure of technological knowledge, and thus the continuation of a systematization of technological sciences. Against the background of the discussions, the conference contributions reflect the methodological, theoretical, and formal foundations of technological sciences. Technological Knowledge. Emergence — Methods — Structures. An Introduction -- Technological Knowledge. Emergence — Methods — Structures. An Introduction -- Practical Skills and Technical Experience -- „From Adversity One Becomes Wise ...? How Technology Gains Knowledge“ -- The Pragmatics of Technological Knowledge Or: „How To Do Words With Things“ -- Technological Scientific Knowledge. Design, Problems, and Methods -- Values, Knowledge, and Knowledge Integration in Technological Sciences. Systematic and Historical Considerations -- How Can Technology Be Represented? How Are Representations of Technology Understood? -- On the Heuristic Function of Technical Drawing -- The Hermeneutics of Technological Knowledge and the Future of Education -- Logical Structures of Technological Knowledge — On the Theory of Science of Technological Sciences -- Perspectives of an Innovation-Oriented Technological Science -- Knowledge Trends — Research Trends — Technology Trends -- Market-Oriented Technological Science -- Performance and Limits of Virtuality in Knowledge Acquisition -- What is Societally Relevant Science? -- Technological Knowledge as a Guide to Action — A Paradigm for a Theory of Technological Knowledge?.

Courage to Laziness : The Work and Its Fate ¤ Work is apparently the decisive source for the prosperity, value, and dignity of humans. But what is work? Is this identical with gainful employment? And is the human being actually a naturally working being that falls into a crisis without a job? Would it not be time to fundamentally think about the value and essence of work and also to pay more attention to other possibilities of action and ways of existence of humans again? At the 21st Philosophicum Lech, representatives from philosophy, sociology, and adjacent sciences asked how much courage it takes to think of a society in which everything does not revolve around work.

Temporalität und Form : Configurations of Aesthetic and Historical Consciousness ; Author Colloquium with Karl Heinz Bohrer [December 2002] ¤ The literary scholar and MERKUR editor living in Paris and London, Karl Heinz Bohrer, has exerted a far-reaching impact beyond the borders of the Federal Republic with his contributions to aesthetic theory formation and his interventions in the cultural and socio-political discourse of modernity. The volume documents the contributions of an author colloquium dedicated to Bohrer, which brought together renowned representatives of the philosophical, art and literary theoretical disciplines in Bielefeld, the long-time workplace of the currently teaching scholar in Stanford and New York. The colloquium not only provides the first systematic engagement with Bohrer's work, but can also be read as a preliminary balance of the achievements of post-Adornian aesthetics. With contributions, inter alia, from Vittoria Borsò, Rüdiger Bubner, Volker Gerhardt, Hans Ulrich Gumbrecht, Hannelore Schlaffer, Martin Seel, Victor Stoichita, Wilhelm Voßkamp and Rainer Warning

What does subject-oriented history didactics mean? : Contributions to theory, empiricism, and pragmatics ¤ The 'subject-orientation' appears only at first glance as an exaggerated description of the almost clichéd principle that learners should be 'picked up where they stand'. In fact, it reaches much further, because it places the orientation towards the learning subject even stronger than before on a theoretically-methodical basis. The present volume shows the diversity that subject-orientation has been shaped by so far and which enriches the historical didactic discourse

The Sisters of Icarus : Woman and Flight ; [in conjunction with the exhibition "The Sisters of Icarus - Woman and Flight", which will be shown at the Zeppelin Museum Friedrichshafen from June 04 to September 26, 2004] ¤ They demanded the 'half of the sky' - but on the way there, women are often confronted with insurmountable obstacles. Aviatrixes, who early on demanded an equal place in aviation, encountered rejection, resistance, and unfair treatment. Retreats into the typical female role of mother and housewife, career changes, economic hardship, or even suicide could be the result. Aviation history is still presented as a success story of men. But since the invention of the balloon in 1783, women have been intensively involved in aviation. They have developed the technology and set records. For most, it was still difficult to break out of the shadow of men and make their achievements visible, although they had notable successes. Balloonists, parachutists, sailplane and motor pilots, technicians, scientists, and astronauts were not evaluated according to their real achievements, but were seen within the limits of the prevailing female role. But even the pioneers of aviation faced the experience of the border between life and death. They, like their male colleagues, consciously sought 'debordering' and were border-crossers who risked a 'sensational ascent' - whether into the air or into another social class. As 'Sisters of Icarus', they often shared his tragic fate. The companion book to the exhibition 'The Sisters of Icarus - Woman and Flight' puts the role of women at the center of the consideration. The collection of scientific contributions deals with the entire spectrum of the theme Woman and Flight: From the pioneers of aviation to the role of women in sports, military, and commercial aviation to space travel and the impact of the flight theme in the work of women artists. <CR>From the content: <CR>Maria Osietzki: 'Flight is worth the life' - Debordering female life designs in the history of aviation <CR>Heike Vogel: Early balloonists and pilots - Obstacles and strategies for implementation <CR>Gundula Wolter: Sensational sports costumes - The clothing of the aviation pioneers <CR>Guillaume de Syon: Engines of Emancipation? - Women's Flying Clubs before World War II <CR>Gertrud Pfister: Records, victories, sensations - Pi...

Common man, society and religion in the 16th century : piety, morality and discipline in the Carpathian Basin ¤ The bilingual volume brings together, in part, groundbreaking results of an interdisciplinary research conference, whose contributions address social, economic, cultural, and ecclesiastical historical aspects of the early modern period in the Carpathian arc. Based on sources evaluated for the first time in many cases, the contributions deal with current research questions and research horizons on the interdependence of social, economic, cultural, and religious phenomena in the Carpathian arc of the early modern period, in which the Ottomans became the internationally dominant political factor. Transformation processes were triggered by population and military movements, economic, political, and religious-mental upheavals, which oscillated between opportunistic adaptation and rebellious resistance and correspondingly triggered political measures and counter-reactions. In doing so, the prevailing research opinion on the history of tolerance in Transylvania is called into question and completely revalued

Corporate Tertiarization : The Holistic Transformation from a Production Enterprise to a Service-Oriented Problem Solver ¤ The transformation from an industrial to a service-oriented society is ongoing. As a result of this shift towards the tertiary sector, there is a constantly increasing demand for services, and former pure goods producers are therefore increasingly developing into holistic problem solvers. The authors of this volume investigate the challenges that companies face on their way from a production enterprise to a service-oriented problem solver. Topics include: " The transformation of corporate culture and the establishment of corresponding organizational structures, " appropriate personnel development, qualification, and motivation, " service-specific organizational development, " strategy development for the service business, " development and design of performance portfolios and individual services, " appropriate IT development

Eva's Bite : Female Aggression and its Realities ; [Conference 1994] ¤ Eva's Bite is a collection on the topic of 'Female Aggression and its Realities'. Neither is it the 'peaceful woman' nor the unbridled destructive woman, who served as a model for the authors. Aggressive women are socially ostracized because it is not socially acceptable to think of aggression and femininity together. The myth of the 'peaceful woman' is exposed as a social construct, against which one can rebel. It is also a rebellion against the victim discourse, in which women are only given space because they are victims. Instead of clinging to the traditional patriarchal discourse, the authors try to find new ways. They approach the topic without destroying its contradictions and complexity, on the way of overcoming language clichés. Finding a new language is partly necessary to name the unspoken, ostracized, and taboo. On this basis, new freer role models can emerge. The collection contains material on mythological backgrounds, case descriptions, as well as a literary text by Elfriede Jelinek.

Translating wor(l)ds : Christianity across cultural boundaries ¤ This book addresses the translation of culture in the context of religion. The contributions, which analyse texts in literary, ethnohistorical and/or linguistic terms, show how different cultural traditions and languages are communicated across boundaries. They include studies of the missionary context of the Early Middle Ages and of colonially dominated cultures in Latin America, India, China, Africa and Australia, from the 16th to the early 20th century; and they analyse literary works with respect to how they transmit and translate culture: one a Christian play in the context of Islam, the other one a novel of the Haitian diaspora in the USA; another contribution presents the challenges of how the concept of religion itself is conveyed in contemporary scholarly contexts. By using different methodological tools, the authors show the manifold and innovative ways in which this field of the translation of culture can be approached. With contributions byGwilym Colenso, Fiona Darroch, Sabine Dedenbach-Salazar Sáenz, Pär Eliasson, Sarah Irving, Alison Jasper, David Moore, Brian Murdoch, Richard H. Roberts, Frauke Sachse, Roxana Sarion.

A Chair Makes History : [on the occasion of the exhibition "A Chair Makes History" at Bauhaus Dessau (August 22 - October 25, 1992), at Vitra Design Museum, Weil am Rhein (November 6, 1992 - March 28, 1993), at Museum for Art and Craft Hamburg (April 16 - June 13, 1993) etc.] ¤ Freischwinger -- Design classics -- Design classics -- Mart Stam -- Mies van der Rohe -- Rasch Brothers -- Marcel Breuer

Cultural Nation France? : The Cultural Dimension of Social Change ¤ More than in other countries, culture and education are constitutive components of the French nation and hold a high value for politics and society. Traditionally, the French elite attributes a universal, beyond-France significance to their culture. In recent years, these basic convictions have been questioned both internationally and in the domestic context. The France Yearbook 2011 takes up this debate. In the French domestic view, it is about the culturally shaped self-awareness of the Republic and the Nation, while in the external view, the transformations of cultural foreign policy are illuminated.

Religious Pluralism and Tolerance in Europe : [3rd Constance European Colloquium, which took place from April 21 to 23, 2005 on the topic "Together - With Each Other - For Each Other. Religious Pluralism and Tolerance in Europe"] ¤ Europe is traversed by open and latent religious fields of tension, from which a colorful spectrum of current problem situations emerges: The examples range from disputes over headscarves, crucifixes, and mosque construction to the topics of migration and integration, to religious fundamentalism and terrorist violence. The anthology offers an interdisciplinary forum for dealing with the diverse historical and contemporary aspects of these phenomena. In this context, the basic principles and trends of European history are examined, the interaction and tension relationship between religious pluralism and the idea of tolerance is problematized, the danger of fundamentalism is illuminated, and the constitutional and politically-social situation in Europe is analyzed. The anthology is intended to make a significant contribution to a better understanding of the complex theme complex. - Europe, the tolerant continent? - The legacy of ancient pluralism - The legacy of the Middle Ages - At the confessional border - Fascism and National Socialism - Tolerance and recognition - Tolerance in times of intercultural conflicts - Pluralism and tolerance from the perspective of Christianity - Pluralism and tolerance from the perspective of Islam - Consequences for Jews, Christians, and Muslims in Europe - Considerations in view of the Jewish creation idea - The speech about the "Christian Occident" - Civil society and religion - Law, religion, and tolerance - Tariq Ramadan et al.

Currency - Crisis - Emotion : Collective Perceptions of Economic Crises ¤ The diverse forms of expression of recent economic crises and the current challenges in Europe make it clear that the economy, which is still considered rational, needs to be examined in relation to its parallel developed 'strongly specialized emotional culture' (Eva Illouz). This is particularly evident in crisis discourses in politics, press, economy, or literature, where emotions are clearly visible as a collective 'form of mental attitude or attitude towards the world' (Richard Wollheim). The contributors to the volume examine the emotional dimensions of these crisis discourses in the past and present from the perspectives of sociology, economics, cultural, historical, and literary studies.

Jewish History in Hellenistic-Roman Times: Ways of Research: From the Old to the New Schürer ¤ The German Protestant historian and theologian Emil Schürer was the first to deal scientifically with Judaism at the time of the Second Temple in his ";History of the Jewish People in the Time of Jesus Christ";. The fact that Schürer's work was re-published and translated into English nearly 100 years later gave rise to the question of how research on Jewish history in Hellenistic-Roman times developed in the 19th and 20th centuries.

Early Attachments and Moral Development: Current Findings on Psychological and Social Conditions of Moral Autonomy ¤ This volume brings together attachment research and research on moral development based on Kohlberg's theory, attempting to link these two fields. At the center is the question of the social and psychological conditions of moral development and moral action. Under what conditions do children and adolescents develop in such a way that they build a stable moral motivation? Different aspects of morally relevant action are in focus: the exercise of violence and law-breaking, empathy and sensitivity to the needs of those close to them, the observance of moral core norms in conflicts of interest, personal commitment in the fight for fairer social conditions. The debates associated with these topics lead to convergent assessments in important points, but also open up further research questions with controversies.

Evaluation (in) the Educational Science ¤ Evaluation is currently not only used as an instrument of educational science self-observation, but also for scientific policy control. Institutional and professional specifics of educational science determine the difficulties of evaluating their performances and the profiling of their disciplinary shape. The volume offers with its contributions theoretical, empirical, and comparative perspectives to analyze criteria and results of evaluation of educational science. It takes into account, in particular, also experiences of other disciplines and nations. Furthermore, the volume deals with the evaluation of educational institutions, describes experiences and discusses limits and possibilities of educational science to contribute to the evaluation of educational practice fields. It stands in the field of empirical science research of educational science and current science and education policy.

The Digital Library and Its Right - a Stepchild of the Information Society? : Cultural Aspects, Technical Backgrounds and Legal Challenges of the Digital Cultural Memory ; [Proceedings of the Event 'The Digital Library and Its Right - a Stepchild of the Information Society?', which took place on September 6 and 7, 2012 at the Marriott Hotel in Cologne and was jointly organized by the University of Cologne, the Training Foundation for Law and Social Sciences at the University of Cologne and the University Library Center of North Rhine-Westphalia] ¤ Numerous information and cultural expressions are now only available in digital form. This facilitates access to content and its exchange on the one hand. On the other hand, however, the question arises as to how future generations will have access to the digitalia of the present as historical sources and as testimonies of our culture. This question is usually understood technically in the sense of the durability and readability of data carriers. Conversely, little attention has been paid to the legal difficulties that arise when building a digital cultural memory. It is only certain that the conditions, information, and cultural expressions to be stored have fundamentally changed compared to the analog age with its predominantly printed media. The reason for this lies on the one hand in the enormous public potential, especially of online publications, and on the other hand in the simple fact that digitalia always experience a multiplication when used and thus touch the copyright. The present collection, which documents a Cologne conference of the same name, deals with the legal framework conditions to be observed when building a digital cultural memory from different perspectives. In particular, it should be investigated whether the legal side of the digital library will require greater attention in the future, so that the established memory and remembrance culture of the present is not replaced in the future by a digital amnesia prescribed by law.

Marriage Splitting and Family Policy ¤ In the context of the current family policy discussion, the target accuracy of incentives and, in this context, also marriage splitting is on the agenda. The symposium held at the University of Hohenheim,

Table Society of the Future: On an Ethics of Nutrition; Hannah-Arendt Lectures and the 17th Hannah-Arendt Days 2014 ¤ In the present volume, the authors of the Hannah Arendt Lectures and Hannah Arendt Days 2014 in Hanover deal with the problem of eating from different perspectives. The book documents this equally politically current and ethically sensitive debate about a table society of the future and works out the systematic connection between philosophy and gastrosophy, which Hannah Arendt claimed. Its core is the realization that our eating is not a purely private matter, but always also a political action. Content: Bernd Ladwig takes up the specifically animal-ethical perspective in his contribution "Why animals do not belong on our plates." Corinna Mieth considers the topic of meat consumption from the perspective of a consumer ethics based on the distinction between strong and weak duties. Ingo Pies considers the question of how to address hunger in the world from the perspective of business ethics. Christian Meyer describes what a minister must do in his daily business to actively work towards a table society of the future. Hilal Sezgin represents a radical animal rights morality that doubts whether something like humane animal husbandry is even possible. Hartmut Stützel finally shifts the focus from animals to humans by asking about the consequences for a grain cultivation that can not only adequately feed the (global) population, but also meet ethical and ecological requirements. (Publisher's advertising)

The Productivity of the Social — Activating the Social State: Sixth Federal Congress of Social Work ¤ The "Federal Congress of Social Work" serves the transfer of knowledge between theory and practice of social work, the understanding of practitioners and scientists about the current social problems and uncertainties, about their specific forms of expression and about the tasks that arise from social work. Under the thematic orientation "The Productivity of the Social - Activating the Social State" the volume documents contributions of the congress of 2005 and gives new impulses for theoretical clarification and the development of practice models oriented towards action. The Productivity of the Social - Activating the Social State -- The Productivity of the Social - Activating the Social State -- Shaping the Productivity of the Social through Social Work -- Where does the Productivity of the Social come from? Approaches to an analysis of their productive forces -- Education for all - On the educational mandate of social work -- Future of Work -- Free Providers - Welfare Associations as Producers of the Social? -- Does the democratic civil society come after the dismantling of the (Social) State? Religious fundamentalism and the limited scope of theories of social work -- Islam and Integration - a contradiction? A sociological plea for a new attention -- The economization of the social as a question of gender relations - for a policy of intervention -- European integration and gender relations -- Effects of gender relations on social work in Europe -- On the productivity of intergenerational relationships in child and youth work -- Utilizing the potential of aging - opportunities for the individual and society -- Requirements for a new social professionalism in an aging society -- Civic engagement as an option for a self-determined shaping of aging and goal orientation in open elderly care -- Civic engagement in social change! -- Social work and empowerment - some critical comments on the search for a political social work -- Social movements as struggles for social participation or: The rhythmicization of the social space -- Activating the Social State through Social Work -- The solidarity of the social state - The solidarity of the reformed social state -- Political participation and recognition in the context of social work -- Client - customer - user - comrade?! -- Social work as applied social policy - a European perspective -- The expansion of the European Union and social work -- The future of social work as a profession - a federal republic search movement

The Law of the 'Soldier Emperors': Legal Stability in Times of Political Upheaval? ; [Contributions of an interdisciplinary international conference, which took place from 10-12 April 2013 at the Historical Seminar and the Institute of Law of the University of Zurich under the title 'Law of the Soldier Emperors'] ¤ The contributions in this volume investigate continuities and breaks in the legal system of the 'Soldier Emperors': How do crisis and law relate to each other? Can changes in legal development be explained by political instability? Are regional special paths also legally justifiable? Do peculiarities in private law appear? By means of the legal sources, a multifaceted image of an epoch marked by upheavals emerges.

Paradoxes of Consumer Behavior: Documentation of the 2017 Annual Conference of the Consumer Research Network ¤ The 2017 annual conference of the Consumer Research Network aimed to explore paradoxes, contradictions, and ambivalences in consumer daily life and analyze the associated implications. Renowned representatives from politics and society discuss in this conference volume the concrete behavior of consumers in their socio-economic contexts and shed light on possible consequences for consumer sciences and consumer policy. The conference contributions documented in this book identify current and future research needs and aim to promote the transfer of knowledge and experiences from science actors like consumer-related practice. The content • Privacy in online shopping • Paradoxes of IT system use • On the tension between fashion and sustainability • Contradictions of digitalization for sustainable consumption • Consumer policy implications • Consequences for consumer research The editors Univ.-Prof. Dr. Birgit Blättel-Mink is Professor of Sociology with a focus on industrial and organizational sociology at the Institute of Sociology of Goethe University Frankfurt. Since 2015, she has been a member of the coordination committee of the Consumer Research Network of the Federal Ministry of Justice and Consumer Protection (BMJV). Univ.-Prof. Dr. Peter Kenning is holder of the chair for business administration, especially marketing, at Heinrich Heine University Düsseldorf. He is speaker of the coordination committee of the Consumer Research Network at the Federal Ministry of Justice and Consumer Protection (BMJV) Keynote -- Privacy -- Information -- Sustainable consumption -- Panel discussion: Paradoxes of consumer behavior - Consumer policy implications -- Final word: Paradoxes of consumer behavior and consequences for consumer research

Manifestations in the Design Process : Design - Architecture - Engineering ¤ Den in the design process developed artifacts are given too little public and scientific attention, as are the things of our designed world. The book deals with the epistemic role of the manifestations emerging in the design process, making intentions, methods, and creative processes readable. The contributions from and about design, architecture, and engineering present an interdisciplinary inventory, asking for a new interdisciplinary perspective on design in the field of tension between analog and digital planning and technical processes.

Iconology of the Performative ¤ We live in a world of images - so is the iconic turn stated in the humanities and social sciences. At the same time, we live in a performative culture, in which performances, stagings, and rituals are gaining importance. Images play a central role in the performative character of language as well as in the staging and perception of social or artistic actions. Images are events. They develop a specific power and ambiguity in performative performances and stagings, which is connected to enigmatic, transgressive, and liminal states. In this scenic-processual tension, collective and individual images mix, which cannot be reduced to textualization alone or simply bypassed. To what extent and to what benefit can an iconology of the performative be spoken, the authors discuss in structural, historical, and methodological terms. Both culture-specific and cross-cultural image patterns, collective and individual image spaces, performativity in images, and images as performative media are addressed. The contributions come from anthropology, art history, media and image science, communication science, history, education science, sociology, philosophy, and ethnomethodology

Regional Development Policy between Centralization and Balance: Consequences for the Design at State Level ¤ The current occasion for the workshop were the preparations of the state and its regional actors for the new funding period of the EU Structural Funds with a clearly intensified and broadened instrumentarium of regional policy interventions. The new opportunities of especially intensive funding in the former administrative district of Lüneburg, which has been classified as convergence objective 1, as well as the wide range of interventions in the rest of the country require focus and priority settings that are oriented towards the development bottlenecks and opportunities of the regions and the state as a whole. This volume is intended to contribute to this discussion (Source: NIW)

Excess : from Excess in Religion, Art and Philosophy ¤ Excessive celebration, unbridled consumption, workaholics or sports fanatics - excess is a central and yet contentious phenomenon of our culture. While some vehemently reject excess and call for moderation, others actively seek out excessive experiences. This tension demands a scientific exploration. From the perspectives of theology, art history, and philosophy, this volume inquires into the reality of excesses. The contributions discuss the meanings of excess in different contexts and seek action perspectives.

The Ten Commandments: A Contradictory Legacy? ¤ The Ten Commandments have permeated the norms and values of cultures shaped by the Jewish-Christian tradition up to the present day. But are the biblical commandments still determinations by which we can orient ourselves unbrokenly today? And do the dark sides of our history and present also go back to them? Notable contributors such as Jan Assmann, Hermann Deuser, Horst Dreier, Hanna-Barbara Gerl-Falkovitz, and Dietmar Mieth reflect in this volume what the Ten Commandments meant at the time of their promulgation and what they can mean to us today. Central themes such as the prohibition on murder, the prohibitions on desire, the prescription of monogamy, and the prohibition on images are each presented with a more skeptical and a reflectively positive voice. The fundamental relationship between the ethos of love and the morality of commandments is also taken into account in the considerations. Thus, a multifaceted image emerges that is of interest to all who ask about the foundations of law and morality in the present - regardless of whether they are believers or unbelievers.

Conditions for Local Citizen Participation ¤ The book provides an overview of different forms of local citizen participation as we find them at the beginning of the 21st century in Germany. In the background, the question stands of how representative democracy can be adapted to the new social and political challenges of the 21st century. What opportunities and risks are associated with the participation forms that have developed in recent years, particularly at the local level?The book is designed to provide an overview. It shows how the science deals with the topic in a variety of ways. The authors address different questions. They draw, as is appropriate for the topic of local citizen participation, on different research methods. Qualitative and quantitative contributions complement each other. They all share the discussion of the questions about the goals and the conditions for success of different forms of local citizen participation, in order to contribute to further systematization of success and failure conditions.

Universities and Politics in Lower Saxony after 1945 ¤ Universities and Politics after 1945 : an important historical field of study in the regional context / Detlef Schmiechen-Ackermann -- Concealing, interpreting, making useful : on the handling of the NS past at the Technical University of Hanover in the first post-war years / Frauke Steffens -- Between Tradition and Modernity : the "Braunschweig School" of architectural education at the TU/TH Braunschweig after 1945 until the end of the 1960s / Anne Schmedding -- From the task of education : the failed reform experiment of the "University of Work, Politics and Economics" in Wilhelmshaven-Rüstersiel (1949-1962) / Oliver Schael -- Without dignity : the revocation of doctoral titles at the Georg-August University of Göttingen in the "Third Reich" and the long process of rehabilitation after 1945 / Kerstin Thieler -- Legitimization of the responsible : the institutionalization of historical regional research in Lower Saxony / Matthias Martens -- 1968 in Hanover : student movement in the political province / Anna Berlit-Schwigon -- The University of Bremen : founding and establishment period / Birte Gräfing

August Wilhelm Schlegel's Modeling of Literary History ¤ With the rediscovery of August Wilhelm Schlegel (1767–1845) in recent years, the success story of his Berlin lectures „Lectures on Fine Literature and Art“ (1801–1804) and his Vienna lectures „On Dramatic Art and Literature“ (1808) also came into focus. The two public lecture series aimed to rethink and reconceive the history of art and poetry with a focus on a „romantic“ tradition. How this new conception was concretized, what patterns it set, and what scientific and cultural policy intentions it pursued, are answered by the contributions brought together in this volume. They do not only address the question of the tension between a national and a cosmopolitan conception of literary history writing at Schlegel, but also take up genre-theoretical, translational, and comparative questions.

Problems of Municipal Finance ¤ This volume contains the contributions presented at the conference of the Financial Science Committee of the Verein für Socialpolitik in Konstanz in 2000 on the topic "Problems of municipal finance". -- At the center of Wolfgang Scherf's work "Perspectives of municipal taxation" is the proposal to replace the trade tax in favor of a value-added tax, which is deductible from the value-added tax - alternatively from the income tax. Gisela Färber deals with "Theory and practice of municipal fee calculation". -- In the practice-oriented focus, the federal German legal framework is first presented, then the fee policy is largely shown by the example of the municipality of Speyer. Hans Georg Schmitz examines the traditional municipal accounting system and discusses reform proposals in the following. Karl-Dieter Grüske and Michael Maier deal with the "New Steering Model (NSM)". -- After an analysis of the defects of the traditional communal administration and after an analysis of approaches for a theoretical foundation of an administrative reform, the basic idea, main elements and efficiency potentials of the NSM are presented and evaluated on the municipal level.

Crimes of the Wehrmacht: Dimensions of the War of Annihilation 1941-1944; Exhibition Catalogue ¤ The war against the Soviet Union differed from all wars of European modernity, including those led by the German Wehrmacht in other countries during World War II. It was a war that targeted not only another army, but also parts of the civilian population. The Jewish population was to be murdered, non-Jews were to be decimated by hunger and terror and employed as forced labor. This criminal conduct did not arise from the escalation of the war, but was already part of the war plans. For what happened during the German occupation in the East, the war plans were only a determining factor. Furthermore, each individual case was shaped by concrete action conditions, determined by current influences and influenced by the behavior and action patterns of the actors. The war and international law in force at the time contained a number of internationally recognized principles that were to be observed in every war. Civilians and prisoners of war were under special protection. Although war law allowed for measures that were deeply inhumane and did not regulate every case, it did draw a clear line between right and wrong. - The exhibition 'Crimes of the Wehrmacht. Dimensions of the War of Annihilation 1941-1944' shows, based on the war and international law in force at the time, the involvement of the Wehrmacht in the crimes committed on the war fronts in the East and Southeast Europe during World War II. It documents a total of six dimensions of the war of annihilation: genocide of Soviet Jews; mass deaths of Soviet prisoners of war; war of hunger; deportations of forced laborers; partisan war; reprisals and hostage shootings. The exhibition shows the partial active and partial passive involvement of the Wehrmacht in the committed crimes. The research on this topic so far does not allow any statements about the number of German soldiers and officers involved. Nevertheless, the exhibition also shows the concrete behavior of individual persons. In the 'action spaces' it is demonstrated that the war of annihilation was not a place of abstract dynamics, but of tiered decisions and individual responsibilities.

Das Handwerk der Seefahrt im Zeitalter der Industrialisierung : [the contributions ... were presented and discussed at a conference held from May 5-8, 1994, at the University of Bremen] ¤ The question that the book poses and answers is: How has traditional seafaring, customs, working and living conditions of sailors changed since the beginning of industrialization and the resulting changes in German shipping? In particular, the aspect of what has been preserved is of interest. Competent experts from various disciplines (technology, economics, cultural and social sciences, art) approach the difficult-to-delimit topic from their respective angle. Their essays, which are thematically far apart, provide a comprehensive overview of the connections for those interested in maritime history. The numerous references to literature help with a deeper understanding. (2)

Law and Diversity: Local Configurations and Global Perspectives from the Early Modern Period to the Present ¤ Parallel justice, antidiscrimination laws, and the transfer of law - the theme of 'Law and Diversity' connects diverse current discussions and proves to be central for the social handling of difference and equality. The contributors to the volume - from history and law science as well as Jewish studies - place this theme in a historical perspective and take configurations and ways of dealing with legal diversity from the Early Modern Period to the present into view. Situations of cultural contact and interreligious coexistence as well as globally acting actors and organizations in Europe, Asia, the Americas, and Africa are illuminated. Frontmatter -- Content -- Foreword & Thanks -- Law and Diversity: Conceptual Considerations and Microhistorical Insights -- 'Le chapeau ou la toque' -- Strangers or Native Sons? -- Sharia according to k. u. k. Ordinance -- Diversity of Law in the Process of Globalization -- Excerpt, Order, Sort -- 'Their Constitution is here completely different from that in the old provinces…' -- The Diversity of Law in Pre-Modern Contact Zones of Asia -- Universal – transnational – local -- List of Contributors

Guaranteeing Family Influence in Family Businesses: Symposium of the Research Center for Family Businesses of the University of Bayreuth on October 6/7, 2016 ¤ To guarantee the influence of the family in family businesses is a crucial factor for the success of those businesses. Their influence is increasingly threatened from the inside and the outside. Internally conflicts within the family – between tribes or generations – about the succession may affect the family influence. Externally the growing number of legal requirements compromise the family influence directly and indirectly. A typical example is the claim for independent board members and the revision of the inheritance tax.The conference transcript documents the current state of scientific research on the influence of the family in family businesses in relation to that topic and at the same time it is devoted to knowledge transfer between science and practice. For this purpose, various instruments to secure family influence in family businesses are analysed and evaluated under different perspectives by considerable experts: for example, advisory boards, foundations, interim management, notarized agreements and common values. Besides the national view this volume also includes a comparative presentation on how Austrian, Swiss and Chinese family businesses deal with this issue. Therefore, the volume points out, that securing the family influence in family businesses is not only a major structural but also an overall challenge – a challenge practice and science must face together.With contributions by:Prof. Dr. Dr. Alexander Brink, Prof. Dr. Jens Prütting, Prof. Dr. Katharina Uffmann, Prof. Dr. Hermut Kormann, Prof. Dr. Knut Werner Lange, Prof. Dr. Susanne Kalss, Dr. Miriam Bird, Prof. Dr. Reinhard Meckl

Regional Integration in Central Asia ¤ The former Soviet republics in Central Asia - Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan - became independent in 1991, without any prior independence movements. However, there is a need for cooperation in many areas for the countries in Central Asia. All Central Asian economies are relatively small and not integrated into the processes of global economic division of labor. Environmental problems, such as the Aral Sea disaster, affect all Central Asian countries. The desired integration into the world market requires the development of a capable infrastructure to transport the exported goods to the world markets. The development towards lasting forms of regional cooperation and integration is a crucial factor in designing sustainable strategies for the further transformation process. Authors from Central Asian countries and Germany examine in this volume the conditions and perspectives of regional integration in Central Asia. They analyze, in addition to the global economic conditions for regional integration, the prospects for the integration process against the background of problematic transformation processes in the individual countries. - Heribert Dieter: Introduction: The Need for Regional Integration in Central Asia - Cord Jakobeit: The Theory of Regional Integration - Alparslan Yenal: Global Economy in Transition: Structural Change and Trends - Elmar Altvater: Regionalization of the World Market - Serik Primbetov: Regional Integration of Central Asian States: Results, Experiences, Problems, and Perspectives - Heribert Dieter: Regional Integration in Central Asia: Economic Situation and Perspectives - Umiserik Kassenow, Klara Rachmetowa: Priorities of Economic Integration of Central Asian Countries - Kurt Hübner: Regional Integration and Payment Union: Chances and Limits of a Central Asian Payment Union (ZAZU) and Western European Experiences - Hansjörg Herr: Currency Cooperation in Central Asia - Advantages, Models, and Requirements - Umiserik Kassenow: The Foreign Economic Strategy of the Republic of Kazakhstan - Thomas Sauer, Thomas Röhm: The Foreign Economic Strategy of Kazakhstan - Turar Koitschujew: Post-Soviet Kyrgyzstan in the World Community - Jan Priewe: Considerations on the Foreign Economic Strategy of Kyrgyzstan - Sanaat Wachidowa: Regional Integration under Transformation Conditions: Economic Reforms and Restructuring in Uzbekistan - Hansjörg Herr: A Foreign Economic Strategy for Uzbekistan - Documentation: Declaration of Almaty of July 8, 1994 - Decision on the Creation of an Intergovernmental Council of July 8, 1994 - Statute of the Executive Committee of the Intergovernmental Council

The Role of Scientific-Technical Expertise in the Approval of Chemical and Nuclear Facilities ¤ Struktur und Zustandekommen sicherheitsrelevanter Bestimmungen in technischen Regelwerken für chemische Anlagen / Gottfried Kremer -- Struktur und Zustandekommen sicherheitsrelevanter Bestimmungen in technischen Regelwerken für kerntechnische Anlagen / Otto-August Kellermann -- Zur rechtlichen Relevanz wissenschaftlich-technischer Regelwerke bei der Genehmigung technischer Anlagen / Fritz Nicklisch -- Struktur und Inhalt der Aussagen wissenschaftlich-technischer Sachverständiger bei der Bewertung des sicherheitstechnischen Gesamtkonzepts technischer Anlagen / Walter Brötz -- Zur rechtlichen Relevanz der Aussagen wissenschaftlich-technischer Sachverständiger bei der Genehmigung grosstechnischer Anlagen / Hellmut Wagner

Child Protection, Children's Rights, Participation : [Documentation of the Expert Conference "Child Protection, Children's Rights, Participation - Ensuring the Well-being of Children", November 15-16, 2007 in Berlin] ¤ Children are equal to adults in value. But not in the same way. Due to developmental facts, children need special protection, special promotion, and special, child-friendly participation forms. The rights laid down in the Convention on the Rights of the Child of the United Nations in this respect establish respect for the human basic values of children.

Integrated Risk and Sustainability Management : Successful Navigation through the Complexity and Dynamics of Risk ¤ Interdisciplinary perspectives on sustainability and risk management -- Sustainability of business models of companies and credit institutions -- Sustainability in personnel work as a critical factor for companies -- Sustainability and risk management in the responsibility of cities and regions. When risks are investigated without considering sustainability, decision-makers are limited because they are surprised by the complexity and dynamics of the risks. The challenges in society and large damages show that there is currently no convincing approach to dealing with risks that includes sustainability. The conference proceedings contain suggestions and solution approaches to linking the topics of risk and sustainability from society, politics, economy, health, and technology. The content Interdisciplinary perspectives on sustainability and risk management Sustainability of business models of companies and credit institutions Sustainability in personnel work as a critical factor for companies Sustainability and risk management in the responsibility of cities and regions The target groups Lecturers and students of economics, law, natural sciences with a focus on sustainability and risk management Decision-makers in the areas of sustainability and risk management The editors Prof. Dr. rer. nat. Achim Michalke, Professorship for Technical Business Management, Faculty of Supply Technology, Ostfalia University of Applied Sciences – University of Braunschweig/Wolfenbüttel Prof. Dr.-Ing. Martin Rambke, Professorship for Forming Technology, Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Ostfalia University of Applied Sciences – University of Braunschweig/Wolfenbüttel Prof. Dr. rer. pol. Stefan Zeranski, Professorship for Financial Services and Financial Management, Brunswick European Law School, Ostfalia University of Applied Sciences – University of Braunschweig/Wolfenbüttel.

Nature and Theory of Emotion ¤ Cognitive neuroscience investigates the mechanisms of perception and recognition as brain processes. In recent years, emotions have been rediscovered and their fundamental, indeed indispensable role in behavior and action has been recognized and appreciated. Not least through these new approaches, psychology and philosophy have turned their attention to these long-neglected phenomena with renewed interest. The present, interdisciplinary volume provides an overview of the diversity of these approaches and the new insights and knowledge gained. The first part is introductory in nature. It provides information on psychological and developmental psychological theories of emotion as well as contributions from new methods such as functional imaging procedures. Furthermore, specific individual topics are discussed in more detail, such as emotions in animals, emotional development in early childhood, and the neurobiological foundations of love and lust. The second part deals with the dysfunction of emotions, for example the field of anxiety and depression and the phenomenon of emotional inhibition, as well as the question of how psychological structure and unconscious emotions are involved in the genesis of pathological phenomena. The third part finally encompasses reflective philosophical moments on the relationship between reason and passion, the affect theory of Kant and Hume, emotions in cross-cultural comparison, and the question of the nature of artificial feelings.

Microwave cavities and detectors for axion research : proceedings of the 2nd International Workshop ¤ Introduction to RF-Structures and Their Design -- Symmetry Breaking in Haloscope Microwave Cavities -- Pound - Drever - Hall frequency locking method -- Evaluation of Commercial Phase Shifters for Cryogenic Applications -- Application of the Bead-Perturbation Technique to a Study of a Tunable 5 GHz Annular Cavity -- Novel Resonant Cavity Designs and Applications to Axion Haloscopes -- PBG cavities for future ADMX -- First test of a photonic band gap structure for ADMX-HF -- Hybrid cavities for axion detectors -- Simulation of Superconducting QUBIT devices -- Detecting Axion Dark Matter with Superconducting Qubits -- First results from a microwave cavity axion search at 24 μeV -- Multiple-cavity detector for axion search -- The ORGAN Experiment -- Searching for Low Mass Axions with an LC Circuit -- ABRACADABRA: A broadband/resonant search for axions -- The QUAX experiment -- Progress on the ARIADNE axion experiment The nature of dark matter remains one of the preeminent mysteries in physics and cosmology. It appears to require the existence of new particles whose interactions to ordinary matter are extraordinarily feeble. One well-motivated candidate is the axion, an extraordinarily light neutral particle that may possibly be detected by looking for their conversion to detectable microwaves in the presence of a strong magnetic field. This has led to a number of experimental searches that are beginning to probe plausible axion model space and may discover the axion in the near future. These proceedings discuss the challenges of designing and operating tunable resonant cavities and detectors at ultralow temperatures. The topics discussed here have potential application far beyond the field of dark matter detection and may be applied to resonant cavities for accelerators as well as designing superconducting detectors for quantum information and computing applications. This work is intended for graduate students and researchers interested in learning the unique requirements for designing and operating microwave cavities and detectors for direct axion searches and to introduce several proposed experimental concepts that are still in the prototype stage. Describes unique designs for microwave cavity axion searches Includes detectors for ultra-low noise microwave applications Presents new methods of axion dark matter detection

Advances in experimental political science ¤ Experimental political science has changed. In two short decades, it evolved from an emergent method to an accepted method to a primary method. The challenge now is to ensure that experimentalists design sound studies and implement them in ways that illuminate cause and effect. They must do so while also respecting ethical boundaries, interpreting results in a transparent manner, and sharing data and research materials to ensure others can build on what has been learned. This book explores the application of new designs; the introduction of novel data sources, measurement approaches, and statistical methods; the use of experiments in more areas; and discipline-wide discussions about the robustness, generalizability, and ethics of experiments in political science. The volume explores these new opportunities while also highlighting the concomitant challenges. The goal is to help scholars and practitioners conduct high-quality experiments that make important contributions to knowledge

Empire and politics in the Eastern and Western civilizations : searching for a ›Respublica Romanosinica‹ ¤ The volume includes the proceedings of the 2nd Roma Sinica project conference held in Seoul in September 2019 and aims to compare some features of the ancient political thought in the Western classical tradition and in the Eastern ancient thought. The contributors, coming from Korea, Europe, USA, China, Japan, propose new patterns of interpretation of the mutual interactions and proximities between these two cultural worlds and offer also a perspective of continuity between contemporary and ancient political thought. Therefore, this book is a reference place in the context of the comparative research between Roman (and early Greek thought) and Eastern thought. Researchers interested in Cicero, Seneca, Plato, post-Platonic and post Aristotelic philosophical schools, history, ancient Roman and Chinese languages could find interesting materials in this work

Lake Baikal : a mirror in time and space for understanding global change processes : the 1998 BBD Baikal Symposium of the Japanese Association for Baikal International Research Program (JABIRP), Yokohama, November 5th-8th, 1998 ¤ Lake Baikal is the oldest lake and largest freshwater reservoir in the world. As a result of its exceptionally long geological history, the lake has been a theatre of evolution and speciation of organisms, and it currently harbors more species than any other lake in the world. Based on its unique nature, Lake Baikal was recently designated a World Heritage site and is regarded as a hotspot for evolution, speciation, and biodiversity. With its tremendously peculiar biota, Lake Baikal is now awaiting modern analytical approaches to the profound problems of speciation and evolution. In late autumn 1998 a symposium was held in Japan with the theme

Physical and Mathematical Aspects of Symmetries : Proceedings of the 31st International Colloquium in Group Theoretical Methods in Physics ¤ Dedication to Bertram Kostant -- Preface -- Acknowledgments -- Organization of the Volume -- Committees -- Part I Laudatios: Wigner Medal and Weyl Prize -- Part II Plenary Invited Articles -- Part III Articles -- Part IV Short Articles -- Part V Memorials: S.T. Ali and L. Boyle This proceedings records the 31st International Colloquium on Group Theoretical Methods in Physics (“Group 31”). Plenary-invited articles propose new approaches to the moduli spaces in gauge theories (V. Pestun, 2016 Weyl Prize Awardee), the phenomenology of neutrinos in non-commutative space-time, the use of Hardy spaces in quantum physics, contradictions in the use of statistical methods on complex systems, and alternative models of supersymmetry. This volume’s survey articles broaden the colloquia’s scope out into Majorana neutrino behavior, the dynamics of radiating charges, statistical pattern recognition of amino acids, and a variety of applications of gauge theory, among others. This year’s proceedings further honors Bertram Kostant (2016 Wigner Medalist), as well as S.T. Ali and L. Boyle, for their life-long contributions to the math and physics communities. The aim of the ICGTMP is to provide a forum for physicists, mathematicians, and scientists of related disciplines who develop or apply methods in group theory to share their research. The 31st ICGTMP was held in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, from June 19th to June 25th, 2016. This was the first time that a colloquium of the prestigious and traditional ICGTMP series (which started in 1972 in Marseille, France) took place in South America. (The history of the colloquia can be found at http://icgtmp.blogs.uva.es/)

Mathematical and Theoretical Neuroscience : Cell, Network and Data Analysis ¤ 1 Simulating cortical Local Field Potentials and Thalamus dynamic regimes with integrate-and-fire neurons -- 2 Computational modeling as a means to defining neuronal spike pattern behaviors -- 3 Chemotactic guidance of growth cones: a hybrid computational model -- 4 Mathematical Modeling of Cerebellar Granular Layer Neurons and Network Activity: Information Estimation, Population Behaviour and Robotic Abstractions -- 5 Bifurcation analysis of a sparse neural network with cubic topology -- 6 Simultaneous jumps in interacting particle systems: from neuronal networks to a general framework -- 7 Neural fields: Localised states with piece-wise constant interactions -- 8 Mathematical models of visual perception based on cortical architectures -- 9 Mathematical models of visual perception for the analysis of Geometrical optical illusions -- 10 Exergaming for autonomous rehabilitation -- 11 E-infrastructures for neuroscientists: the GAAIN and neuGRID examples -- 12 Nonlinear Time series Analysis -- 13 Measures of spike train synchrony and Directionality -- 14 Space-by-time tensor decomposition of single-trial analysis of neural signals -- 15 Inverse Modeling for MEG/EEG data This volume gathers contributions from theoretical, experimental and computational researchers who are working on various topics in theoretical/computational/mathematical neuroscience. The focus is on mathematical modeling, analytical and numerical topics, and statistical analysis in neuroscience with applications. The following subjects are considered: mathematical modelling in Neuroscience, analytical and numerical topics; statistical analysis in Neuroscience; Neural Networks; Theoretical Neuroscience. The book is addressed to researchers involved in mathematical models applied to neuroscience

Software engineering, artificial intelligence, networking and parallel/distributed computing 2022-Winter ¤ This edited book presents scientific results of the 24th ACIS International Winter Conference on Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Parallel/Distributed Computing (SNPD2022-Summer) which was held on December 7-9, 2022, at Taichung, Taiwan. The aim of this conference was to bring together researchers and scientists, businessmen and entrepreneurs, teachers, engineers, computer users, and students to discuss the numerous fields of computer science and to share their experiences and exchange new ideas and information in a meaningful way. The conference organizers selected the best papers from those papers accepted for presentation at the workshop. The papers were chosen based on review scores submitted by members of the program committee and underwent further rigorous rounds of review. From this second round of review, 15 of the most promising papers are then published in this Springer (SCI) book and not the conference proceedings
